Entered Loss of FW heating off-normal 4005.01, Stationed Dennis Suchyta as Incident Assessor. Initial Feedwater temperature was 424F Performed immediate actions and closed A/B FCV from 85%/93% to 64%/77% - Initial Core flow - 82.6 MLBS/H - Above the MELLA limit 23:03 - Inserted all CRAM rods per sequence A2-02 - Final Core flow - 75.5 MLBS/HR - Below the MELLA limit 23:05 - Feedwater inlet temperature has dropped by 100F 23:06 - Placed Rx Mode Switch in S/D, entered CPS 4100.01, Reactor SCRAM off normal, Entered EOP-1 Established Rx Level band LVL 3 to LVL 8, Pressure band 800-1065psig 23:07 - Manually tripped main turbine 23:13 - Main turbine is reset 23:14 - Placed TBCCW Pump and Heat Exchanger B in service 23:24 - Started CA pump 'A' 23:47 - Condensate Polisher Status: A - Off service D - Off service F - Off service G - Off service H - Off service J - Off service B - On service C - On service E - On service CD pump 'D' running CB pump 'D' running MDRFP running 23:58 - Reset FCV runback, both RR FCV have been returned to 90% and locked out 06/11/2017: 00:16 - Exited EOP-1, entered 3006.01 00:45 - Initiated 9000.06D001, HEATUP/COOLDOWN, INSERVICE LEAK AND HYDROSTATIC TESTING 30 MINUTE TEMPERATURE LOG 01:05 - 1CY071 is throttled open to maintain 1CY003 20-40% open per 3304.01 section 8.2.18. 01:20 - Core monitor secured SJAE 'B' shutdown currently in progress Electrode 'B' startup in progress

While performing 9069.01 step 8.5.3 the SX pump C switch was taken to start and red light came on in the MCR. The following valves began to stroke, 1SX006C and 1SX014C. Approximately 30 after the switch was taken to start the amber light came on for SX C pump along with 5064-1A annunciator Auto Trip SSW pump 1C. The report from the field (EM's) was that the shaft never moved. The EM's recorded 470 amps of in rush current. The EM's were in the process of switching their meter over to record running amps when the pump tripped. The EM's believed that it is possible that the SX C pump tripped on thermal overloads. The EM's also reported a slight smell in the room that could have been coming from the thermal overloads.

During performance of N2-OSP-RPS-Q001, the Reactor scrammed on an automatic scram signal. Step 8.3.92 of N2-OSP-RPS-Q001, which stroked turbine control valves 1 and 2, was being performed at the time of the reactor scram. The automatic scram signal generated was due to Reactor HI Pressure. All systems responded as expected to the reactor scram signal.
ERAT SVC tripped. Ameren informed CPS that the Clinton Substation breaker tripped and closed most likely due to weather conditions and that the 138Kv line was available for use.

During performance of QCOS 2300-05, HPCI Pump Operability Test, the Unit 1 HPCI turbine did not trip when the REMOTE HPCI Turb. Trip pushbutton was depressed at step H.59.f.1. The NSO attempted to re-perform step H.59.f.1 multiple times with EMD present to check resistance across the pushbutton. Repeated use of the pushbutton did not cause the HPCI turbine to trip. The Unit 1 HPCI flow controller setpoint was set to 0 GPM at 1806 and flow reduced to approximately 3600 GPM. At time 1810 the US ordered Unit 1 HPCI to be shutdown by isolating the 1-2301-4 and 1-2301-5 valves, and this caused HPCI flow to reduce to 0 GPM. The 1-2317 HPCI stop valve remained open after the HPCI turbine was no longer turning. The local HPCI trip lever was withdrawn with no change in stop valve position or other parameters. During further QCOS 2300-05 steps the HPCI auxiliary oil pump was shutdown, which caused the 1-2317 HPCI stop valve to close. U1 HPCI remains isolated with the 1-2301-4 and 1-2301-5 valves closed.

Received multiple alarms due to trip of 4160V 1A1 breaker 1AP07EJ, 480V XFMR 1A and A1 breaker. Dispatched area operators to investigate trip of breaker. Many division 1 components lost power (powered from unit subs 1A and A1). Noted containment IA valves had lost power and were closed. Commenced monitoring for scram pilot air header pressure low alarm and potential for control rods to drift due to loss of air. Entered the Loss of IA, Loss of AC Off Normal procedures. Stationed Glidden as IA. 13:48 -- Secondary containment differential pressure has trended up and is positive due to a loss of Fuel Bldg ventilation (isolation dampers lost power). Entered EOP-8 due to low secondary containment differential pressure. 13:50 -- Div 2 VG was placed in service at 13:51 and secondary containment differential pressure was restored back in the normal band. On loss of 480 Volt Bus A and A1 lost the following: Division 1 AC Powered MOVs, Division 1 Isolation Dampers, Division 1 Water Leg Pumps, AC Power to Division 1 Battery Charger

This IR identifies a non-conforming condition with the Emergency Diesel Generator (EDG) Main Fuel Oil (FO) Storage tank vents with respect to tornado missile protection. Since the fuel oil supply (with the vent pipe) is an integral component of the EDG's and is not protected against tornado missiles, the design does not meet the licensing basis and a non-conforming condition exists. This design vulnerability applies to all three of Dresden's main fuel oil tank vents (EDG Fuel Oil Tank Vent Pipes: 2-5214-3", 3-5214-3" and 2/3-5214-3"). Since the vent piping for each main fuel oil tank is not protected from missiles, an event can be postulated that the vent piping becomes plugged or blocked from relieving negative pressure inside the main fuel oil tank while the day tank is being replenished. The EDGs would be expected to start and run until the day tank is depleted (approximately 4 hours). If the obstruction is not removed to allow the main storage tanks (EDG Fuel Oil Tanks: 2-5201, 3-5201, 2/3-5201) to equalize with atmospheric pressure, the fuel oil transfer pumps would lose the ability to refill the day tank and the EDGs would have no fuel oil for continued operation. NRC Enforcement Guidance Memorandum EGM 15-002, Revision 1, provides for application of NRC enforcement discretion which allows the diesel generators U2 Emergency Diesel Generator, 2/3 Emergency Diesel Generator and U3 Emergency Diesel Generator to be returned to an operable status based on the application of Compensatory Measures which are intended to minimize the likelihood that the tornado event would result in a failure of the EDGs. Application of the guidance in EGM 15-002, revision 1, and, NRC DSS-ISG-2016-01, revision 1, Appendix A, describes acceptable initial and comprehensive compensatory measures necessary to ensure that the identified nonconforming condition in this issue report can be treated by the NRC with enforcement discretion. The measures listed below should be verified as current and readily deployable within a very short timeframe. The resident inspector has been informed of this issue and of the intent to utilize enforcement discretion in accordance with EGM 15-002 (Rev 1). Extent of Condition: In August of 2015, Exelon Corporate Engineering initiated a project to identify the licensing basis for tornado-generated missiles at all Exelon plants. A report of initial potential vulnerabilities was generated using overly conservative assumptions (EC 404048). Additional reviews are being performed by Dresden Engineering and other departments with final discovery to be completed and documented in EC 619558. Cause: This is a legacy design issue not recognized during the original licensing of the plant. Other plants have identified similar non-conformance, and the NRC determined that a period of enforcement discretion was appropriate to allow the industry to resolve the non-compliances.

This IR identifies a non-conforming condition with the Unit 1, Unit 2 and Unit Emergency Diesel Generator (EDG) intake and exhaust stacks, fuel oil tank vents, and day tank vents with respect to tornado missile protection. If any of these lines were to become crimped by a missile impact, the associated EDG could become inoperable. The NRC has provided guidance for such issues in Enforcement Guidance Memorandum (EGM) 15-002, Regulatory Issue Summary (RIS) 2015-06, and Interim Staff Guidance DSS-ISG-2016-01. This IR documents the non-conforming condition and the implementation of EGM 15-002 to transition the SSCs from inoperable to operable but non-conforming. This IR documents that initial compensatory measures are in place, tracks development of longer term compensatory measures (within 60 days), and tracks resolution of the issue (by June 10, 2018), per the EGM 15-002 and DSS-ISG-2016-01. EC 619116 documents the evaluation performed to determine what, if any, non-conforming conditions regarding tornado missile protection exist. This evaluation addresses all components required for safe shutdown that are vulnerable to a tornado missile strike. Due to the ambiguity in the licensing basis, with regard to exterior missiles, the EDG intake and exhaust stacks, fuel oil tank vents, and day tank vents are conservatively being identified as non-conforming. The NRC reviewed issues related to tornado missile protection in RIS 2015-06. Licensees that identify tornado generated missile non-compliances that result in a Tech Spec (TS) LCO required shutdown may receive enforcement discretion as described in EGM 15-002. SSCs that are determined to be inoperable should be declared (logged) as inoperable, initial compensatory measures should be implemented and the SSC can be declared operable but non-conforming. Per EGM 15-002, additional compensatory measures specific to the vulnerability must be implemented within 60 days. The enforcement discretion will remain in effect for 3 years after the issuance of RIS 2015-06 (to 06/10/18). The enforcement discretion does not relieve the licensee of any reporting requirements. The resident inspector has been informed of this issue and of the intent to utilize enforcement discretion in accordance with EGM 15-002. EGM 15-002 states, "The staff will exercise this enforcement discretion only when a licensee implements initial compensatory measures prior to the expiration of the time allowed by the LCO that provide additional protection such that the likelihood of tornado missile effects are lessened." The EGM provides examples of potential compensatory measures that may be taken to lessen the effects of tornado missiles. The examples listed are: a)Development and implementation of procedures and conduct of training for plant staff in performing compensatory and mitigating actions related to tornado missile impact effects on identified safety-related SSCs, b)Actions to be taken if a tornado watch is predicted or issued for the area to secure potential missiles, protect equipment that could affect safety-related SSC operation, cease maintenance activities in progress on equipment that could affect availability of SSCs, repair/restore SSCs if undergoing maintenance, stage equipment necessary for mitigative actions in protected but promptly accessible locations, and c)Actions to be taken if a tornado warning is issued for the area (e.g., pre-staging of plant staff at safe, strategic locations to promptly implement mitigative actions, and alerting plant staff necessary for prompt mitigative actions of preparation for response following severe weather conditions). Procedures QCOA 0010-10 (Tornado Watch/Warning, Severe Thunderstorm Warning, or Severe Winds) and OP-AA-108-111-1001 (Severe Weather and Natural Disaster Guidelines) contain the existing Quad Cities compensatory measures as required by the EGM. These two procedures are entered concurrently when the entry conditions exist. Step D.10 of QCOA 0010-10 describes actions to consider if a tornado watch or severe thunderstorm is issued for an area that includes Quad Cities Station (upper Rock Island County). Actions to consider are: Designate personnel to inspect the site for potential missiles and secure the items as necessary. Verify the Unit 1, Unit 2 and Unit 1/2 Emergency Diesel Generators are available. If minor maintenance is being performed or short duration Clearance Orders are in effect on any Diesel Generator, consider returning the Emergency Diesel Generator to available status. If the Unit 2 125 VDC Alternate Battery is supplying Station loads, consider transferring back to the Normal Unit 2 125 VDC Battery. If the 345 kV ring bus is open, or is planned to be opened, for maintenance, consider taking actions to restore the ring bus as soon as possible and delay the planned maintenance. Review in-progress and planned work activities and consider expediting in-progress work and/or delaying upcoming work on systems needed to mitigate a loss of off-site power, mitigate transients, or place the Unit in a Cold Shutdown condition. If FLEX equipment is located external to the building for surveillance testing, then curtail the testing and return all equipment to storage. Procedure OP-AA-108-111-1001, Step 4.3 (Guidelines for High Winds and Tornados) provides similar guidance for preemptive actions that are contained in QCOA 0010-10. Once the storm has passed, Step D.16 of QCOA 0010-10 describes actions to compensate for potential damage to the Emergency Diesel Generator's intake and/or exhaust stacks. This step states, "If damage to any EDG's intake or exhaust piping is sufficient to consider the particular EDG inoperable, then the damaged portion of piping can be removed by any available means to allow operation of the subject EDG."

While Allied Boilermaker was shutting the inner airlock door on 828 containment personnel airlock after moving equipment in, he noticed the outer door was off its seat and coming open. He immediately shut the inner door and proceeded to call the Control Room. During this time Allied Pipefitters were opening the outer door. Both door indicators indicated closed prior to the outer door being opened. There was no resistance to opening of the outer door. When the outer door was about half open, the crew outside heard a grinding noise coming from inside the airlock. They entered the airlock and closed the outer door normally with no further adverse noises. They opened the inner door with no issues as they had not seen the inner and outer doors open at the same time and did not know there was a problem. The crew then left the containment through the same doors with no indication of any mechanical issues.

During the performance of 1BwOSR 3.8.1.11-1, 1A Diesel Generator Loss of ESF Bus Voltage with NO SI Signal, the 1A EDG did successfully start up and energize ESF Bus 141 as designed upon the actuation of an undervoltage to ESF Bus 141. The ESF loads were sequencing onto the Bus and after the 1A Aux Feedwater pump sequenced on the 1A EDG lost indication of speed and voltage and ESF Bus 141 also did not have voltage or amp indications. Individual motors that had sequenced onto the Bus also indicated 0 amps. The 1A EDG was still running with its output breaker ACB 1413 still closed. A loss of ESF Bus 141 was announced and the MCR team entered 1BwOA ELEC 3 for the loss of ESF Bus 141. The actions of 1BwOA ELEC-3 were successful in energizing Bus 141 from Unit 2 through the cross tie breakers although the first attempt to close in ACB 1414 resulted in the breaker closing into an immediate trip. The RNO actions were taken which directed the local operator to depress the Emergency stop pushbutton for the 1A EDG and then sync and close ACB 1414 which was successful.

During a 1B Diesel Generator monthly run the 1B DG tripped. Local panel annunciator 1PL08J-1-A7, Engine Overspeed is lit. Report from the 1B DG room is the turbocharger inlet butterfly valve springs are broken.

On Sunday, April 22, 2018 at 1646, a valid actuation of Engineered Safety Feature (ESF) Bus 141 Undervoltage (UV) Relay occurred. At the time, Unit 1 was performing a pre-planned 1A Diesel Generator (DG) Emergency Core Cooling System (ECCS) Actuation Surveillance, initiating the 1A DG to emergency start and sequence loads on a safety injection signal. Following the 1A DG solely supplying electrical power to Bus 141, the 1A DG lost voltage resulting in an unplanned UV actuation of ESF Bus 141. The 1A DG output breaker was manually opened and local emergency stop of the 1A DG was attempted. The 1A DG continued to run at idle. Fuel supply was secured to the 1A DG and the engine stopped. Subsequently, operators restored power to ESF Bus 141 from the Unit 1 Offsite Power Source. Following the shutdown of the 1A DG, BwOP DG-12T1 was completed with the following engine trips lit on the 1A DG panel: Engine Overspeed Engine Trip Under Frequency. 1BwOA ELEC-3 was entered and exited due to a momentarily loss of power to Bus 141. Off site power was restored to Bus 141 and the 1A DG control switch and ACB 1413 were placed in pull-to-lock.
At 04/30/2018 11:23:21.048 Unit 1 tripped on PN1025 TURBINE MOTORING GENERATOR -TRIP. Troubleshooting in progress.

At 0248, with the plant Shutdown in Mode 4, Nine Mile Point Unit 2 experienced a partial loss of off-site power during relay testing that resulted in an automatic start of the Division 2 Emergency Diesel Generator, trip of Shutdown Cooling Pump and Trip of Spent Fuel Pool Cooling pump along with automatic sequencing of the stations Service Water System. All systems responded as expected for the event. The station responded in accordance with appropriate Special Operating Procedures and restored impacted systems. Shutdown cooling was out of service for 6 minutes and reactor temperature increased approximately 2 degrees during the transient. Spent fuel pool temperature increased approximately 3 degrees during the transient and was restored approximately 23 minutes after the loss of power. Required notification was made to the NRC at 0859 under event report EN#53395.

Received a call from "C" area operator who identified that valves 1DG160 and 1DG161 are SHUT. These are the div 2 DG air start receivers. Sent a peer check out in the field with 3506.01P002 Div 2 Diesel Generator Operation procedure to verify valves and positions for DG air start system lineup, and return it to standby. With 1DG160 and 1DG161 SHUT, Div 2 diesel generator is INOPERABLE. Div 1 DG is presently INOPERABLE for div 1 4160V 1A1 partial bus outage. Enter the following ITS LCO actions: Suspend Core Alterations (Action Met, no core alts in progress) Suspend movement of irradiated fuel in the primary and secondary containment immediately (Action met, no fuel irradiated fuel movement in progress) Initiate action to restore required DG to OPERABLE immediately. Action in progress. Safety function determination and support/supported evaluation as follows: Evaluated for DRAIN TIME and ECCS OPERABILITY. With no ECCS pump powered by an OPERABLE on-site power source is not MET. With RHR-B in shutdown cooling and letdown mode and the RHR shutdown cooling isolations not powered by an OPERABLE on-site power source, evaluated DRAIN TIME. Based on current makeup flow rates to the reactor, the current DRAIN TIME is evaluated at 10.2 hours. Entered the following LCO actions: Enter the condition in the table Declare associated penetration flowpath incapable of auto isolation (RT/RHR) IMMEDIATELY (action met) Calculate DRAIN TIME IMMEDIATELY (action met) Restore required ECCS injection / spray subsystem to OPERABLE in 4 hours. (Due at 19:03). Verify secondary containment can be set within DRAIN TIME by 19:03 (Action met - secondary CTMT can be set, reviewed 1409.01 and secondary containment restraints) Verify secondary containment penetrations can be set within DRAIN TIME by 19:03 (Action met - secondary CTMT can be set, reviewed 1409.01 and secondary containment restraints) Verify standby gas treatment can be set within DRAIN TIME by 19:03 (Action met - SBGT 'B' is capable of manual start from the MCR) Reviewed plant risk. Currently div 3 DG, RAT, and ERAT electric power sources are AVAILABLE. There is no defined condition in OU-CL-104 for this condition with neither div 1/2 not having both onsite and offsite power, but div 3 onsite DG available. 15:39 -- Discussed with shutdown safety manager who agreed this is not a defined condition. The shutdown safety manager review of paragon trees initially classifies this condition as outage risk RED. Protected high pressure core spray, div 3 AC/DC/DG/SX. Notified security of change in system availability and protected equipment status. Shutdown Safety Manager is commencing an emergent SSRB per OU-AA-104. Per recommendation by Shutdown Safety Manager reviewed FLEX equipment deployment per 4306.01P017, and based on currently available resources, FLEX could be deployed prior to time to boil or DRAIN TIME and utilized for inventory control or decay heat removal. 16:03 -- Contacted Ameren and verified that there is no work actively ongoing that would impact 345 kV or 138 kV power to the station RAT or ERAT busses per outage contingency plan. 15:45 -- Completed performance of 3506.01P002 section 2.2 placing div 2 DG air start system to standby. Div 2 DG air receivers are now lined up to allow the div 2 DG to auto start if required. Div 2 DG is now AVAILABLE. Performing all sections of 3506.01P002 to verify all DG support systems are in service. OP-AA-108-106 Equipment Return to Service Checklist is in progress to fully restore division 2 DG OPERABILITY. 16:12 -- Verified all div 2 DG support systems are in service. 16:22 -- Corporate PRA engineer states that this is an outage RED condition. 16:38 -- Notified Security of plant risk change to YELLOW. Div 3 AC/DC/SX/DG and HPCS remain protected (HPCS is still INOPERABLE but AVAILABLE). 18:13 -- Emergent SSRB per OU-AA-104 reports that plant risk at the time of the div 2 DG unavailability was as follows: Electric: RED Spent fuel cooling: ORANGE Decay Heat Removal: ORANGE Inventory: YELLOW Reactivity: GREEN Containment: GREEN 19:03 . 4 hour action to restore an ECCS injection / spray subsystem to OPERABLE has elapsed. Div 2 DG remains INOPERABLE during administrative review of operability. Entered the following LCO actions: - Initiate action to establish a method of water injection capable of operating without offsite electric power . Immediately this action is met by HPCS system available as a water injection source capable of operating without an offsite electric source . Div 3 DG is available as an onsite source to power HPCS is called upon 21:04 System Return to Service checklist OP-AA-108-106 Attachment 2 has been completed and reviewed satisfactory for Division 2 DG. Field walkdown and panel walkdown have been completed and channel checks completed satisfactory. All PMT has been completed satisfactory and the Operability Restraint Database has been reviewed to verify no additional restraints to operability exist. A review has been performed utilizing the guidance provided in OPERATIONS DEPARTMENT STANDARDS AND EXPECTATIONS, section 4.27 Return to Service (No Work Performed). Division 2 DG is now OPERABLE.
On 6/4/2018 at 09:20, Unit 1 reactor was manually tripped following 1C FW pump trip during execution of 1BwOSR 3.3.2.8-621A.

While performing Safety System Status Report discovered the 1E22-F004 valve open vice required position of closed. Review of computer point HP-BC801 showed the valve went open at 8:47 6/20/18, local area operator reports that the 1E22-F004 valve indicates open locally and valve is not hot to the touch. No Alarms or other indications for a change in position of 1E22-F004 valve.

At 09:46, CPS experienced a trip of the ERAT SVC. Approximately 15 seconds following the trip of the ERAT SVC, the 4160KV bus 1A1 locked out the RAT feed breaker and the DIV 1 DG started and loaded to the 1A1 bus. Ameren was notified of the disruption in power to the 138KV line and the subsequent trip of the ERAT SVC and the fact that DIV 1 DG is powering the DIV 1 safety bus. Ameren informed CPS that Ameren received a report from Decatur dispatch that a 138KV to 13.8KV transformer number 2 at Clinton route 54 substation was on fire and the South feed to Tabor cycled as a result of this fault. The north feed from Bloomington to Tabor is out of service for line replacement until December. This caused the 138 KV feed to CPS to be de-energized for a short period of time. At the time of the event, 4160KV bus 1A1 was on the ERAT and 4160KV bus 1B1 and 1C1 were on the RAT as a result of the Op Eval associated with Open Phase Detection.

On 9/26/18 at 1908 CST, Unit 1 Reactor Automatic Scram signal was received due to Channel A/B Turb-Gen Load Mismatch Low EHC press. The turbine trip was due to GCB 7-8 tripping open with GCB 6-7 open for switching orders. The 3B and 3C Low Set Relief Valves actuated and reset to control reactor pressure. Plant is in a stable condition with reactor pressure being maintained by the Turbine Bypass valves. Reactor water level is being controlled with feedwater.

At 0901, during the performance of QCOS 6500-09, Functional Test of Second Level Undervoltage, the feed breakers to bus 13-1 from Bus 13 opened. This de-energized Bus 13-1 and Bus 18. The 1/2 EDG Auto-started but did not power Bus 13-1 due to conditions established for the test. The 1/2 EDGCWP did not start due to loss of power to Bus 18 and the 1/2 EDG was placed in stop at 0906. All other actions occurred as expected.

During troubleshooting of 12BY a Human Performance Error caused a loss of power to 12A. 'A' EDG started and tie into Bus 14 and 18 automatically. At the time of the event Bus 13 was tied to bus 14 and 'A' instrument bus was on maintenance supply. The Operating crew entered AP-ELEC.3 and restored power per ER-ELEC.1

On 10-28-18 at 0445, identified rising trend on all IRMs which rose high enough to cause a RPS actuation. RPS actuated on IRM upscale trips on IRM D, E, and G creating trips in Division 1, 3, and 4. Shutdown was in progress IAW 3006.01 at the time, the last bypass valve was shut 8 minutes prior, actions were being taken secure steam loads to control cooldown rate.

220-08 line tripped causing all 4KV busses to transfer to 3EA emergency transformer. E434 LC should re-energize in 3 seconds when power is restored. E434 failed to energize and had to be manually transferred.

On April 29, 2019 at 1633, Nine Mile Point Unit 1 scrammed due to reactor pressure oscillations of 7 psig and APRM oscillations of approximately 10 percent. Due to MPR being out of service due to an unrelated equipment issue, operations was required to manually scram the reactor due to pressure oscillations on the EPR IAW N1-SOP-31.2. All control rods fully inserted and all plant systems responded per design following the scram. Following the manual scram, the High Pressure Coolant Injection (HPCI) System automatically initiated as expected and was reset by operations.

At 03:48, an automatic reactor scram was received on turbine stop valve closure from turbine trip. The turbine trip was due to Turbine Bearing Pressure Low signal. Following the plant stabilization, U2 Turbine Building Floor Drain Sump Lvl Hi was received. The NLO sent to investigate the Hotwell basement reported approximately 1.5 inches of oil/water fluid mix in the basement and a stream of oil coming down the south wall from the LPHB above. NLO sent to the turbine deck to investigate behind the shield wall did not locate any abnormalities or indications of oil leaks at that level.

TDRFP B speed began coasting to zero rpm without a trip signal initially present to prompt Digital Feedwater Scram automatic actions and a Reactor Recirculation Flow Control Valve runback. RPV level lowered to level 3 and caused an automatic RPS scram. Mode switch has been placed in SHUTDOWN; scram choreography conducted; entered EOP-1 on level 3; entered 4100.01 Scram Off-Normal; Entered 4200.01 Abnormal RPV Level at Power; Mike Nelson stationed himself as Incident 02:27 -- RPV level reached level 2; HPCS and RCIC initiated; TDRFP A and B trip due to RCIC initiation; RR FCV's runback; RR pumps trip due to ARI; CRVICS groups 4, 8, 10, 12, 14, 15, 16, 19, and portions of 20 isolated; MDRFP started; Entered 4001.01 Automatic Isolation, 4008.01 Abnormal Coolant Flow; Performed level 2 walkdowns, SAT. 02:28 -- RPV level reached level 3 02:30 -- RPV level reached level 8; HPCS secured; RCIC automatically shutdown 02:38 -- Entered EOP-8 on RT B room cooler differential temperature high. This was caused by B RWCU pump seal failure after isolation of RWCU. 02:56 -- RPV level reached level 3 03:13 -- 0RIX-PR001 HI ALARM; 0RIX-PR012 started; entered 4979.01 Abnormal Release of Airborne Radioactivity 03:25 -- 1RIX-PR019 in ALERT. Entered 4979.02 Abnormal High Radiation Levels 03:26 -- VG B placed in PTL 03:33 -- Scram reset 03:56 -- Condenser Vacuum Pump B started 04:39 -- Exited EOP-8 due to RT B room cooler differential temperature returning to nominal value 05:00 -- CCW restored to Containment 06:03 -- VP A started; Drywell temperature 140F. 06:37 -- Division 3 DG shutdown Plant equipment status after walkdowns during transient: - loss of all running WO chillers (chillwater pumps remained running) - loss of instrument air to the Control Building and Service Air compressor #0 auto-started - FCV A would not re-open (IR 04269348) - RT B pump seal showed indications of failure - Digital Feedwater would not control in AUTO (IR 4269346)
At approximately 1743 it was noticed computer point K311 for RRMG 11 tach generator output was flashing DBAD. While investigating this computer point 11 RRMG tripped at 1745.

RO identified that both divisions of RT Differential Flow failed downscale. Declared Division 1 and Division 2 RWCU differential flow instrumentation (LCO 3.3.6.1 function 4.a RWCU differential flow - High) INOPERABLE. Entered the following LCO action statement: - Place channel in trip in 24 hours. - Restore isolation capability within 1 hour. The following LCO is not met due to loss of the support system function (RWCU differential flow high). Per OP-CL-108-104-1001 Section 2.7.1, in the event of a loss of initiation capability, the supported system shall be declared inoperable, and the Instrument LCO ACTIONS entered to address the LOSF. Therefore, LCO action entry is not required. - LCO 3.6.1.3 is not met for Div 1 RT isolation valves. - LCO 3.6.1.3 is not met for Div 2 RT isolation valves. 08:20 -- Contacted IMD GL for support. 08:22 -- Identified that Rx bottom head flow was zero gpm. 08:30 -- Performed CPS 3303.01 Section 8.2.8.4, to raise bottom head drain flow by opening 1G33-F101, Bot Hd Drn Suct. 08:52 -- Both Div 1 and 2 RT Differential Flows are reading 15 gpm and steady. Channel check SAT. Performed Equipment Return to Service checklist OP-AA-108-106 Attachment 1 has been completed and reviewed satisfactory for both Div 1 and Div 2 RT Differential Flow channels. No maintenance was performed; however operations re-established Bottom head flow IAW CPS 3303.01. MCR walkdown and panel walkdown have been completed and channel checks completed satisfactory. Both Div 1 and 2 RT Differential Flows are now OPEABLE. Exited LCO 3.3.6.1 actions and delay action into 3.6.1.3.

At 1106 on 9/23/19, Braidwood Unit 1 tripped on Lo-2 SG level in the 1B SG. MCR indications and field reports suggest a failure of the 1B Feedwater Regulating Valve 1FW520. Abnormal conditions noted from the trip: an electrical transient occurred on 0PR31/32J (MCR intake rad monitors) which realigned VC to makeup mode. Additionally, N-36 was noted to be reading higher than expected post transient and appears to be slightly under-compensated. Post Transient review is in progress per OP-AA-108-114.
Equipment operator on rounds noticed water dripping from the Control Room HVAC Air Filtration Unit. Field supervisor investigated and found a significant amount of water in the filter enclosure.

On 11/1/19 at 0316, Received Control Room annunciator 601706 HPCS SYSTEM INOPERABLE and associated computer point CSHBC01. Inop Status Light TRIP UNITS OUT OF FILE/POWER FAIL lit concurrently. Multiple HPCS trip units were indicating downscale and HPCS min flow valve 2CSH*MOV105 repositioned open. Operator attempted to close 2CSH*MOV105 to secure draining CSTs to Suppression Pool. Valve immediately re-opened. At 0324, HPCS pump suction was manually swapped from CST to Suppression Pool per N2-OP-33 H.6.0 to stop flow from CSTs to the Suppression Pool. HPCS System Pressure Pump discharge pressure was adjusted to 81 psig per ARP 601719. Annunciator 601719 HPCS SYS PRESS PMP DISCH PRESS LOW clear following suction swap to the Suppression Pool. HPCS high point vent was performed per N2-OSP-CSH-M001. No air was observed. HPCS trip unit power supply breaker was verified on and fuses verified good (F9-2CSHN10 and F10-2CSHN10). Suspect 24VDC power supply has failed based on good voltage readings at F9-2CSHN10 and F10-2CSHN10 (120VDC power to E22A-PS1 120VDC->24VDC) and no voltage found at either side of fuses F12-2CSHN10 and F13-2CSHN10 (24VDC from E22A-PS1 to HPCS Trip Units).

Observed GREEN off light indication not lit for the 'B' Control Room HVAC RCU on the 912-5 panel. Local light indication was also not lit. Discovered the feed breaker tripped at MCC 18-4 cubicle 1.D at 17:00. Reset feed breaker at 17:05 per Unit Supervisor, which restored all light indication.

There was a step change in Main Control Room noise level and vibrations above the ceiling. The sound was coming from the Control Room Ventilation area on TB 300'. All other Control Room parameters were normal and stable. The Field operator reported higher than normal noise and vibration from Control Room Ventilation ductwork and concurred that the cause of the noise was Control Room Ventilation Circ Fan and/or Motor 11. This is a sealed plenum, internal investigation was not possible. Attempted to swap from CR Circ Fan 11 motor to 12 motor (system is a common fan with two motors) but when the noise and vibes continued the CR Circ Fan was secured. At the same time of the Fan swap L1-4-1, CONTROL ROOM VENT SYSTEM TROUBLE was received along with computer points F151, Ventilation Flow Low and F152, Control Room DP Low. Also at the same time Local Fire Panel 4 Fire alarm came in with zone D-3054 TB 277 Control Room along with a smell of burnt rubber and a slight haze in the Main Control Room. At this point Alternate Control Room Ventilation was placed in service per N1-OP-49. Circ Fan 11 Motor was recently replaced 04/23/2020 per WO C93746246 due to elevated vibes.
11 4kv bus normal feeder breaker opened resulting in a loss of 11 4KV bus, cause is currently unknown. The 1A EDG restored power to 11 4KV as designed.
Received MCR PPC alarm for HPCS Water Leg Pump OFF and control power not available. Two minutes later we received a Div 3 system ground that cleared within 15 seconds.

During performance of N1-OP-1 H.1, lowering RRP 13 flow in preparation to secure it for planned maintenance, RRP 13 received an automatic trip. On Friday 3/11/21 RRMG 13 generator volts and amps were observed to be oscillating and IR 04408313 was generated. While lowering flow on RRP 13 to secure it, continued intermittent oscillations were noted, but magnitude and frequency of oscillations were not as severe as oscillations observed during initial discovery. Flow through RRP 13 was lowered to 12 million lbm/hr before automatic tripping at 2102. Appropriate SOP actions were performed following the pump trip, including shutting the RRP 13 discharge valve at 2110. No observable problems were noted locally at the RRMG or its associated breakers. APRM operability was affected during the period between RRP 13 automatic trip and discharge valve being closed.

AT 2219 HRS, UNIT 2 REACTOR WAS MANUALLY TRIPPED FROM 38% POWER DUE TO LOWERING STEAM GENERATOR LEVEL. 21 MAIN FEED REGULATING VALVE 2CV1111 APPEARS TO HAVE FAILED SHUT, RESULTING IN A LOSS OF FEED FLOW TO THE STEAM GENERATORS.

At 0051 on 6/21/21, Unit 1 received an automatic trip due to Generator Load Reject. No faults on bus 8 or L0104 were identified, and the ring bus has subsequently been restored. Post transient review in progress per OP-AA-108-114.

Control room operators observed lower than normal voltage on UPS 162A at ~115V (normal 120V) shortly after the control room received unexpected annunciator A3-1-2 UPS 162 TROUBLE just prior to a momentary loss of RPS 11. Dispatched operator to UPS 162A to investigate. The operator reported a Frequency Protective relay trip at the local panel with frequency oscillating approximately 0.5 Hz. At 03:42, power was momentarily lost to RPS 11 resulting in multiple annunciators, a half scram on channel 11, Reactor Water Cleanup Isolation, and Emergency Condenser 11 and 12 Isolation. Entered SOP 40.1 Loss of RPS 11. RPS 11 was transferred to its maintenance supply I&C 130A per N1-OP-40. The high Drywell pressure signal for Channel 11 was reset and the half scram was reset at 04:05. SOP 40.1 was executed with some exceptions: 1. Control Room Emergency ventilation did not actuate as expected. A Control Room Vent Rad Monitor Off Normal annunciator L1-4-2 was received and found to be caused by an equipment failure indicator on 11 Control Room Vent Rad Monitor. 2. Both ECs (Isolation Condensers) isolated on high steam flow (unexpected). This resulted in a "commence a shutdown in 1 hour and be Cold S/D in 10 hour" LCO entry. This was exited at 04:20 when 11 EC was restored to Standby. No LCOs were in effect for the EC Systems. A shutdown was NOT commenced. The team has reset all alarms with the exception of the: 1.CU System Isolation, K3-4-4, 2.Control Room Vent Rad Monitor Off Normal, L1-4-2, 3.RPS UPS 162 Trouble, A3-1-2.

During O-2.1 plant shutdown, following the planned reactor trip Tavg lowered and approached the minimum temperature for the current RCS Boron Concentration of 535F. Control Room Operators directed isolating flange heating steam and isolation of Blowdowns to maintain temperature. RCS Tavg continued to lower to 535F. In order to maintain RCS temperature above 535F feed to the Steam Generators was minimized. Main Steam Isolation Valves were closed per guidance in O-2.1 and RCS Tavg began to rise to 547F. During the event 'A' Steam Generator lowered to less than 17%. 'B' Steam Generator lowered to a minimum level of 33%.

At 1042 Hrs, Unit 1 started 12 SFP Cooling Pump (Breaker 52-2411). Upon start, 12 SFP Cooling pump breaker faulted to ground, causing feeder breaker 52-2412 to trip open. This resulted in a power loss to 24A 480V Bus, MCC 204R, and loss of 2Y10. The resulting transient caused lowering steam generator levels on both steam generators. U2 crew manually initiated a reactor trip from 100% power at 1046 11/21/2021 due to receipt of SG low level pretrips and not recovering.

During performance of QCOS 2300-05 at time 1843, Annunciator 901-3 B-9 "HPCI Motor Overload" was received. QCAN was referenced and SER showed cause to be a tripped HPCI gland exhauster. Operators were dispatched to 250 VDC Bus 1A and at time 1847 it was determined that indications of overheating were present in the thermal overloads in cubicle C02. HPCI was trip latched upon receipt of the report. At time 1905 it was determined that thermals for the HPCI gland exhauster in 250 VDC Bus 1A cubicle C02 were charred. At 1855 HPCI turning gear engaged and subsequently tripped on motor overloads and the 250 VDC 1A cubicle D01 was directed to be opened. No visible flame or fire was seen during these events.

During repair activities associated with 2FWS-LV10B a Reactor Level transient occurred resulting in a Reactor Scram on Low Reactor Level as well as initiations / isolations associated with Low-Low Reactor Level.

IR#4495001 was previously generated for an indication identified as part of ultrasonic testing of Penetration 75 of the U2 Reactor Head per WO# 05100141-01. When the issue report was generated, it was assumed that the flaw was only in one of the welds that acts as an anti-rotation device to prevent vibrations experienced during normal operations from causing the funnel to 'un-screw' and become detached from the nozzle (see attached photograph for reference). The weld itself is non-ASME, non-safety related and this was stated in the original IR. However, upon further review of the UT data contained in Framatome report INR-B2R23-UT-75, it has been identified that the location of the indication is NOT in the weld but in the actual CETC nozzle itself near the root of the weld. Specifically, the indication is located at 184 degrees with a length of 0.197" with a measured depth of 0.141" from the outer diameter surface and extends from 1.498" to 1.695" from the end of the nozzle. This was confirmed at 0854 on 4/23/2022 when reviewed by an NDE Level III qualified individual. Since the indication is in the CETC penetration nozzle itself and not the weld, even though the nozzle is not part of the pressure retaining boundary, it does fall within ASME Section XI and is Class 1 safety-related.
On 5/16/22 at 1537 PB U2 experienced a grid disturbance and received an A channel half scram. At 1552 received a group 1 isolation and automatic U2 full scram.

At approx 0104, Received 902-5 G-7 2A FW Reg trouble. The 2A feedwater reg valve failed closed and locked up. Rx level was 25" and lowering rapidly. NSO took manual control of feed water. At approx 11" a manual scram was inserted based on scram criteria of 11 inches Rx water level and lowering.

At 2217, Outside EO reports Intake Canal Level is < 501'6" due to buildup of grass on bar racks. UHS is INOPERABLE due to bay 13 level <501.5'. ENTER TS 3.7.3 condition A (RA A.1 mode 3 in 12 hours, RA A.2 mode 4 in 36 hours). ENTER DOA 0010-01, DRESDEN LOCK AND DAM FAILURE, due to intake level <501'6". ENTER DOA 4400-06, 2/3 CRIB HOUSE SCREEN PLUGGING, due to large buildup of debris on bar racks. Dresden Lockmaster reports river level normal at 504.89'. Intake level assigned to Outside Operator as a critical parameter and directed to report level every 6" change or every 30 minutes. Commenced trash rake operations per DOP 4400-14. At 2239, Intake Canal level 498.5'. At 2310, Intake Canal level 499'. Outside operator critical parameter changed to Bay 13 level and directed to report level every 15 minutes. At 2310, Bay 13 level 499' 2". At 2335, Bay 13 level 499' 9". At 2350, Bay 13 level 500' 0".
Unit 2 was manually Scrammed due to report of fire in U2 Generator Bus Ducts. Cause of the fire is unknown at this time.

During the Liquid Penetrant examination on the weld build up for CRDM Penetration 69 during A1R23, five rejected rounded indications were discovered. The first is a 1/4 inch rounded indication which was discovered at 90 degrees, on the nozzle at the weld saddle of the penetration. The second is a 1/4 inch rounded indication which was discovered at 90 degrees, on the nozzle portion of the weld build up and it is .5" from the transition of the head to penetration. The third is a 1/4 inch rounded indication which was discovered at 90 degrees, on the nozzle portion of the weld build up and it is 1.5" from the transition of the head to penetration. The fourth is a 1/4 inch rounded indication which was discovered at 180 degrees, on the nozzle portion of the weld build up and it is 1" from the transition of the head to penetration. The fifth is a 1/4 inch rounded indication which was discovered at 180 degrees on the nozzle portion of the weld build up and it is 2.5" from the transition of the head to penetration. 2 additional acceptable indications were discovered on the nozzle weld and 4 additional acceptable indications were discovered on the pad. These 6 acceptable indications will also be captured in the NDE report, 2022-PT-008 for trending. WO# 4872135-45 is for the removal of the rejected indications. 0 Degrees is located at the outermost portion of the penetration on the flange side (downhill/outermost side). The transition is the point where the vertical portion of the penetration meets the horizontal area of the reactor head. These indications will be documented in NDE report number 2022-PT-008.

0VE04CB, 0B VE Compressor tripped on High Oil Temperature. With 0A VC Compressor Inoperable, entered Tech Spec to restore the B VE HVAC compressor to operable in 30 days and to verify control room area temperature <90 degrees and to restore one control room area ventilation AC Subsystem to operable in 72 hours.

At 1400 a manual scram was inserted on high water level due to the 2B Feed Reg Valve failing open. Rx level was 44" and rising. At approx 44" a manual scram was inserted based on scram criteria of 44 inches Rx water level and rising.

1/31/2023 at 23:43 unexpected trip of 345kV switchyard breakers 4506 and 4510 resulting in main generator trip, main turbine trip, and reactor scram. All rods inserted fully. 2/1/2023 at 02:30: Ameren and NSED performed walkdown of 345kV switchyard relay house. Found relays 11#1-1014 and L7121-2 with LEDs illuminated for A Phase to Ground Fault on Latham transmission line. Relays indicate the fault is estimated at 16 miles from the CPS switchyard. Relay 11PCB-4510 has Breaker Failure LED illuminated for 4510 breaker failure and subsequent trip of 4506. Ameren technician reports visual inspection of 4510 found no deficiencies.
At 0910 received an auto scram on low charging water header pressure. At the time of the scram, unit 2 was in mode 4 with all rods full in. There were no complications with the scram.

During the U1 RCIC run, the LPCS pump is started to mix the suppression pool. When attempting to secure the LPCS pump after the RCIC run, the LPCS Pump Injection Flow HI alarm did not clear which prevented the LPCS Min Flow valve from opening on low flow. This condition inops the LPCS pump. 1E21-N004 was recently replaced on April 4th of this year and a PMT was performed by performing LIS-LP-102 which is a switch calibration.

On 8/11/23 at 0323 U2 had an Automatic SCRAM without complications due to a tribune trip caused by moisture separator drain tank high level. This event was caused by a loss of U2 ESS normal feed, inverter voltage read zero. U2 ESS went to its alternate feed; however, this caused all heaters on U2 to de-latch.

At approximately 2117 on 10/12/23 PPCS alarm was received for high air ejector off-gas flow (F2500). This was accompanied by multiple indications of degrading condenser vacuum. The crew entered AP-Turb.4, Loss of Condenser Vacuum, and initiated a load rejection in accordance with the procedure. Condenser backpressure degraded to the point that the DO NOT OPERATE REGION of Fig-13.0 was entered. After operation in the DNO region for greater than 5 minutes, the crew manually tripped the reactor IAW AP-Turb.4. E-0, Reactor Trip or Safety Injection was entered with no SI required. The crew transitioned to ES-0.1 and eventually closed the MSIV's to maintain RCS temperature. All other systems responded as required.

At 2048 annunciator F2-2-2 React Recirc M-G Set 12 was received. Also, computer points E053 RRMG SET 12 Trip and A081 GEN OVLD RELAY were received. Due to the Trip Reactor power lowered to approximately 88%

U4000-22 Transformer de-energized after its feeder breaker, 252-2103, tripped open, de-energizing associated 4kV buses 22, 23, 24. 2B Emergency Diesel Generator started and powered 24 4kV SR bus with no issues. EMD Support requested to investigate cause.

Per Procedure ER-DR-200-101 and WO 05410041-01; performed UT Water Solid Exams at (3) HPCI High Point Vent locations per ER-DR-200-101. While performing the exams identified the 2-HP-01 (ER-DR-200-101) location was indicating not water solid and had no indication of water in pipe in the immediate area within the vent location. Vent Valves 2-2304-A-500, 2-2304-A-501, on Line 2-2304-14" Stopped work immediately and notified the U2 Unit Supervisor. Subsequent exams at the vent location to try and supply an air void measurement for calculations identified that the horizontal run of pipe(approximately 28') was not water solid, but the verticals on each side of the horizontal line were water solid after the elbow to horizontal pipe weld. OPS performed Fill and Venting and subsequent UTs were performed at all (3) U2 HPCI locations per ER-DR-200-101. All (3) HPCI locations were found SAT - Water Solid.

During testing for L0104 relay upgrade, OCB 1-13 tripped on differential current and subsequently tripped the Unit 1 SAT. Unit 1 Division 1 4.16 kV 141Y/141X buses are powered by the '0' DG due to a failure of Fast Transfer to UAT. The '0' DG CWP is being powered by Unit 2 as expected. Unit 1 Division 2 4.16 kV 142Y/142X buses are powered by the UAT as expected. Unit 1 Division 3 4.16 kV 143 bus is powered by the Division 3 DG as expected.

On 5/5/24 @ 0330 U1 entered Mode 1 for planned startup. U1 was returned to Mode 2 at 0336 following issues controlling SG level. At 0338 an automatic Reactor Trip occurred on 1C SG Level Lo-2 following the Manual starts of 1A and 1B AF pumps per 1BwOA SEC-1. Post transient review in progress per OP-AA-108-114.

On 7/7/2024, the 0A VC Chiller had a sudden drop in visible oil level low out of the sightglass. The MCR was notified and was recommended to secure the 0A VC Chiller. The 0A VC Chiller was secured and the decision was made to establish the VS-VC crosstie for the 0A VC Train. The 0A VC Chiller was lined up in accordance with BOP VC-20. During the step to establish the cross-tie, Service Building WO flow was aligned to the 0B VC Train instead of the 0A VC Train. This caused the WO relief valve to lift on the 0B VC Chiller and caused the 0B VS Chiller to trip. The misalignment was identified and the lineups were restored to normal. The MCR regrouped, validated plant system alignments, then placed the VS-VC crosstie in service to the 0A VC Chiller. MCR temperature remains stable at approx 70F on the VS-VC crosstie. During the period that both chillers were inoperable, TS 3.7.11 Condition D was applicable. This was evaluated as requiring an 8-hour, non-emergency notification.
During power ascension for 2M09, unit 2 automatically scrammed.

During the Liquid Penetrant examination on the weld buildup for CRDM Penetration 31, 9 indications were identified with 5 indications being acceptable and 4 being rejectable were identified during the examination that exceed ASME Section III criteria. 0 Degrees is located at the outermost portion of the penetration on the flange side. The transition is the point where the vertical portion of the penetration meets the horizontal area of the reactor head. These four indications are documented in NDE report number B1R26-PT-001.

At 0720 on 09/23/24 Nine Mile Point Unit 2 Scrammed from 100% power due to a High Reactor Pressure caused by Turbine Trip. At time of Scram, Reactor Pressure indicated 1066PSIG in the main control room via computer point ISCPA100 "Reactor Pressure-A". Reactor Pressure rapidly rose due to a Turbine Trip caused by Generator Field high current. No major evolutions were occurring at the time of the Scram.

Observed GREEN off light indication not lit for the 'B' Control Room HVAC RCU on the 912-5 panel. Changed lightbulb twice and light was still extinguished. Dispatched FS. Local light indication was also out. The feed breaker appeared to be not tripped at MCC 18-4 cubicle.

During performance of ST-2-055-609-2, when low steam pressure was simulated to the HPCI system, the HV-055-2F093 valve auto closed. No high drywell condition at the time of the isolation. Attempted to open valve per arc actions with the Low steam pressure trip in and no low DW pressure, valve failed to open.

During EMD performance of Semi-Annual PM 517 RB/TB INTERLOCK DOOR ELECTRICAL CHECKS per WO 1450006-01, received an UNEXPECTED ALARM 902-4 E-19, RX/TURB 517 INTLK DOORS INOP/BYP. Alarm came in at 0046 and cleared 9 seconds later. ENTERED TS 3.6.4.1 for 9 seconds. Doors were verified closed and working properly by NLO.
ERDS was not functioning between PBAPS and the NRC from 1730 to 1918. The problem was on the NRC end and has been resolved.

Indications identified on ID of existing nozzle at U2 Reactor Vessel penetration N11B. Indications discovered during surface examination of weld prep area for nozzle repair per WO 1529316-01. The indications were identified at 90 degrees and 270 degrees looking at the penetration from OD of RV. These indications are located in the section of the nozzle that will remain after the repair, but not part of the pressure boundary. The remaining portion of the nozzle is being evaluated for loose parts concerns as part of this repair. Refer to EC388684 for loose parts evaluation. This nozzle is unique as it was replaced after initial fabrication and prior to installation. Extent of condition is limited to this particular nozzle.

This IR is being written as a follow-up IR upon receipt of an NRC violation as part of the 2012 PI&R FASA (IR 1338977). THIS ACTION IS CLOSED. This IR is being generated to meet the requirements of LS-AA-1003. Per the procedure, once an NRC Inspection Report is issued with a Finding or Violation, the NRC Coordinator is responsible for generating an IR that requires the responsible organization to review the NRC Violation and ensure the Station response and corrective actions properly address the violation. From the 2010 NRC 4th Quarter Integrated Inspection Report (2010-005). The inspectors determined that the issue is closed: (Closed) Licensee Event Report 05000457/2010-002-00: Containment Spray Pump Suction Valve Failed to Close Resulting in Unanalyzed Plant Condition Due to Procedure Error. On June 17, 2010, Unit 2 containment spray (CS) pump suction valve 2CS009B failed to close during a quarterly surveillance test. Upon evaluation of the potential consequences of this failure, the licensee identified and reported an 8-hour non-emergency unanalyzed condition that significantly degraded plant safety. The licensee manually restored the valve to the normally closed position, eliminating the condition. During a loss-of-coolant accident, both the emergency core cooling and CS systems utilize the RWST as a water source. Upon the receipt of a RWST lo-2 level, both automatic and manual actions are performed to align the emergency core cooling system (ECCS) water source from the RWST to the containment sump. Upon a RWST lo-3 level, the plant licensing basis assumes that the CS system is manually aligned from the RWST to the containment sump by opening CS009A and CS009B valves and isolating the RWST by shutting the CS001B valve. The license identified that during the performance of the surveillance, if the CS009A/B valves failed to shut (as on June 17, 2010, or from an assumed license basis active single failure) and if a safety injection had occurred, that upon the receipt of a RWST lo-2 level signal, a portion of the RWST would drain back into the containment sump via the open CS009A/B valve. Until the ECCS swap over was completed, an unanalyzed amount of RWST borated water would have drained into the containment sump and would not have been available for injection and assumed accident boration. This condition also applied to Unit 1. The licensee determined that the root cause of this condition stemmed from inadequate reviews since the plant was originally licensed and inadequate procedures created and implemented in 1988. Upon licensing, additional revisions to the surveillance procedure did not identify the unanalyzed condition. The inspectors reviewed this LER and determined that it was completed in accordance with NRC regulations. The licensees review determined that the station did not have an adequate procedure for performing this surveillance activity and implemented changes to prevent recurrence. The inspectors identified that this issue was a performance deficiency that had been identified by the licensee and entered into the stations CAP. The enforcement aspects of this finding are discussed in Section 4OA7 of this report. This LER is closed. This finding was determined to be of very low safety significance based on an estimated core damage probability of 9.6 E-8.

AUTOSTART OF DIVISION 3 DIESEL GENERATOR FOLLOWING 4160 VOLT LINE OUTAGE On 4/2/12 at 1511 CDT, GGNS Grand Gulf Nuclear Generating Station received a valid ESF actuation for emergency AC power to Division 3 4160V bus due to degraded voltage. One of the two 500KV offsite feeders tripped causing a drop in grid voltage which resulted in a trip of the ESF feeder breaker for 4160 Volt Division 3 bus. The HPCS (High Pressure Core Spray) Diesel Generator automatically started and energized the bus. The HPCS system was not running and no ECCS initiation occurred during this event. The plant was in Mode 5 with RHR A in shutdown cooling. Divisions 1 and 2 ESF power monitoring instrumentation responded to the grid voltage transient but no actuation setpoints were reached. Division 1 and 2 ESF 4160V buses remained energized and shutdown cooling remained in service. The 500KV offsite feeder and additional 115 KV feeder remained in service. The 500KV feeder that tripped was restored by the dispatcher at approximately 1515 CDT. The Division 3 bus was subsequently transferred back to offsite power and the HPCS Diesel Generator was secured. A lightning strike resulted in a voltage transient on the GGNS electrical distribution system. Due to this transient, the 'A' Control Room Air Conditioning Unit (CRAC 'A') tripped and had to be manually restarted. CRAC 'A' was not running for approximately two minutes. During this timeframe CRAC 'B' was tagged out of service. This was evaluated and determined to not be a loss of safety function. Emergency Class: NON EMERGENCY

UNPLANNED SYSTEMS ACTUATIONS WHILE PERFORMING A SURVEILLANCE TEST Unit 1 was performing a planned refueling outage surveillance test, FNP-1-STP-40.0, 'Safety Injection with Loss of Off-Site Power LOSP.' The systems were being returned to normal following the actuation portion of the test. When the B1F Sequencer Test Trip Override Switch was taken to the 'ON' position, the 1-2A Diesel Generator output breaker opened, which caused a loss of power to the 'A' Train 4 kV busses. Prior to the event, the 1-2A Diesel Generator was running at normal speed and voltage carrying the 'A' Train 4kV busses. When the diesel generator output breaker opened, it then reclosed upon receipt of the LOSP signal causing the LOSP sequencer loads to automatically start. This included the 1C Component Cooling Water Pump, the 1A High Head Safety Injection Pump (discharge isolation was closed prior to the event), and the 1A and 1B SW pumps. Therefore, during the test, the system actuated in a way that was not part of the planned surveillance testing. The 1A RHR pump was in shutdown cooling mode at the time of the event and was load shed. RHR was restarted manually by the operating crew approximately 1 minute later (no auto start signal present due to a loss of site power - LOSP signal without a safety injection signal present). The investigation revealed that a step in the procedure sequence was not performed during the restoration portion of the test. The operator did not parallel the diesel with off-site power prior to operating the B1F Sequencer Test Trip Override Switch which opened the diesel output breaker without off-site power aligned to the 'A' Train 4kV busses. The 1-2A Diesel Generator was subsequently paralleled to the grid and properly shutdown per the test procedure restoration. Emergency Class: NON EMERGENCY

The Drywell Spray Function is not currently in the Peach Bottom Technical Specifications. During a Small Steam Line Break (SSLB) event, drywell sprays are required in order for the containment temperature to remain below 340 deg. F. Since the drywell sprays are required to mitigate the SSLB, based on Criterion 3, the drywell spray function is required in the Technical Specifications. Peach Bottom's requirements for the RHR drywell spray function are contained in Section 3.12 of the Technical Requirements Manual (TRM). Those requirements were removed from Peach Bottom's Technical Specifications at the time of conversion to improved standard technical specifications (ITS) in January 1996. The following justification was provided for removal from tech specs: "The drywell spray is not credited in any DBA (i.e., it is not needed to function to mitigate the consequence of any design basis accidents) and it is a secondary action in the emergency procedures. Therefore, drywell spray is not risk significant and can be relocated outside of Technical Specifications. This change is consistent with NUREG-1433." At the time of removal, drywell spray was not needed to mitigate a Recirc Suction Line Break, which was considered the bounding accident, and is currently the only LOCA described as a DBA in the UFSAR. Although evaluated as not being required to mitigate a DBA, drywell sprays were, and still are, the primary success path for mitigating a steam line break (in the drywell). At the time of the ITS conversion, Peach Bottom did not have an SSLB analysis. An SSLB analysis was performed for Peach Bottom under GE-NE-0000-011-4483 in 2003. This analysis states that "steam line breaks are the most limiting events for drywell temperature response", and "these analyses, with primary focus on the drywell temperature response, took credit for containment sprays and structural heat sinks in the drywell and wetwell airspace." The Peach Bottom-specific analyses confirm that drywell sprays are relied upon to limit the peak drywell temperature for an SSLB. NEDO-31466 Supplement 1, Technical Specification screening Criteria application and Risk Assessment, dated February 1996 (the analysis that provides the basis for what is in and not in TS) concluded (on page 5-53) that: "Thus, the drywell spray mode of RHR is not considered as part of the primary success path for mitigation of postulated design basis accident." This statement supported the drywell spray function removal from Tech Specs when ITS was implemented. However, there is a note on page 5-53 which states: Note: Some Mark 1 containments do take credit for containment spray for long term containment response to small break LOCAs to ensure that the peak drywell temperature remains below its design value. This note provided an exception to the basic argument that DW spray is not required to be in TS. However, if DW spray is credited for SSLBs, NEDO-31466 Supplement 1 indicates that Drywell Spray should not have been removed from the Technical Specifications. As stated previously, Peach Bottom did not have an analysis for the SSLB when ITS was implemented. When the GE analysis was performed in 2003, an opportunity to identify that drywell sprays should be in Technical Specification presented itself. However, since the DBA-LOCA (Recirc Line Break) was still the bounding radiological accident and NEDO-31466 Supplement 1 was not readily known in 2003, no action was taken to move DW Spray back into the TS at that time. Another opportunity for identification that the drywell spray function should be in the Technical Specifications occurred in 2003 during PORC review of an evaluation. In 1996, when the Drywell Spray Technical Specification was removed from the Tech Specs and placed in the TRM, the action statement required a shutdown. As part of a regulatory assurance initiative, TRM actions statements that required Unit shutdown were reviewed for removal. As part of this initiative, the action statement for drywell spray inoperability was changed. TRMS 3.12, RHR Drywell Spray, Condition C was revised to require implementation of the Corrective Action Program (CAP) and receive management approval for exiting the condition instead of entering Mode 3 in 12 hours and Mode 4 in 36 hours in the event that one RHR drywell spray subsystem is inoperable for 7 days or if both subsystems are inoperable for 8 hours. This TRM change occurred in 2003 following PORC approval the Evaluation. Engineering Assessment of Operability: Since Peach Bottom is not currently in an Action Statement for TRM 3.12, both loops of drywell spray are considered operable (for both Unit 2 and Unit 3). Reportability Assessment: Regulatory Assurance, Operations, and Engineering discussed this issue for reportability. While on-shift Operations personnel will need to make the determination, the discussion resulted in the following recommendation: This event would not be considered as a prompt NRC notification in accordance with reporting requirements. Preliminary review of the TRM 3.12 entries for the previous 3 years have not identified any instances when the completion time was not met for an inoperable drywell spray sub-system. However, formal review is required and is requested in the Recommended Action section.

At 1030 EDT Dresden station completed notification to the NRC Reactor Plant Event Notification Worksheet. The notification was assigned event number 48080. The notification was for the Invalid group 5 Isolation Due to Failed Test Switch During Surveillance. The notification read as follows: "At 0236 CDT on Tuesday, July 10 2012, the Dresden Nuclear Power Station (DNPS) U3 Isolation Condenser System automatically isolated due to a inadvertent partial Group 5 Primary Containment Isolation System (PCIS) isolation, causing the inboard isolation valves to close. The PCIS isolation was caused during the performance of DIS 1300-07, U3 Isolation Condenser Steam/Condensate Line High Flow Calibration due to a failed test switch. The test switch failed to bypass the PCIS signal generated during the surveillance. All valves responded as expected due to this condition. The isolation condenser was declared inoperable and Technical Specification 3.5.3, Condition A was entered. HPCI was verified to be operable to satisfy the requirements of TS 3.5.3, Condition A.2. This condition is reportable due to a condition occurring that could have prevented fulfillment of a safety function needed for residual heat removal.

At 12:00 on July 13, 2012 it was determined, during a conference call with the Exelon siren vendor, that Oyster Creek emergency planning zone (EPZ) sirens may be unreliable. The unreliability is being caused by an intermittent signal on the frequency used to activate the sirens. A 4-hour NRC report was made on 7/13/12 at 1420 based on the following: Exelon contacted the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) for troubleshooting and reporting purposes, as well as the New Jersey Office of Emergency Management (NJ OEM) and the Ocean County Office of Emergency Management to institute compensatory actions. Exelon will notify the NRC Operations Center upon full-restoration of the Oyster Creek EPZ siren system. The interfering signal appears to be resulting from an atmospheric phenomenon that has resulted in the transmission of a radio signal, at the same frequency as the siren control frequency, from the New York City area. This is based on information from the FCC.

At 0329 on 7/23/12, the reactor automatically scrammed due to a loss of offsite power. Both EDG's started and loaded. Crew entered applicable EOP's, ABN's and normal procedures to stabilize reactor pressure using both isolation condensers and stabilize RPV water level using CRD and subsequently RWCU letdown. Shift Manager declared UE at 0341 and completed notifications. Offsite power was subsequently restored to startup transformers and the EDG's secured. Plant is currently cooling down.

MCR received 5050-1J SMOKE VC SYSTEM. The VC supply air filter 0VC07SA went into service as expected. The area operator was dispatched and noted an alarm on detector 0XE-VC095A Control Room Main Air Intake Smoke Detector. No smoke was detected in the area and security reported no smoke outside in the vicinity of the plant. The alarming detector was reset per the ARP and the filter went into bypass as expected.

The MCR was notified by IT (T. Barnett) that ERDS was unavailable and that the issue was believed to be an equipment problem at the NRC end. This was supported by the fact that the other Exelon Midwest ROG sites were experiencing similar issues. IT later called to confirm that the issue had been resolved and that the problem had been positively identified as an NRC equipment issue. Total time between the initial notification of unavailability and the call confirming that ERDS communication had been reestablished was approximately 33 minutes.

While securing the "A" Condensate string, CO-P-2C tripped when CO-P-1A was placed in Normal-After-Stop. CO-P-2A/B attempted to start multiple times (green light and amps flickered on each attempt). Reactor tripped on high RCS pressure.

IR 1414490 describes an event at LaSalle in which secondary containment integrity was adversely impacted. Corporate Licensing was contacted by LaSalle Operations to perform a peer check for potential reportability to the NRC. LS-AA-1110, Revision 17, SAF 1.8 was reviewed as part of that effort. SAF 1.8 contains an error with respect to when a loss of secondary containment is considered reportable. Specifically, SAF 1.8 includes a condition that vacuum must be less than allowed by the plant's Technical Specifications in order for a loss of secondary containment to be reportable. This condition was added in response to ATI 1212744 based upon a violation documented in an NRC inspection report for LaSalle (i.e., Inspection Report 2011002, dated 5/11/11). The violation concerned a failure to report to the NRC an event in which secondary containment could not have fulfilled its safety function. The NRC stated that because secondary containment had been declared inoperable that it could not based on the Tech Spec definition of Operable/Operability perform its safety function, and as such should have been reported to the NRC. However, Revision 17 of LS-AA-1110 incorrectly translated the NRC's basis for the violation by including the condition that vacuum must be less than allowed by the plant's Technical Specifications in order for a loss of secondary containment to be reportable. The reason the event was reportable was because secondary containment was declared inoperable due to the failure to maintain the required vacuum. Other unplanned events in which secondary containment is declared inoperable but for which vacuum is satisfactory would be screened as not reportable per the current guidance in SAF 1.8. This is contrary to the NRC requirements and could result in future NRC violations for failing to make required NRC notifications. LS-AA-1110 SAF 1.8 should be revised to read as follows: "Loss of secondary containment is considered reportable. A breach of secondary containment (which includes simultaneous opening of two interlock (or airlock) doors) is considered reportable if the following conditions are met: 1) secondary containment is required in the current mode or other specified condition; 2) secondary containment is declared inoperable in accordance with the plant's Technical Specifications; and 3) the reason(s) for inoperability is (are) not part of a planned evolution."

During observations of work activities in U2 Reactor building, 135' elevation, NOS identified and coached several individuals for violating secondary containment 'blue light' and horn. Individuals were observed from Williams Specialty, Shaw, and MedTex who received blue light indication and warning buzzer when attempting to open Door 190 or 191, yet proceeded to open the door and pass through. One individual even held the door for a coworker to pass through despite the warning buzzer.

Limerick's load sequencing of safety related loads during a design basis loss of coolant accident with offsite power available intentionally sheds all 480v loads on the LOCA affected unit when reactor level reaches Level 1 and low pressure ECCS pumps start. MOVs that are already stroking closed from previous isolation signals (like high DW pressure or reactor level 2) will stop during the load shed. If the MOV stops in the 'dead zone' where the valve indicates closed, those MOVs that use LS-8 as an isolation permissive will not resume isolation when 480v power is restored. LS-8 provides a permissive for automatic isolation that ensures that the valve gets approximately 90% or further closed. A closed contactor seal in (42C/ 'a' switch) ensures that the valve continues fully closed when LS-8 opens. After the torque switch trip, the seal in contact opens to remove the auto isolation signal (anti-hammering circuit). Removal of the isolation signal is required for MOVs with non-locking gear sets since the torque switch will reclose, reinitiating the valve closure over and over if LS-8 did not remove the signal. IR1402693 identified three CAC isolation valve on each unit that would have power interrupted in the dead zone. The subject CAC isolation valves in the original IR were temporarily resolved on Unit 1 by short stroking the valves to close within 3 seconds. Unit 2 CAC isolation valves remain to be short stroked and are considered inoperable until this is completed. The extent of condition of the original IR1402693 condition was reviewed. In addition to the CAC valves, four chilled water inboard isolation valves are also affected. HV-087-122, HV-087-123, HV-087-128, and HV-087-129 have a dead zone that occurs at approximately 36 to 37 seconds after the high drywell pressure isolation initiation during a LOCA. The outboard isolation valves are not affected. If the level 1 load shed occurs while the valve is traveling closed in the dead zone, the seal in is lost at the same time LS-8 is open, and the valve will not isolate but will indicate fully closed. Plant staff is investigating if landing in the dead zone is credible and within the licensing basis. Plant staff feels that it is prudent to jumper out LS-8 in the interim until the investigation is completed. This is acceptable since this actuator gearing is locking and the LS-8 anti-hammering feature is not required. This jumper and post maintenance test will be done expediently per a temporary modification that provides an appropriate jumper in a convenient location (control panel or MCC) to remove the vulnerability. Follow up to make permanent will be done based on the results of the investigation. Appropriate testing will be done to prove that the valve performs its safety function after modification.

Limerick's load sequencing of safety related loads during a design basis loss of coolant accident with offsite power available intentionally sheds all 480v loads on the LOCA affected unit when reactor level reaches Level 1 and low pressure ECCS pumps start. MOVs that are already stroking closed from previous isolation signals (like high DW pressure or reactor level 2) will stop during the load shed. If the MOV stops in the 'dead zone' where the valve indicates closed, those MOVs that use LS-8 as an isolation permissive will not resume isolation when 480v power is restored. LS-8 provides a permissive for automatic isolation that ensures that the valve gets approximately 90% or further closed. A closed contactor seal in (42C/ 'a' switch) ensures that the valve continues fully closed when LS-8 opens. After the torque switch trip, the seal in contact opens to remove the auto isolation signal (anti-hammering circuit). Removal of the isolation signal is required for MOVs with non-locking gear sets since the torque switch will reclose, reinitiating the valve closure over and over if LS-8 did not remove the signal. IR1402693 identified three CAC isolation valve on each unit that would have power interrupted in the dead zone. The subject CAC isolation valves in the original IR were temporarily resolved on Unit 1 by short stroking the valves to close within 3 seconds. Unit 2 CAC isolation valves remain to be short stroked and are considered inoperable until this is completed. The extent of condition of the original IR1402693 condition was reviewed. In addition to the CAC valves, four chilled water inboard isolation valves are also affected. HV-087-222, HV-087-223, HV-087-228, and HV-087-229 have a dead zone that occurs at approximately 36 to 37 seconds after the high drywell pressure isolation initiation during a LOCA. The outboard isolation valves are not affected. If the level 1 load shed occurs while the valve is traveling closed in the dead zone, the seal in is lost at the same time LS-8 is open, and the valve will not isolate but will indicate fully closed. Plant staff is investigating if landing in the dead zone is credible and within the licensing basis. Plant staff feels that it is prudent to jumper out LS-8 in the interim until the investigation is completed. This is acceptable since this actuator gearing is locking and the LS-8 anti-hammering feature is not required. This jumper and post maintenance test will be done expediently per a temporary modification that provides an appropriate jumper in a convenient location (control panel or MCC) to remove the vulnerability. Follow up to make permanent will be done based on the results of the investigation. Appropriate testing will be done to prove that the valve performs its safety function after modification.
