Originator: DAVID J HABERKORN 
Supv Contacted: T. Gallentine 

During the final clear of C/O 104822 for the U2 RWCU sample valves, the EO entered the U2 RWCU heat exchanger room in order to execute a step of the clearance. During the execution of the step in the room, DPI 1-5740-22, RB TO ATMOS DP indicated less than -0.1" H20 and 912-5 C-1 RX BLDG 1 LOW DP and 912-5 C-4 RX BLD 2 LOW DP alarms were received. Reactor building went >0" dP for two minutes until the door was closed. Technical Specification 3.6.4.1 Condition A and QGA 300 were entered. Two minutes later, Reactor Building DP was restored to >-0.10" H20. Exited T.S. 3.6.4.1 Condition A. No emergency existed and exited QGA 300. 

Immediate actions taken: Entered/exited T.S. 3.6.4.1 Condition A. 

Recommended Actions: System Manager to investigate and determine the necessary system control improvements to prevent unnecessary T.S. entries during normal operations. 

What activities, processes, or procedures were involved? Final clear of CO 104822, while entering RWCU HX room. 

Why did the condition happen? Low Reactor Building to atmosphere DP during execution of a clearance order. 

What are the consequences? Entry into T.S. 3.6.4.1 Condition A and QGA 300. 

Repeat or similar condition? Yes - refer to recent IRs including IRs 1412296, 1416123, 1416156, 1417996. 

Operable Basis: T.S. 3.6.4.1. Cond A Secondary Containment was entered and exited as required. Secondary Containment vacuum has been verified to be greater than or equal to 0.10 inch of vacuum water gauge. Secondary Containment has been restored to Operable status. 

Reportable Basis: Reference SAF 1.8 as needed.

Functional Basis: The Reactor Building ventilation system is functional but degraded. RB dP has been restored, but the RWCU/RB dP control systems should be capable of maintaining normal dP during RWCU room entries. Because it is slow to respond, this leads to unnecessary T.S. entries. 

Reviewed by: MICHAEL F MACLENNAN 09/26/2012 11:38:01 CDT 
Reviewer Comments: Close to actions in progress under IR 1417996.

SOC Reviewed by: MARK L BRIDGES 10/15/2012 08:41:22 CDT 
SOC Comments: From System Manager: The RWCU rooms have their own dp control systems. This issue is not directly related to other rx bldg dp issues. System Manager recommended WR to check dp control system for this zone. (Note: WR may be initiated from earlier IR 1417996. Luebbe/Rushing 9/26/12). * Close to WR. (SOC 9/27/12) 
* SL 3 assigned given issue is an MRFF. In addition, this issue has been determined to be an unplanned LCO entry which could lead to unit shutdown (OM.01 indicator). (Richter, 10/01/12) 
* Follow up to Eng. (SOC 10/2/12)
* Close to actions taken, WR, ATs 1409820-03, AT 1412296-02, AT 1418466-02 and WGE to Engineering to address the new issue of RWCU area affecting RB DP. (Trettin - 10/2/12) (SOC 10/3/12) (SOC 10/15/12) 
* Follow up to Shift to revisit Reportability per MRC Comments (Bridges 10/12/12) 
MRC Note 10/01/12 - Per MRC issue on POD, Engineering and OPs evaluating options. (p mcgarvey) 
Per Sr Staff Engineering 10/01/12 - Return to SOC for assignment of Maintenance Rule Functional Failure assignments. (p mcgarvey) 

Reviewed by: JAMES G TRETTIN 10/02/2012 11:02:28 CDT 
Reviewer Comments: This event is a MRFF. SL3 applies. MRFF attribute added. MRFF assignment added. This event is not a CCF because the component is not a critical component (category 8), the DP controller is a category 7 component. Additional investigation is being performed under IR 1409820 (ACE). A Plant Health Committee presentation is tracked under AT 1412296-02 to address Reactor Building D/P issues. Close to actions taken, WR, ATs 1409820-03, AT 1412296-02, and AT 1418466-02 (Trettin - 10/2/12) 

Department review performed by: JEREMY BRIES 10/09/2012 14:35:04 CDT 
Evaluation Comments:

Condition/Problem Statement: During the final clear of clearance order (C/O) 104822 for the U2 Reactor Water Clean Up (RWCU) sample valves, the Operator entered the U2 RWCU heat exchanger room in order to execute a step of the clearance. During the execution of the step in the room, DPI 1-5740-22, RB TO ATMOS DP indicated less than -0.1" w.c. and 912-5 C-1 RX BLDG 1 LOW DP and 912-5 C-4 RX BLDG 2 LOW DP alarms were received. Reactor Building to Atmosphere DP was > 0" for two minutes until the door was closed. Technical Specification 3.6.4.1 Condition A and QGA 300 were entered. Two minutes later, Reactor Building DP was restored to < -0.10" w.c. TS 3.6.4.1 Condition A was exited. No emergency existed and QGA 300 was exited.

Statement of Cause: The two alarms received in the Main Control Room were caused by a loss of Reactor Building DP and U2 Area DP. The area DP was lost when the door to the RWCU room was opened. This is an expected alarm as the Area DP is a comparison of the pressure in the RWCU vs. the pressure on the refuel floor. Opening the door causes the DP between those two areas to become zero. The loss of Building DP was caused by two air leaks in the pneumatic control instrumentation for the U2 Area DP (see IR 1421995). The air leaks degraded the signal air to the U2 Area DP control dampers. Therefore, these area DP dampers were in an almost closed position resulting in a high initial DP condition between the RWCU room and refuel floor. When the RWCU room doors were opened, DP dramatically dropped (-0.45" to 0.0") and all area DP dampers repositioned (including exhaust air dampers from the refueling floor). This significantly changed the pressure on the refueling floor and therefore the Building DP as measured from the atmosphere to the refuel floor. IR 1421995 identified two air leaks in the U2 Reactor Building Ventilation Control Panel 2252-24x: one at P/E transducer P/E 2-5741-191 and the other at a rubber tube connection on the inlet of DPC 2-5703-3. Both of these instruments are associated with the Unit 2 Reactor Building Ventilation Area DP control. The goal of the Area DP control is to maintain the most contaminated rooms inside the reactor building at a more negative pressure than general areas. This allows the air to flow from areas of lesser contamination to areas of greater contamination, thus controlling the spread of contamination in the reactor building. 

Extent of Condition: Any additional leaks within the Reactor Building Area DP control system will be identified as troubleshooting continues under WO 1578805. Any additional failure information will be evaluated under the associated Failure Classification Form because this issue was identified as a Maintenance Rule Functional Failure under function Z7504-03 (see AT 1418466-02 for more information). 

Evaluation of any SOC Comments: SOC/MRC asked the question of why the RB DP was lost when the U2 RWCU Room door was opened and the room was entered. This explanation can be found in the Statement of Cause section of this evaluation. 

Actions Completed/Created:

AT 1412296-02 due 10/29/12 to create a PHC presentation for actions to deal with the Reactor Building DP control issues. 

AT 1418466-02 due 11/2/12 to perform a failure classification form (FCF) for the MRFF on the RB Ventilation MR function for loss of Bldg DP. 

WO 1578805 was generated out of IR 1418466 to troubleshoot the Unit 2 RB Area DP control. This WO was originally scheduled for May 2013. Following the initiation of IR 1421955 this WO was added to the POD as part of the RB DP control item.

The only air leak that can be repaired under WO 1578805 is the rubber tubing connection for DPC 2-5703-3. The other air leak inside P/E 2-5741-191 can't be repaired. The only way to fix the leak is to replace the P/E transducer. This P/E transducer can't be replaced because it is obsolete and a replacement P/E transducer can't be procured. This air leak will need to be repaired by completing a TMOD to cut and cap the air lines to P/E transducer 2-5741-191. This TMOD will cause the loss of Unit 2 Area DP indication in the Main Control Room. A permanent modification will need to follow the TMOD to either eliminate the MCR indication or replace the old obsolete area DP control instruments with electronic or digital controls. At 22:22 CDT on Sunday, September 30, 2012 an ENS notification was made IAW SAF 1.9 due to information released to the media. The event was assigned EN# 48361. The following information was included in the ENS notification: 
At 18:04 CDT on Sunday, September 30, 2012, Security personnel reported a fire in the Mechanical Maintenance Shop. Fire Brigade responded and due to the severity of the fire, Coal City Fire Department was called for assistance. The fire was successfully extinguished at 18:34 CDT. There were no personnel injured in the fire. The fire did not affect any structures, systems, or components that are required to provide for nuclear safety. At no time was the health and safety of the public adversely affected by this condition. The maintenance shop is not attached to safety related structure of the operating units; therefore Dresden Station Unit 2 and Unit 3 were not affected by the fire. At approximately 19:30 CDT information was released to the media due to fire in the mechanical maintenance shop requiring Coal City Fire Department assistance. No official Press Release was made.

The purpose of this IR is to provide preliminary results of an ultrasonic inspection being performed of the 'A' Waste Sample Tank ('A' WST) floor plates. During an ultrasonic inspection (WO 01385883-06) of the 'A' WST (2/3-2001-468A) floor plates, several pits were identified. The pitting corrosion originates from the underside of the tank and works its way through the tank floor plate. The tank inspection is ongoing and so far one, approximately 1/8" hole, has been discovered that penetrates the " plate. This hole was verified by placing a wire through the hole. The pitting is not isolated to one location on the tank floor and it is unknown how many additional areas will need to be repaired.

At 1509 EDT Dresden station completed notification to the NRC Reactor Plant Event Notification Worksheet. The notification was assigned event number 48426. The 4 hour ENS notification was due to state notifications being required per RAD 3.4 for the hole discovered in the 'A' Waste sample tank during inspection. The notification read as follows: "OFFSITE NOTIFICATION MADE DUE TO POTENTIAL INADVERTENT RELEASE OF TRITIUM The notification is being made due to the fact that Exelon Nuclear has informed the Illinois Emergency Management Agency (IEMA) and the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency (IEPA) of the discovery of a hole in the A Waste Sample Tank resulting in a potential inadvertent release of tritium at Dresden Station. Any release is currently contained within the plant's restricted area. The notifications to IEMA and IEPA were made at 1340 hours CDT on October 20, 2012. The tank was out of service and had been emptied for internal inspection. Therefore at the time of discovery, there was no active leak. The IEPA/ IEMA regulations require notification when newly occurring, event-related unpermitted releases of radionuclides are identified. A release has not been confirmed but is suspected. A review of the historical groundwater monitoring well data trends and trending analysis from wells in proximity to the tank indicates no impact on groundwater. Further investigation of the groundwater in the area of the tank is ongoing to determine if an actual release has occurred. The potential leak was not released to an unrestricted area; therefore there is no anticipated adverse impact to the health and safety of the public. Since there was no release to an unrestricted area, limits were not impacted. The licensee has notified the NRC Resident Inspector."

During the planned full length Bobbin Coil Eddy Current (EC) inspection in the 2C Steam Generator (SG) during A2R16, a Distorted Support Indication (DSI) was identified at the Hot Leg (HL) 3rd and 5th quatrefoil broached hole support plate and a Distorted Freespan Indication (DFI) in the freespan between the 3rd and 5th HL support plate in tube Row 44 Column 47. Subsequent Plus Point inspection of the DSI's at the Hot Leg 3rd and 5th quatrefoil broached hole support plates confirmed the presence of Axial Outside Diameter Stress Corrosion Cracking (ODSCC) within a single quatrefoil land contact point at each of the supports. Additionally, Plus Point inspection of the DFI in the freespan between the 3rd and 5th HL support plate confirmed the presence of Axial ODSCC. The Plus Point EC voltage is being sized using the applicable EPRI Appendix I Examination Technique Specification Sheets (ETSS) and will be evaluated in accordance with the EPRI In-situ Pressure Testing Guidelines to determine if In-situ pressure testing is required. Since Bobbin Coil EC is the detection method for these types of degradation mechanisms and 100% full-length bobbin EC is planned for all in-service tubes in all four SGs during A2R16, all other in service tubing will be inspected as required by the EPRI PWR Steam Generator Examination Guideline requirements.

During a review investigating the impact of the proposed EPU power uprate upon pool hydrodynamic loads it was discovered that Design Analysis 3C7-0781-001 "Investigation of Containment Response to Subcooled Inventory Blowdown Effect" (a 1983 vintage calculation) did not properly address the effect of subcooling. This issue is applicable to LaSalle Units 1 and 2. Historical Background Following the DBA LOCA (double guillotine break of a reactor recirculation suction line), the drywell becomes pressurized. This causes non-condensable gas & steam to flow into the suppression pool through 98 downcomer vent lines. This in turn results in a phenomenon where a portion of water in the suppression pool swells up and imposes drag and impact loads on items located in the pool swell zone. The phenomenon is referred to as pool swell. The drag and impact loads associated with the pool swell phenomenon were determined in Design Analysis 3C7-1075-001 (first issued in 1975). This Design Analysis will be referred to as calc "1075". These loads were used as input to subsequent analyses that demonstrated the adequacy of affected piping and structural items for the pool swell loads. After completion of calc "1075" it was learned that input upon which calc "1075" was based was not conservative. The input was from analysis of the DBA-LOCA event that used saturated water, instead of subcooled water. Subsequent investigations found the use of subcooled break effluent results in a higher mass release rate which affects the drywell pressure response and the pool swell loads. Calc "0781" was generated to address sub-cooling and to demonstrate that the pool swell loads determined in calc "1075" remain bounding. As explained in the summary of calc "0781": "The LaSalle design basis pool swell loads were calculated for the recirculation pump suction line break mass/energy release rates which did not include the "subcooled inventory effect". When the "subcooled inventory effect" is included the pool swell loads increase. In order to avoid costly design reassessment and possible design modifications, the mass/energy release rate, customarily provided by GE which calculates it with their own conservative assumptions, was recalculated with a less conservative model..The RELAP4/MOD5 generated mass/energy release rates were used to . determine the pool swell water velocity vs pool swell height. The pool swell water velocity profile was then compared to the design water slug velocity profile. The comparison confirmed that the design water slug velocity profile bounds the new calculated water slug velocity profile." Non-Conforming Condition Investigations performed for EPU determined that that calc "0781" did not appropriately address subcooling. Specifically: calc "0781" used saturated water in the annulus area of the RPV (the area between the core shroud and the RPV wall, the area where the jet pumps are located). Since the DBA-LOCA is a double guillotine break of a reactor recirculation suction line and the reactor recirculation suction lines draw from the annulus area, the water in the annulus area of the RPV should be subcooled, not saturated. The recent discovery that calc "0781" did not appropriately address subcooling brings into question whether the loads determined in calc "1075" remain bounding. Should the loads determined in calc "1075" not be bounding, then items subject to pool swell loads may be subjected to higher loads than currently considered in design analyses. Basis for Reasonable Assurance of Continued Operability Based upon the following and the use of engineering judgment the following review concludes that the piping and structural items located in the suppression chamber that are affected by the pool swell phenomena will remain adequate. The design configuration avoids horizontal pipe runs in the pool swell zone whenever possible. (Ref: S&L Report SL-3876, Sections 3.1.3, 3.9.1.3, and 3.9.4). Affected Wetwell piping, their associated support system, and other items were modified during original plant construction (from their initial design) to increase their load capacity to sustain pool swell loads and/or minimize pool swell loads (Ref: S&L Report SL-3876, Section 3.6.4). To obtain an initial assessment of the possible impact of this discovery, an evaluation was performed by General Electric Hitachi (GEH) to determine the pool swell velocity versus pool height using a best-estimate model that addressed subcooling. The drag and impact loads associated with the pool swell phenomena are dependent upon the velocity of the pool swell. A comparison of pool swell velocity profile determined in the GEH evaluation and that used in calc "0781" the analysis of record (AOR), shows that the velocity profile in the AOR envelopes the velocity profile in the GEH evaluation except for swell heights less than approx 7 ft. In addition, where the GEH velocities exceed the velocities determined in the AOR; the amount is not significant. This GEH evaluation was performed for operability and did not consider several of the inputs/assumptions/methodology required for a design analysis. For example, the GEH evaluation did not consider reduced feedwater temperature ("Final Feedwater Temperature Reduction"). The GEH evaluation does not credit the lower downcomer bracing that is located just below the pool surface. As an initial check of existing margins, a study performed for the Mark II Pool Swell Subcommittee had previously assessed the effect of such bracing upon the dynamics of the pool swell phenomena. The study shows that bracing at or near the pool surface provides resistance that reduces the swell velocity by 15% to 17%. If the GEH review is extended to include evaluation of the effects of the installed LaSalle bracing; the velocity profile would be reduced and the velocity profile indicates that the AOR would be expected to envelope the reduced GEH velocity profile. Therefore, the pool swell loads considered in the AOR have been initially reviewed and seen to envelope those associated with the adjusted (reduced) GEH velocity profile. In addition: A preliminary assessment of representative items affected by the pool swell phenomena shows that they have margin to accommodate higher pool swell velocities. Current guidance for potential load increases in piping and supports provide a basis for the conclusion that the existing conditions are acceptable as non-conforming conditions. In particular: As identified in OP-AA-108-115 "Operability Evaluations", Section 4.5.8 regarding non-conforming piping and supports, the allowables in Appendix F of the ASME B&PV Code, Section III should be used to for determining operability. These allowables are significantly higher than those currently used in the design analysis. OP-AA-108-115 identifies that the Appendix F allowables are to be used until the Current Licensing Basis (CLB) criteria can be satisfied.

Notified by site IT that ERDS communication failed at 02:07 on 11/06/12. This issue is company wide, indicating a potential problem with communications at the NRC's end. Performance of WO 1591565-01 resulted in RB d/p going positive. This WO is a troubleshooter associated with the 1A Rx Building Exhaust Fan Isolation Damper. Technician's identified a damper on the 1A Rx Building exhaust fan. Disconnected the line to the positioner actuator and capped the line. Technician then followed the air line back to the 2251-24X panel and found a convenient breaking point at 1-5799-605 isolation valve and connected a pressure source for the static leak check. Upon pressurizing this line RB D/P went positive and the 2C RB exhaust fan tripped. Operators took action to restore RB D/P by securing U2 RB ventilation. U1 RB ventilation was already secured for this evolution. Troubleshooting was stopped when system did not respond as discussed. Lessons learned: -WO steps are vague. Specifically, the step in the WO that was being performed was "Perform static leak check of tubing". Other steps in this package are also vague and could be performed many ways. -Labeling of the U1 RB exhaust isolation dampers and associated damper controls is insufficient. -Labeling of the U1 RB exhaust control dampers and associated damper controls is insufficient. -Original plan, from the day before, had all RB ventilation secured. Discussions with on shift operations resulted in that to have all of U1 RB ventilation secured. However, U2 RB ventilation remained online. Discussion of a common sensing line occurred, but did not specify the effect on U2. Nothing directed this via WO steps, which is captured in the first lesson learned. Equipment was returned to normal configuration and work stopped.

While starting U1 Reactor Building Supply/Exhaust Fans, Reactor Building DP went positive due to the slow response of the control system. Reactor Building pressure went to above 0 and received alarm 912-5 C1 (U1) and C4 (U2) for approx. 19 seconds. Entered QGA 300. No emergency existed, Exited QGA 300. Entered and exited TS 3.6.4.1 for RB D/P. Also, 1/2A SBGT was in operation per QCOS 7500-05 during the evolution.
Location: HPCI tunnel, airlock door closest to the U-1 HPCI, inactive side has a defective lower seal. The rubber is out of the "U" channel.

On April 24, AT&T notified the Dresden phone tech about alarms they were seeing and asked to come onsite to troubleshoot/repair the issue. Once on site, the AT&T tech found the problem to be a bad cable pairs feeding to the SLC96 shelves. Upon further troubleshooting, the cable pair failure was traced to a 50-60' section of cable located just east of the PAF, from an overhead splice down to a point where that cable is spliced again into the underground cable coming into the Admin building. The overhead splice has taken on water and the pairs inside are brittle, and broke each time the AT&T technician attempted to re-splice the pairs. This splice point was temporarily wrapped in plastic until replacement of cable could happen. This wrap was only intended to last a day. If the cable fails there is a potential loss of communication from all the landline telephone system that leaves or enters the station including 911. NRC ENS System Remote Control System for Lift Station Supervisory, Illinois State Link Notification Dialogics System (if initiated from landline phone) NARS System IF GENERAL EMERGENCY CODE USED (Grundy County Sheriff and Grundy County EOC will not receive the notification call THIS AFFECTS BRAIDWOOD NGS AND LASALLE NGS) EAL MU-6 was reviewed by EP and deemed to be not applicable due to the fact that satellite phone and cellular phone capabilities will be maintained. EP will be implementing compensatory measures when the work is being performed by AT&T to fix the issue in order to ensure adequate communication capability with offsite agencies **Onsite and communication between sites will not be affected. **

1A RPS tripped, in conjunction with a fire alarm on Unit 1. Entered LOA-RP-101. Initial investigation in the field is that the motor supply breaker at 135X-2 tripped, and the EPMA's tripped, and the generator output breaker tripped. OAD responded and reported that the motor has an acrid smell.

While performing LIS-HP-205 per W.O. 01630361-01. 2E22-N012A pressure switch was found out of LCO/tech spec. limit per LIS-HP-205. ***This is a Tech Spec. issue*** The as found trip was 114.0 PSIG with a trip tolerance of 119.7 to 127.7 PSIG and the tech spec/LCO limit is (greater than or equal to 114.6) PSIG. The switch was returned to within specifications per the LIS and repeatability was confirmed.

LaSalle has received the NRC Special Inspection Team (SIT) report for the inspection activities conducted the week of April 22, 2013 related to the 4/17/13 Dual Unit LOOP and associated automatic scrams on Unit 1 and Unit 2. The inspectors identified a finding of very low safety significance with an associated Severity Level IV non-cited violation of the NRC's reporting requirements. The licensee failed to make a required 8-hour non-emergency notification call to the NRC Operations Center after discovery of a condition that could have prevented fulfillment of the safety function of the low pressure core spray (LPCS) system. The licensee entered this issue into its corrective action program (CAP) for evaluation and made an appropriate notification call to the NRC Operations Center. This finding was of more than minor significance because the NRC relies on licensees to identify and report conditions or events meeting the criteria specified in the Technical Specifications and the regulations in order to perform its regulatory function. Because this issue affected the NRC's ability to perform its regulatory function, the inspectors evaluated it using the traditional enforcement process and assessed the significance of the underlying issue using the Significance Determination Process (SDP). The underlying technical issue (i.e., an inoperable LPCS system) was determined to be of very low safety significance using the SDP. Consistent with the guidance in Section 6.9, Paragraph d.9, of the NRC Enforcement Policy, the violation associated with this finding was determined to be a Severity Level IV Violation. This finding affected the cross-cutting area of problem identification and resolution. Specifically, the licensee did not implement and institutionalize operating experience from a similar event reported at another licensee's facility while evaluating the reportability of the inoperable single train safety system. The inspectors reviewed the preliminary assessment and the design basis of the switchyard as described in the UFSAR. The inspectors noted that Section 8.2.3.2, "Adequacy of Offsite Power," of the UFSAR stated, in part, that: "The switchyard arrangement is such that offsite power to both units cannot be lost due to any single failure." Additionally, UFSAR Section 8.1.2.5, "Unit Non-Class 1E DC System," stated, in part, that: "The design of the protective relay circuits for the 345-kV oil circuit breakers and the 345-kV transmission lines is such that the loss of either battery or the loss of both batteries and associated feeder cables will not cause the loss of offsite power sources." Whether the series of events in the LaSalle switchyards that led to the dual-unit LOOP stemmed from a single failure or more than one failure, and whether the design of the switchyards meets regulatory requirements remain open questions. The issue will be treated as an Unresolved Item (URI 05000373/2013009-01; 05000374/2013009-01, Review of the Loss of Offsite Power Event Root Cause Evaluation and Switchyard Design Basis) pending completion of the licensee's root cause evaluation and resolution of open questions on the switchyard design basis.

An inservice Liquid Penetration examination was performed on the previously repaired Penetration 69 (repaired in A1R16). The examination was performed in accordance with ER-AA-335-002 and the acceptance criteria was in accordance with ER-AA-335-1008 and ASME Section III Class 1 - NB criteria. All indications exceeding 1/16" are recordable. Linear indications that exceed 1/16" are rejectable and rounded indications that exceed 3/16" are rejectable. The PT examination revealed 22 recordable indications and 5 non-relevant indications. All 22 indications are rounded and 13 of these indications exceed the 3/16" criteria. The identify, size, and location of the rejectable indications is as follows: Indication 1 - 3/8" rounded located at approximately 0 degrees and the intersection of the head and tube. Indication 3 - 1/4" rounded located at approximately 15 degrees and the intersection of the head and tube. Indication 4 - 1/4" rounded located at approximately 45 degrees on the tube, 1" from the intersection of the head and tube. Indication 6 - 3/16" wide x 9/16" rounded located at approximately 80 degrees and the intersection of the head and tube. Indication 7 - 1/4" rounded located at approximately 90 degrees on the tube, 2.5" from the intersection of the head and tube. Indication 9 - 1/4" rounded located at approximately 125 degrees on the tube, 0.5" from the intersection of the head and tube. Indication 12 - 5/16" rounded located at approximately 170 degrees and the intersection of the head and tube. Indication 14 - 5/16" rounded located at approximately 180 degrees and the intersection of the head and tube. Indication 19 - 3/8" rounded located at approximately 220 degrees and the intersection of the head and tube. Indication 21 - 7/16" rounded located at approximately 260 degrees and the intersection of the head and tube. Indication 22 - 1/2" rounded located at approximately 280 degrees and the intersection of the head

IR 01562654 documents that Dresden Nuclear Station Unit 2 experienced a containment integrity violation when both the 2/3 EDG side and Reactor Building side doors were open at the same time. This occurred as an operator was entering the Reactor Building. This event was reportable under SAF 1. 8 which requires an 8 hr NRC notification as a condition that could have prevented the fulfillment of a safety function. Procedure 1303-11.20 RB Access Hatch Interlocks, checks both the personnel and emergency hatch interlock features every 6 months. An evaluation should be completed to ensure that we are not vulnerable to violating containment integrity during this testing.

The following question was raised by the Senior Resident NRC Inspector: "If already in LCO if something unexpected occurs that would have made entry into LCO would that be considered a new unplanned entry into the LCO?" The question is being raised following Fuel Bldg ventilation tripping off during opening the Fuel Bldg RR bay inner door, which was considered expected. ESoms log entry 9/25/13 @ 1636: A review of the data from VF fans tripping indicate that the VF system operated as designed. After a review of LS-AA-1110 for SAF 1.8 and NUREG 1022 rev. 3 (LS-AA-1400), and consultation with Regulatory Assurance, it was determined that this condition is not reportable as described in LS-AA-1110: Removal of a system or part of a system from service as part of a planned evolution for routine (or emergent) maintenance or surveillance testing when done in accordance with an approved procedure and/or the plant's TS is not a reportable condition. All required conditions were met for this evolution. If it was considered unexpected, reportability would be the issue. Also, senior resident NRC inspector would like to be notified when entering EOP or unplanned LCO of 24 hours or less. SM has a memorandum which addresses the 24 hour LCO, but not the EOP entry. This would require NRC senior inspector to update the memorandum.

This IR does NOT document a new adverse condition with the TSC ventilation system. This IR is to document an ENS call made to the NRC. ENS 49723 was made at 18:33 EST on 1/14/2014. This issue was previously documented in IR 1572994 written on 10/16/2013. The ENS call made to the NRC contained the following information: On 10/16/2013 at 14:20 CDT, the Technical Support Center (TSC) Emergency Makeup Filter Flow Control Damper (0VV145Y) was discovered degraded and non-functional during planned maintenance activities. The degraded damper adversely impacted the TSC ventilation system function. On 10/16/2013 at approximately 15:00 CDT, administrative actions were developed and briefed to isolate instrument air to the degraded nonfunctional damper 0VV145Y providing the capability to restore TSC Emergency Makeup Filter functionality. Isolating instrument air to the degraded damper places the damper in the failed open position, thereby restoring TSC Emergency Makeup Filter functionality. On 10/16/2013 at 20:25 CDT, instrument air was isolated to the degraded damper 0VV145Y under administrative controls restoring TSC Emergency Makeup Filter functionality. This action was taken after determining no adverse effects on system operation. On 10/30/2013, degraded damper 0VV145Y was repaired, instrument air restored and post-maintenance testing completed, thereby restoring the degraded TSC emergency Makeup Filter Unit flow control damper functionality. This event is reportable for a major loss of emergency assessment capability because the emergent degraded TSC flow control damper 0VV145Y adversely impacted the function of TSC Emergency Makeup Filter and was not restored within the TSC activation time (60 minutes). This event was originally determined not reportable because the capability to restore within the TSC activation time (60 minutes) existed from the time of discovery. Upon further review, it was determined to be reportable because the degraded damper 0VV145Y was not restored to service within the TSC activation time (60 minutes).
MCR received alarm 003, D-3 "MAIN STACK RAD MONITOR TROUBLE/BYPASS". The "OPER" lights are out on RI-0-17-050B. Operations to perform AO 63E.1-2 in accordance with ARC.

IR# 1635618, CDBI: INADEQUATE PROCEDURAL GUIDANCE OF A DESIGN ASSUMPTION, was created on 3/19/2014 to document a condition where design assumptions in a calculation did not align with procedural direction / guidance. This issue identified that the Engineering calculation PM-620 utilizes an RHR flow rate of 9050 gpm (assuming one RHR pump in service) to the vessel in determining maximum opening differential pressure across the MO-2(3)-10-039A(B) valves. The calculation assumes that opening the MO-39A(B) valve (to place torus cooling in service) occurs with the pump off or with at least 9050 gpm being pumped to reduce pressure seen by the MOV. The scenario of interest is the small break LOCA without reaching -160" RWL. The timeline is as follows: -Small break LOCA resulting in 2# in the drywell. -HPCI maintains level above -160". -OPS places torus cooling in service. -Rx continues to depressurize to 450 #. -RHR pumps start and system re-aligns for LPCI upon reaching 450# (2# drywell already received). -5 minute timer for MO-2(3)-10-154A(B) times out. -Rx pressure is below 450# but still above RHR shut off head. -OPS attempts to place torus cooling in service iaw AO 10.8-2(3) Section 4.1. Not all Operations procedures address ensuring that an RHR pump is secured prior to opening MO-39A(B). Since RHR pumps could be running without injection and MO-2(3)-10-039A(B) is not designed to open against this dp (per calculation), it does not open when the switch is taken to open. When the Operations SRO performed a review of IR# 1635618, the SRO did not identify any non-conforming condition while considering current operability of the U2 and U3 MO-39A(B) for current plant conditions and did not determine that any of the 4 MO-39s were inoperable. It was reviewed only from the viewpoint that this was a procedural issue in relationship to the calculation and not reflective of a component inoperability. The potential for an impact post accident was not taken into account. This operability review was independently reviewed by a second SRO. Operations also entered into the IR review that Operations personnel are trained during simulator training that the MO-39 valves are not to be operated while an RHR pump is in service due to the DP concerns. In addition, actions to revise the procedures identified as deficient were not immediately revised or TCd. This was completed on 3/20/2014. The NRC's concern is that when OPS is directed to open MO-2(3)-10-039A(B) to place torus cooling in service IAW AO 10.8-2(3) (or other procedures that direct opening MO-2(3)-10-039A(B)) the valve would not open since it is not designed to open against pump shutoff (or min flow) head. NRC contention is since the valve may not open on demand it should be considered inoperable. (The valve must be capable of opening under all accidents it is credited for). This condition, if proved that the valves would not meet the requirements to open under all credited accidents, would be reportable as an event or condition that could have prevented fulfillment of a Safety Function, due to both subsystems of Torus Cooling, Torus Sprays and Drywell Sprays being affected for both U2 and U3. Based on actions taken by Operations to address the concern with MO-2(3)-10-039A(B), this condition has been addressed with respect to current operability. A past operability evaluation (OPDC) is being performed to document that the valve would have indeed been capable of opening under these conditions (for past 3 years only). Reference IR# 1635618-04.

Further analysis of OPEX ENS 49875 may be warranted for the following issue: "A review of industry operating experience regarding the impact of unfused Direct Current (DC) ammeter circuits in the control room has determined that a similar condition is applicable to the Waterford 3 Nuclear Station resulting in a potentially unanalyzed condition with respect to requirements. The original plant wiring design and associated analysis for an ammeter measuring current from the train AB Class 1E battery to its associated power distribution panel does not include overcurrent protection features to limit the fault current and is routed through multiple fire areas. The ammeter is located on the train AB power distribution panel in the train AB switchgear room. "In the postulated event, a fire could cause one of the ammeter wires to short to ground. Simultaneously, it is postulated that the fire could cause another DC wire from the opposite polarity on the same battery to also short to ground. This could cause a ground loop through the unprotected ammeter wiring. This event could result in excessive current flow (i.e., heating) in the ammeter wiring to the point of causing a secondary fire in the raceway system. The secondary fire could adversely affect safe shutdown equipment and potentially cause the loss of the ability to conduct a safe shutdown as required by requirements. "There is no effect on plant operation. Fire watches have been implemented for affected areas of the plant as an interim compensatory measure." According to review of drawings it appears ammeters for the DC system come directly off a shunt with no protection at TMI. There could be a concern.

Braidwood 2014-07-01 7:15 AM #312098 Plant Event Notification on Emergency Planning Sirens Status: OE - No Equipment Involved - Study Final Complete Last Updated: 2014-07-03 1:51 PM Significance: None Selected

Abstract:
At approximately 0715 (CDT) on 7/1/2014, during the daily morning test, Braidwood Generating Station experienced Offsite Alert and Notification System (ANS) failure of sirens BD10 and BD13 due to a loss of power to the sirens. Loss of power to the sirens was due to the adverse weather conditions experienced on the evening of 6/30/2014. Siren BD10 provides coverage for 20% of Braidwood's Emergency Planning Zone (EPZ) population and siren BD13 provides coverage for 14.1% of the Braidwood EPZ population. The cause of the event was a power outage due to adverse weather conditions. There were no consequences to the operating units.

Recommended for Review By:
Emergency Preparedness Staff
Licensing Staff
Operations Staff

Lessons Learned Summary:
Weather or Environmental Condition - Weather Tested and Restored to Service Actions to Prevent Recurrence not Needed

Event Summary:
The failure of the sirens resulted in the loss of the capability to alert a large segment of the population in the EPZ (34%) for more than 1 hour. Per NEI 13-01, Rev 0, a large segment of the population in the EPZ should be taken to mean approximately 25% of the total EPZ population. Immediate actions taken included placing a portable generator online to restore siren BD10 at 1015 CDT on 7/1/2014. ComEd is currently in the area attempting to restore normal power. Proposed long term corrective actions including an upgrade to the sirens to contain a battery backup are being evaluated. The licensee has notified the NRC Resident Inspector. The county emergency managers (for Will County - for siren BD10 and Grundy County - for siren BD13) are aware of the siren outage and the requirements to initiate mobile route alerting (FEMA approved backup) if required.

Cause Summary:
The cause of the loss of power to the sirens was adverse weather conditions.

Corrective Action Summary:
Temporary power was provided to siren BD10 at 10:15 on 7/1/14. The power was restored to siren BD10 on 7/1/14 at 1120. The power was restored to siren BD13 on 7/2/14 at 1145.

On 07/19/2014 at 20:10, a live Kemp's Ridley sea turtle was retrieved from Bay 5 of the Dilution Plant Structure. It was first observed at 20:00 while performing turtle tour. Intake temperature was 79.0 degrees F (26.3 degrees C) during an outgoing tide. The turtle was retrieved via the turtle rescue net. The Dilution Grates were previously raked at 15:17 on 07/19/2014. The previous turtle tour of the Dilution Plant Structure was performed at 16:45 on 07/19/2014. The turtle had significant injuries to its head/mouth and shell. The injuries are consistent with a boat propeller. However, the turtle seemed energetic. ENS Notification to the NRC Operations center completed for 4 hr non-emergency notification. Notification made to D. Norwood. NMFS Endangered Species Coordinator was notified via voice message and turtle was picked up at 21:40 07/19/2014. Notified Jack Bills from Environmental and Erica Libra from Chemistry. Executed procedure 106.12, Sea Turtle Surveillance, Handling, and Reporting Instructions.

On 7/28/14 while performing 636.4.013 EDG-2 LOAD TEST, just before performing step 6.23.3 (POSITION the EDG 2 NORMAL START switch to STOP position and return to NORM position), alarm T-6-f "EDG 2 ENGINE TEMP HI" was received at 05:09:07. Immediately after T-6-f was received, step 6.23.3 was performed and EDG 2 NORMAL START switch was taken to STOP. Automatic shutdown of EDG #2 was initiated as designed by performing step 6.23.3. Alarm T-4-f "EDG 2 DISABLED" was received at 05:10:07. In accordance with RAP T-6-f, "If in peaking mode, 60 seconds later, disable alarm annunciates and automatic shutdown is initiated". Operator was currently in the field and reported that cooling fan belt fell off pulley. Louvers were open. During operation and after one hour run at full load, step 6.22.6 indication TI-861-1188 (Lube Oil Cooler Oil Outlet Temperature) read 188 degrees F. After the fan belt fell off, TI-861-1188 indicated 218 degrees F. Acceptable band is 120-200 degrees F. During operation and after one hour run at full load, step 6.22.7 indication TI-861-26 (Lube Oil Cooler Oil Inlet Temperature) read 218 degrees F. After the fan belt fell off, TI-861-26 indicated 225 degrees F. Acceptable band is 100-220 degrees F.

River Bend ENS 50337 Power Reactor Event Number: 50337 Facility: RIVER BEND Region: 4 State: LA Unit: 1] ] ] RX Type: 1] GE-6 NRC Notified By: DANIEL PIPKIN HQ OPS Officer: DANIEL MILLS Notification Date: 08/02/2014 Notification Time: 03:39 ET] Event Date: 08/01/2014 Event Time: 21:42 CDT] Last Update Date: 08/02/2014 Emergency Class: NON EMERGENCY Person (Organization): NEIL OKEEFE (R4DO) Unit SCRAM Code RX CRIT Initial PWR Initial RX Mode Current PWR Current RX Mode 1 N Y 100 Power Operation 100 Power Operation 50337 - HIGH PRESSURE CORE SPRAY DECLARED INOPERABLE DUE TO TEST RETURN VALVE LEAKAGE "River Bend Station personnel declared the High Pressure Core Spray system inoperable at 2142 CDT] on 8/1/2014. "The High Pressure Core Spray (HPCS) system at River Bend Station includes a test return line to the Condensate Storage Tank (CST). The test return line is isolated by two motor operated valves (MOVs) with both having a safety function to close on an ECCS Emergency Core Cooling System] initiation signal to ensure that injection flow is directed to the reactor vessel. While the HPCS pump is normally aligned to the CST, the credited source of water for the pump is the suppression pool. Accordingly, the pump suction is realigned to the suppression pool on low level in the CST or when suppression pool level rises to a certain point. Station personnel identified leakage past the test return valves to the CST. In evaluating this condition, engineering personnel noted that the observed leakage past the two MOVs might be sufficient to deplete suppression pool inventory such that it would not be capable of performing its specified function for the duration of the 30 day mission time. The issue of concern is that once HPCS is aligned to the suppression pool post-LOCA, pool inventory would be lost to the CST through the leaking test return valves. "Based on that concern, the HPCS pump suction valve from the suppression pool was disabled in the closed position to preserve pool inventory. This action caused the HPCS system to be declared inoperable at 2142 CDT]. This action results in a 14 day shutdown LCO and is reportable to the NRC. "The HPCS pump remains available with its suction aligned to the CST. Assuming normal makeup water supplies are available, the HPCS system can be realigned to the suppression pool if necessary. "This condition continues to be evaluated and rework options are being developed. "The NRC Senior Resident Inspector has been notified." PLANT OE CONTACT: MICHELLE FREEMAN (225) 381-4276

As documented in IR 1695675, a 10 dpm leak was observed on ESW piping on an elbow between HV-2-33-502 and CHK-2-33-513. A graduated cylinder was used to measure the leak rate and it determined to be 3 ml/minute. Engineering evaluated the location of the piping flaw and determined that Code Case N-513-3 was not applicable since the flaw existed on an elbow. As a result, both trains of Emergency Service Water (ESW) System were declared inoperable on Unit 2 and Unit 3 at 1300 hours on Saturday, August 23, 2014. An ENS call was made to the NRC at 2019 hours as an event or condition that could have prevented the fulfillment of the safety function of systems that are needed to shut down the reactor and maintain it in a safe shutdown condition, remove residual heat and mitigate the consequences of an accident. The above referenced IR will track the Operability Determination and Repairs. The purpose of this IR is to document the regulatory processes followed and to track the remaining regulatory actions. On August 23, 2014, a Notice of Enforcement Discretion was processed. This request was reviewed and approved by PORC at 1730 hours. A verbal request to NRC Region 1 was made and subsequently granted at 1922 hours. A followup written request is required to be submitted to the NRC by 8/26/14. This NOED granted an extension to the 12 hour shutdown Tech Spec 3.7.2 to allow the station to submit a Relief Request for approval to utilize ASME Code Case N-513-3 for this leak on the elbow. This relief request was submitted on 8/24/14 at 1157 hours. If NRC approval is not granted, the LCO 3.7.2 48 hour extension expires at 0100 on 8/26/14. If approval is granted, an operability determination utilizing the NRC approved ASME code case for this elbow is required.

Brief Description: UNANALYZED DC CIRCUIT FROM THE BATTERY AND BATTERY CHARGER AMMETER GOING TO THE CONTROL ROOM FOR A FIRE IN UNIT 1 CABLE SPREADING ROOM (CSR) WHICH COULD ALSO CAUSE A SECONDARY FIRE IN THE UNIT 2 CSR.

Detailed Description: AS A RESULT OF RECENT INDUSTRY OPERATING EXPERIENCE (OE 305419, EN 49411) AT PALO VERDE REGARDING THE IMPACT OF UNFUSED DIRECT CURRENT (DC) AMMETER CIRCUITS IN THE CONTROL ROOM AND AS DISCUSSED IN CR-2013-008020, CALVERT CLIFFS PERFORMED A REVIEW OF AMMETER CIRCUITRY. THE SPECIFIC FUSE ISSUE AT PALO VERDE WITH SHORTING ACROSS THE DC BUS DOES NOT OCCUR FOR CALVERT. HOWEVER, THERE IS AN UNANALYZED CONDITION IN WHICH THE UNFUSED LENGTH OF CABLE GOING FROM THE DC BUS TO THE CONTROL FROM U2 CABLE SPREADING ROOM GOES THROUGH THE UNIT 1 CABLE SPREADING ROOM ON ITS WAY TO THE CONTROL ROOM. THE SAME EXISTS FOR THE CABLE FOR THE CHARGERS. THE REVERSE IS NOT TRUE FOR THE UNIT 1 CABLE SPREADING ROOM (EXTENT OF CONDITION REVIEWED AND NOT IMPACTED). THE COMPENSATORY ACTION WILL NEED TO BE HOURLY FIRE WATCH FOR THE U1 AND U2 CABLE SPREADING ROOM UNTIL A PERMANENT ACTION IS TAKEN TO CORRECT THE ISSUE. THE PERMANENT ACTION APPEARS TO BE A PLANT MODIFICATION TO ADD A FUSE TO THESE CABLES (6 CIRCUITS). WE HAVE ALREADY REACHED OUT TO OBTAIN ESTIMATES TO COMPLETE THIS ENGINEERING AND EVALUATING OTHER POTENTIAL SOLUTIONS. ADDITIONALLY, DAVIS BESSE, BROWNS FERRY, VC SUMMER, CALLOWAY, COMANCHE PEAK, AND PALO VERDE HAVE REPORTED AND ARE TAKING SIMILAR COMPENSATORY ACTIONS. THE WIRING DESIGN FOR THE AMMETERS CONTAINS A SHUNT IN THE CURRENT FLOW FROM EACH DC BATTERY OR CHARGER. THE AMMETER WIRING ATTACHED TO THE SHUNT DOES NOT CONTAIN FUSES. IT IS POSTULATED THAT A FIRE COULD CAUSE ONE OF THE AMMETER WIRES TO HOT SHORT TO GROUND. CONCURRENTLY, THE FIRE CAUSES ANOTHER DC WIRE FROM THE OPPOSITE POLARITY ON THE SAME BATTERY TO ALSO SHORT TO GROUND. THIS WOULD CAUSE A GROUND LOOP THROUGH THE UNFUSED AMMETER CABLE. THE POTENTIAL EXISTS THAT THE CABLE COULD HEAT-UP CAUSING A SECONDARY FIRE IN THE AMMETER RACEWAY. THE SECONDARY FIRE COULD ADVERSELY AFFECT SAFE SHUTDOWN EQUIPMENT IN THE UNIT 2 CABLE SPREADING ROOM AND POTENTIALLY CAUSE THE LOSS OF THE ABILITY TO SAFELY SHUTDOWN PER THE EXISTING ANALYSIS FOR THE UNIT 1 CABLE SPREADING ROOM FIRE.

Extent of Condition: Identified by Comments: Immediate actions Taken: Discussed this issue with Licensing and PRA. Licensing has the reportability form drafted. The PRA group is analyzing the routing of the six cables so they can do the delta CDF to show that it is less than red.

Brief Description: NMPNS HAS TWO NRC SL IV VIOLATIONS AND A POTENTIAL THIRD PERFORM COMMON ON THIS TREND Detailed Description: BRIEF: NRC HAS IDENTIFIED TWO LEVEL IV TRADITIONAL ENFORCEMENT VIOLATIONS IN THE LAST 12 MONTH PERIOD FOR NMPNS. IN THE LAST 12 MONTHS THE NRC HAS IDENTIFIED FOLLOWING LEVEL IV TRADITIONAL ENFORCEMENT VIOLATIONS: NRC REVIEW OF THE HPCI EVENT NOTIFICATION ON 11/2/2012 AND SUBSEQUENT RETRACTION HAS DETERMINED THAT THE HPCI INITIATION SHOULD BE CONSIDERED A VALID ACTUATION, AND THAT THE RETRACTION WAS INAPPROPRIATE RESULTING IN A VIOLATION FOR FAILURE TO SUBMIT THE ASSOCIATED LER. THIS ISSUE IS DOCUMENTED IN CR-2013-001859 AND CR-2013-004899. FOR FURTHER DETAILS SEE NRC INSPECTION REPORT 2013-002 (SEE ATTACHED) FAILURE OF THE PROCESS ASSOCIATED WITH CHANGE TO AN OPERATING PROCEDURE N1-OP-4 IN 2009 TO IDENTIFY THE NEED FOR AN EVALUATION. THIS ISSUE IS DOCUMENTED IN CR-2012-009540, CR-2013-003478 AND 4897. FOR FURTHER DETAILS SEE NRC INSPECTION REPORT 2013-002 (SEE ATTACHED) ON AUGUST 28, 2013, AFTER AN INSPECTION ASSOCIATED WITH THE HYDROGEN BURN DURING AN ISFSI CASK WELDING, THE INSPECTOR IDENTIFIED A POTENTIAL LEVEL IV VIOLATION FOR THE STATION'S FAILURE TO MONITOR HYDROGEN AS REQUIRED BY PROCEDURE AND THE ISFSI USAR. THE HYDROGEN MONITOR IN USE WAS NOT SET UP PROPERLY LEADING TO INACCURATE READINGS. THUS, HYDROGEN MONITORING DID NOT TAKE PLACE AS REQUIRED BY S-MMP-ISFSI-004 AND THE TRANS NUCLEAR USAR. THIS ISSUE IS DOCUMENTED IN CR-2013-006840. AN INSPECTION REPORT FOR THIS VIOLATION HAS NOT BEEN ISSUED AT THIS TIME NOR HAS A FINAL DETERMINATION. NOTE THAT THE NRC MAY CHOOSE TO PERFORM A SPECIAL INSPECTION USING IP 92723, "FOLLOW UP INSPECTION FOR THREE OR MORE SEVERITY LEVEL IV TRADITIONAL ENFORCEMENT VIOLATIONS IN THE SAME AREA IN A 12-MONTH PERIOD" AT A PLANT THAT HAS RECEIVED THREE OR MORE TRADITIONAL SL IV VIOLATIONS IN FOUR CALENDAR QUARTERS, AND WHERE THE NRC QUESTIONS WHETHER THE LICENSEE IS REACTING APPROPRIATELY. THE PURPOSE OF THE INSPECTION IS TO LOOK AT THE COMMON CAUSE ANALYSIS PERFORMED BY THE LICENSEE, THE EXTENT OF CONDITION AND CAUSE, AND CORRECTIVE ACTIONS. THIS DECISION TO PERFORM THIS INSPECTION WILL BE MADE BY THE NRC AT THE ANNUAL ASSESSMENT IN JANUARY 2014. A COPY OF THE IP 92723 IS ATTACHED FOR USE IN THE EVALUATION OF THIS CR. THIS CR IS BEING WRITTEN TO PERFORM A COMMON CAUSE ANALYSIS. Extent of Condition: Identified by Comments: Immediate actions Taken:

Brief Description: REVIEW OF INDUSTRY OE HAS IDENTIFIED NMP UNIT 1 CONFIGURATION SIMILAR TO THAT DESCRIBED IN OE 305419 Detailed Description: OE305419 (ATTACHED TO THIS CR), IDENTIFIES A POSTULATED FIRE INDUCED CIRCUIT FAILURE INVOLVING UN-FUSED DC AMMETER CIRCUITS LEADING TO A POTENTIAL NON-COMPLIANCE TO AN APPENDIX R REQUIREMENTS. A REVIEW OF DC AMMETER CIRCUITS FOR THE CLASS 1E BATTERIES HAS CONCLUDED THAT SIMILAR CONFIGURATION EXISTS AT NMP UNIT 1. IN ADDITION, A PRELIMINARY REVIEW OF THE BATTERY CHARGER CIRCUITS SHOWS THAT THEY HAVE A SIMILAR CONFIGURATION TO THE BATTERY AMMETERS AND MAY ALSO BE SUSCEPTIBLE TO THE ISSUE DESCRIBED. THE FOLLOWING EXCERPT FROM THE OE DESCRIBES THE POTENTIAL APPENDIX R IMPACT: "THE WIRING DESIGN FOR THE AMMETERS CONTAINS A SHUNT IN THE CURRENT FLOW FROM EACH DIRECT CURRENT (DC) BATTERY OR CHARGER. BOLTED ON THE SHUNT BAR ARE TWO IEEE 383 QUALIFIED LEADS TO A CURRENT METER IN THE MAIN CONTROL ROOM (MCR). THE SMALL DIFFERENCE IN VOLTAGE BETWEEN THE TWO TAPS ON THE SHUNT IS ENOUGH TO DEFLECT THE CURRENT GAUGE IN THE MCR WHEN CURRENT FLOWS FROM THE BATTERY OR CHARGER THROUGH THE SHUNT. THE AMMETER WIRING ATTACHED TO THE SHUNT (POSITIVE SIDE OF THE BATTERY) DOES NOT HAVE FUSES. IT IS POSTULATED THAT A FIRE COULD CAUSE ONE OF THESE AMMETER WIRES TO SHORT TO GROUND AT THE SAME TIME THE FIRE CAUSES ANOTHER DC WIRE FROM THE OPPOSITE POLARITY (NEGATIVE SIDE) ON THE SAME BATTERY ALSO SHORT TO GROUND. THIS WOULD CAUSE A GROUND LOOP THROUGH THE UN-FUSED AMMETER CABLE. WITH ENOUGH CURRENT GOING THROUGH THE CABLE, THE POTENTIAL EXISTS THAT THE CABLE COULD SELF HEAT TO THE POINT OF CAUSING A SECONDARY FIRE IN THE ELECTRICAL TRAY AT SOME POINT ALONG THE PATH OF THE CABLE (INCLUDING THE CONTROL ROOM) OR POSSIBLY HEAT UP TO THE POINT OF CAUSING DAMAGE TO ADJACENT CABLES THAT MAY BE REQUIRED FOR SAFE SHUTDOWN." FOR THE GROUND FAULT HOT SHORT PHENOMENON IDENTIFIED IN THIS OE TO CAUSE A SECONDARY FIRE, ONE OR MORE ENERGIZED CONDUCTORS FROM THE SAME POWER SOURCE AS THE CIRCUIT UNDER ANALYSIS (AMMETER CIRCUIT) MUST ALSO BE SUSCEPTIBLE TO FIRE DAMAGE. ASSUMING THAT THE ENERGIZED CONDUCTORS FROM THE SAME POWER SOURCE ARE LOCATED IN THE SAME RACEWAY AS THE AMMETER CABLES/CONDUCTORS, THE LIKELIHOOD OF A VIABLE CONDUCTION PATH THROUGH A GROUNDED SURFACE IS EXTREMELY REMOTE DUE TO THE FOLLOWING: A. REQUIRES GROUND FAULT HOT SHORTS ON TWO DIFFERENT CABLES FROM THE SAME BATTERY SOURCE WITHOUT MAKING INTRA-CABLE (INTERNAL CONDUCTOR CONTACT WITHIN THE SAME CABLE) ELECTRICAL CONTACT (I.E. NOT RESULTING IN A POSITIVE TO NEGATIVE SHORT THAT WOULD OPEN THE FUSE SUPPLYING THE FAULT CURRENT). B. IN ORDER FOR THIS TO OCCUR A BOLTED FAULT TO THE RACEWAY MUST BE PRESENT ON THE SOURCE AND TARGET CONDUCTORS SUCH THAT SUFFICIENT CURRENT PASSES THROUGH THE GROUND PLANE. C. SINCE THE CABLE TRAYS AT UNIT 1 ARE FULL IT IS UNLIKELY THAT A BOLTED FAULT BETWEEN THE TARGET (AMMETER CABLE) AND THE SOURCE CABLE WOULD OCCUR WITHOUT ANY OTHER ADJACENT CABLES WITHIN THE RACEWAY EXPERIENCING THE SAME FAULT. AT NMP1, IN FIRE AREAS WHERE THE CABLES ASSOCIATED WITH THE AMMETERS ARE ROUTED, THE FIRE AREAS ARE EQUIPPED WITH DETECTION AND AUTOMATIC SUPPRESSION. THE POSTULATED FIRE INDUCED CIRCUIT FAILURE AND THE RESULTANT FIRE SCENARIO IN THE OE IS NOT CONSIDERED A LIKELY SCENARIO. THE GROUND FAULT HOT SHORTS IN THE DC CIRCUITS ARE CONSIDERED A "PLAUSIBLE" CIRCUIT FAILURE BY THE PIRT GROUP (THE INDUSTRY WORKING GROUP WHO IS EVALUATING THE RESULTS FROM THE DESIREE FIRE TESTING). HOWEVER, THE CIRCUIT FAILURE TYPE IDENTIFIED IN THIS OE WAS NOT OBSERVED OR WITHIN THE SCOPE OF THE DESIREE FIRE TESTING AND IS NOT SPECIFICALLY ADDRESSED IN THE PIRT FINAL REPORT. THE AMMETERS DISCUSSED IN THIS CR ARE CONSIDERED SAFETY RELATED HOWEVER THEY DO NOT PERFORM ANY ACTIVE SAFETY RELATED FUNCTION AND THEREFORE ARE FOR INDICATION ONLY. THE AMMETERS ARE NOT CREDITED FOR SAFE SHUTDOWN OF THE PLANT. FOR NMP UNIT 1 DUE TO THE CONTROL ROOM BEING A CONTINUOUSLY MANNED AREA, A FIRE WOULD BE DETECTED IN THE INCIPIENT STAGE OF FIRE PROPAGATION. THE FIRE WOULD BE IMMEDIATELY DETECTED AND SUPPRESSED. THERE IS A LIMITED AREA OF CONCERN FOR THE CABLE RUNS OUTSIDE THE CONTROL ROOM; THESE CABLE TRAYS HAVE DEDICATED FIRE SUPPRESSION AND DETECTION. THEREFORE IF A FIRE WERE TO OCCUR, IT WOULD BE PROMPTLY DETECTED AND SUPPRESSED. CABLE TRAYS ARE ALSO COATED WITH FLAMASTIC IN THE AREA SURROUNDING THE SAFETY RELATED BATTERY BOARDS WHICH PREVENTS FIRE PROPAGATION IN THIS AREA. HOWEVER, THESE CABLES WERE NOT INCLUDED IN THE ORIGINAL APPENDIX R ANALYSIS AND REPRESENT AN UNANALYZED CONDITION. Extent of Condition: Identified by Comments: Immediate actions Taken: Notified Supervision, initiated condition report.

Brief Description: REACTOR SCRAM OCCURRED WHILE INSTALLING INSTRUMENT RACK WARNING TAGS PER WORK ORDER C92589161

Detailed Description: WHILE INSTALLING INSTRUMENT RACK WARNING LABELS ON INSTRUMENT RACK 2CES*RAK004 PER MINOR MAINTENANCE WORK ORDER C92589161 TO ADDRESS CAT. 1 CR-2012-003778 ENHANCEMENT ACTION, A FULL REACTOR SCRAM OCCURRED. UNIT 2 WAS AT APPROXIMATELY 97% POWER WHEN THE SCRAM OCCURRED. JUST PRIOR TO THE REACTOR SCRAM, AN EXISTING TAG WAS BEING REMOVED FROM 2CES*RAK004 COMMON DRAIN VALVE A4 BY I&C TECHNICIANS. WHILE CUTTING THE TAG OFF DRAIN VALVE A4, THE WIRE CUTTER TWISTED AND EITHER "RANG" THE A4 DRAIN LINE TRANSMITTERS OR SLIGHTLY CRACKED OPEN THE A4 T-HANDLE DRAIN VALVE CAUSING THE PERTUBATION. IT APPEARS THE DIVISION I REDUNDANT REACTIVITY CONTROL ARI INADVERTENTLY INITIATED FROM REACTOR WATER LOW-LOW LEVEL 2 TRANSMITTERS 2ISC*LT8A AND 2ISC*LT8B RESULTING IN A TRIP OF THE REACTOR RECIRCULATION PUMPS AND SUBSEQUENT REACTOR SCRAM. IN ADDITION RCIC INITIATED ON A REACTOR WATER LOW-LOW LEVEL 2 CONDITION FROM LEVEL TRANSMITTERS LOCATED ON 2CES*RAK004. THE INVESTIGATION AS TO ACTUAL REACTOR SCRAM SIGNALS, THEIR CAUSE, AND PLANT RESPONSE IS IN PROGRESS.

Extent of Condition: Identified by Comments: Immediate actions Taken: Shift Manager notified. OCC has been staffed. A human performance prompt investigation per CNG-HU-1.01-1000 has been initiated. Fitness For Duty and Fatigue Management assessments were performed for the individuals involved with this event in accordance with CNG-SE-1.01-1002.

Brief Description: REACTOR BUILDING ISOLATED DUE TO LOSS OF AUX BOILERS (REPORTABLE) Detailed Description: ON 03/24/14, DUE TO THE LOSS OF AUX BOILER STEAM HEAT (AUX BOILER B1B COULD NOT BE RUN DUE TO PRESSURE CONTROL ISSUES AND AUX BOILER A TRIPPED ON ELECTRICAL FAULT) THE REACTOR BUILDING HAD TO BE ISOLATED DUE TO LOWERING TEMPERATURES TO THE NORMAL INTAKE SUPPLY PLENUM. WHEN OPERATORS ISOLATED THE HVR SYSTEM, THE BUILDING WENT POSITIVE FROM 0031 TO 0034 CAUSING THE CONDITION TO BE REPORTABLE WITHIN 8 HOURS AS "ANY EVENT OR CONDITION THAT AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY COULD HAVE PREVENTED THE FULFILLMENT OF THE SAFETY FUNCTION OF STRUCTURES OR SYSTEMS THAT ARE NEEDED TO: (C) CONTROL THE RELEASE OF RADIOACTIVE MATERIAL" FOR THE INOPERABLE SECONDARY CONTAINMENT AND ALSO REPORTABLE WITHIN 8 HOURS FOR AN UNPLANNED ISOLATION OF VENT WRGMS WHICH IS "ANY EVENT THAT RESULTS IN A MAJOR LOSS OF EMERGENCY ASSESSMENT CAPABILITY." SECONDARY CONTAINMENT WAS INOPERABLE FOR THE SAME THREE MINUTE PERIOD OF TIME WHILE THE BUILDING WAS POSITIVE AND SINCE HAS BEEN DECLARED OPERABLE. THE VENT WRGMS REMAINS NON-FUNCTIONAL WHILE THE REACTOR BUILDING REMAINS ISOLATED. Extent of Condition: Identified by Comments: Immediate actions Taken:

Brief Description: POSTULATED FIRE EVENT COULD RESULT IN A HOT SHORT THAT COULD ADVERSELY IMPACT SAFE SHUTDOWN EQUIPMENT

Detailed Description: AFTER A REVIEW OF RECENT INDUSTRY FINDINGS AND THE RECOMMENDATION OF EXELON CORPORATE FIRE PROTECTION PERSONNEL, A SECOND EXTENT OF CONDITION REVIEW WAS DONE FOR THE ISSUE DESCRIBED IN CR-2013-008747, WITH THE REVIEW EXPANDED FROM JUST DC AMMETER CIRCUITS TO INCLUDE CIRCUITS FOR DC MOTORS (PUMP MOTORS AND MOV MOTORS). DC SYSTEM LOADS WERE REVIEWED FOR CASES WHERE CONTROL CIRCUITS WERE POWERED BY MOTIVE POWER CIRCUITS (I.E. CONTROL CIRCUIT PROTECTION WAS THROUGH A LARGE FUSE WHICH WOULD NOT BE EXPECTED TO PROVIDE ADEQUATE PROTECTION TO WIRING) OR WHERE FUSES HAD BEEN REPLACED WITH SOLID LINKS TO ENSURE RELIABILITY OF OIL PUMPS PROTECTING LARGE ASSETS SUCH AS THE TURBINE. THIS INCLUDED A REVIEW OF ALL NMP1 DC MOVS FOR THE CONFIGURATION DESCRIBED. THE REVIEW IDENTIFIED VALVE IV-33-04, CLEANUP SUPPLY ISOLATION VALVE 12, POWERED FROM DC VALVE BOARD 12 WITH LARGE MOTOR FUSES (50A), HAS NO CONTROL POWER FUSES. THE VALVE IS A DC POWERED REACTOR VESSEL ISOLATION VALVE. NO OTHER DC VALVES OR PUMP MOTORS WERE IDENTIFIED AS PROBLEMS DURING THIS REVIEW. THE DESCRIBED CONDITION DOES NOT REPRESENT A CHALLENGE TO ANY REQUIRED TECHNICAL SPECIFICATION FUNCTIONS (OPERABILITY). PER APPROVED FIRE PROTECTION ENGINEERING EVALUATION FPEE1-90-014: "ALL DC MOTOR-OPERATED REACTOR COOLANT SYSTEM ISOLATION VALVES (MOVS) WILL CLOSE AS DESIGNED UPON RECEIVING VESSEL ISOLATION SIGNAL ON LOW-LOW WATER LEVEL OR MANUAL INITIATION OF VESSEL ISOLATION." THIS CONDITION DOES NOT IMPACT THIS FUNCTION OF THE VALVE. THE CONDUCTORS IN THE CONTROL CIRCUIT OF IV-33-04 ARE 12 AWG, IEEE-383 RATED, XLPE TYPE CABLES ACCORDING TO PLANT DRAWINGS AND THE CABLE RACEWAY DATABASE (TRAK2000). THE FUSES WHICH PROTECT THE VALVES MOTIVE POWER CIRCUIT ARE 50A FUSES DESIGNED TO PROTECT THE #4/0 MOTOR POWER CIRCUITS. THEY WILL NOT ADEQUATELY PROTECT THE 12 AWG CONTROL CIRCUIT CABLING FROM FAULT CONDITIONS. THE CONCERN WITH THIS CONDITION IS THAT WHEN A FIRE OCCURS IN AN AREA OF THE PLANT, THE CONTROL CIRCUIT CONDUCTORS COULD SHORT TOGETHER WITH THE CORRECT AMOUNT OF RESISTANCE IN THE CONNECTION SUCH THAT THE CONDUCTORS ARE DAMAGED BY EXCESS CURRENT WHICH THE FUSE DOES NOT CLEAR AS IT HAS BEEN SIZED TOO LARGE. THIS COULD CAUSE SECONDARY FIRES ALONG THE CABLE ROUTE, WHICH DOES NOT MEET THE STATEMENTS IN UFSAR APPENDIX 10B SECTION 5.9.3, WHICH STATES THAT ALL CONDUCTORS HAVE PROPERLY SIZED PROTECTIVE DEVICES SUCH THAT ANY FAULT CONDITION IS INTERRUPTED BEFORE BREAKDOWN OF CABLE INSULATION RESULTS IN IGNITION OUTSIDE THE FIRE AREA OF CONCERN. CONDUCTORS THAT MAKE UP THE CONTROL CIRCUIT FOR IV-33-04 ARE CONTAINED WITHIN THREE (3) CABLES AS INDICATED BY PLANT DRAWINGS, THE CABLES ARE 12DV-26, 12DV-27 AND 12DV-28. A REVIEW OF THE CABLES ROUTING WAS PERFORMED TO DETERMINE IF AN UNCLEARED FAULT CONDITION REMAINING ON THE CABLE WOULD CAUSE SECONDARY FIRES IN AREAS BEYOND THE FIRE AREA OF CONCERN. CABLE 12DV-28 IS ONLY PRESENT IN ONE FIRE AREA AND SCREENED OUT. CABLES 12DV-26 AND 12DV-27 FROM DC VALVE BOARD 12 TO THE REACTOR BUILDING (FIRE AREA 1), THE CABLE SPREADING ROOM (FIRE AREA 10), AND THE AUXILIARY CONTROL ROOM (FIRE AREA 11). AS THESE CABLES ARE XLPE TYPE, IEEE-383 RATED CABLES, THE CONCLUSIONS OF FPEE2-14-001 STATE THAT THEY ARE NOT EXPECTED TO IGNITE AND CAUSE SECONDARY FIRES DUE TO OVERCURRENT CONDITIONS. HOWEVER, THEY MAY CAUSE DAMAGE TO CABLES ROUTED IN CLOSE PROXIMITY TO THEM, THEREFORE A REVIEW OF THE CONTENTS OF THE RACEWAYS WHERE THESE CABLES ARE ROUTED WAS PERFORMED TO DETERMINE IF ANY SAFE SHUTDOWN EQUIPMENT WOULD BE IMPACTED. BOTH CABLES 12DV-26 AND 12DV-27 WERE FOUND TO BE ROUTED IN CABLE TRAYS WITH OTHER SAFE SHUTDOWN CABLES, INCLUDING THOSE THAT SUPPORT THE CREDITED SAFE SHUTDOWN TRAIN. IF A FIRE WERE TO OCCUR IN FIRE AREA 1 (REACTOR BUILDING EAST), FIRE AREA 10 (CABLE SPREADING ROOM), OR FIRE AREA 11 (AUXILIARY CONTROL ROOM) WHERE THESE CABLES ARE ROUTED THEY MAY CAUSE DAMAGE TO OTHER SAFE SHUTDOWN CABLES OUTSIDE THE AREA WHERE THE FIRE WAS OCCURRING, ADVERSELY AFFECTING SAFE SHUTDOWN EQUIPMENT AND POTENTIALLY CAUSING THE LOSS OF THE ABILITY TO CONDUCT A SAFE SHUTDOWN. THIS REPRESENTS AN UNANALYZED CONDITION IN RESPECT TO THE STATION APPENDIX R ANALYSIS. Extent of Condition: Identified by Comments: Immediate actions Taken: Notified Supervision and Control Room.

Brief Description: ADJUSTMENTS TO ERO ON-SHIFT STAFFING BASED ON REV. 45 OF THE CCNPP ERP - ENSURE ADEQUATE OPS STAFFING TO FILL OTA ROLE. Detailed Description: REVISION 45 OF THE CCNPP EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN (ERP) WAS APPROVED FOR IMPLEMENTATION ON 12/13/12. THIS REVISION INCLUDES THE INCORPORATION OF THE CCNPP ON-SHIFT STAFFING ANALYSIS REPORT THAT WAS COMPLETED BY EP CONSULTING, LLC IAW NEI 10-05, REVISION 0, ASSESSMENT OF ON-SHIFT ERO STAFFING AND CAPABILITIES. THE RESULTS OF THE STAFFING ANALYSIS INDICATED THAT THERE WAS A SHORTAGE OF LICENSED OPERATORS TO RESPOND TO A CONTROL ROOM FIRE REQUIRING EVACUATION (E.G., AOP-9A SCENARIO - BOTH UNITS IMPACTED). THE IDENTIFIED SHORTAGE WAS IN FILLING THE ROLE OF THE OPERATIONS TECHNICAL ASSISTANT (OTA) THAT PROVIDES TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO THE FIRE BRIGADE AT THE SCENE OF THE FIRE. ADDRESSING THIS SHORTAGE BY EITHER (1) ADDING AN ADDITIONAL LICENSED OPERATOR ON-SHIFT OR (2) REVISING THE UFSAR REQUIREMENT FOR HOW THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PIECE IS PROVIDED TO/BY THE FIRE BRIGADE DURING A FIRE IS REQUIRED TO SATISFY THE TIMELY COMPLETION OF THE EP FUNCTIONS ASSOCIATED WITH THE MAJOR FUNCTIONAL AREAS OF "PLANT OPERATIONS AND ASSESSMENT OF OPERATIONAL ASPECTS" AND "FIREFIGHTING". Extent of Condition: TWO OTHER CRs BEING GENERATED TO IDENTIFY OTHER ON-SHIFT STAFFING IMPACTS: 2ND RP TECH AND EMERGENCY COMMUNICATOR. Identified by Comments: CCNPP ON-SHIFT STAFFING ANALYSIS REPORT INCORPORATED INTO REV. 45 OF THE CCNPP EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN (APPENDIX F). Immediate actions Taken: N/A

Brief Description: ADJUSTMENTS TO ERO ON-SHIFT STAFFING BASED ON REV. 45 OF THE CCNPP ERP - ENSURE ADEQUATE OPS STAFFING TO INDEPENDENTLY FILL THE INTERIM EMERGENCY COMMUNICATOR ROLE.

Detailed Description: REVISION 45 OF THE CCNPP EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN (ERP) WAS APPROVED FOR IMPLEMENTATION ON 12/13/12. THIS REVISION INCLUDES THE INCORPORATION OF THE CCNPP ON-SHIFT STAFFING ANALYSIS REPORT THAT WAS COMPLETED BY EP CONSULTING, LLC IAW NEI 10-05, REVISION 0, ASSESSMENT OF ON-SHIFT ERO STAFFING AND CAPABILITIES. THE RESULTS OF THE STAFFING ANALYSIS INDICATED THAT THERE WAS AN INABILITY TO INDEPENDENTLY FULFILL THE ROLE OF THE EMERGENCY COMMUNICATOR DURING RESPONSE TO A CONTROL ROOM FIRE REQUIRING EVACUATION (E.G., AOP-9A SCENARIO - BOTH UNITS IMPACTED). UP UNTIL THE INCORPORATION OF THE STAFFING ANALYSIS INTO THE CCNPP ERP, IT HAD PERMISSIBLE TO HAVE THE ROLE OF (INTERIM) EMERGENCY COMMUNICATOR ASSIGNED AS A COLLATERAL RESPONSIBILITY OF ANOTHER ON-SHIFT ERO POSITION. TYPICALLY WITH THE ON-SHIFT OPERATIONS STAFF ONLY STAFFED WITH 10 AUXILIARY OPERATORS, THE ROLE OF EMERGENCY COMMUNICATOR HAS BEEN A COLLATERAL DUTY OF ONE OF THE FIRE BRIGADE MEMBERS. ADDRESSING THE NEED TO HAVE ADEQUATE OPERATIONS ON-SHIFT STAFFING TO PROVIDE FOR THE INDEPENDENCE OF THE EMERGENCY COMMUNICATOR ROLE WILL ENSURE THE TIMELY COMPLETION OF THE EP FUNCTIONS ASSOCIATED WITH THE MAJOR FUNCTIONAL AREA OF "NOTIFICATION/COMMUNICATION".

Extent of Condition: TWO OTHER CRs BEING GENERATED TO IDENTIFY OTHER ON-SHIFT STAFFING IMPACTS: OPERATIONS TECHNICAL ASSISTANT AND 2ND RP TECH.

Identified by Comments: CCNPP ON-SHIFT STAFFING ANALYSIS REPORT INCORPORATED INTO REV. 45 OF THE CCNPP EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN (APPENDIX F).

Immediate actions Taken: N/A

Brief Description: ACTIONS REQUIRED TO SUPPORT FCC NARROWBANDING MANDATE DUE BY 1/1/13 WERE NOT SATISFACTORILY IMPLEMENTED. Detailed Description: ALL ACTIONS REQUIRED TO SUPPORT THE FCC NARROWBANDING MANDATE DUE BY 1/1/13 WERE NOT SATISFACTORILY IMPLEMENTED. THE FCC NARROWBANDING MANDATE, WHICH GOES INTO EFFECT AT 0000 ON 1/1/13, REQUIRED PHYSICAL CHANGES/REPLACEMENTS TO HARDWARE THAT SUPPORTS A BACKUP COMMUNICATION METHOD BETWEEN CCNPP AND THE MARYLAND EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY (MEMA) AND THE MARYLAND DEPARTMENT OF THE ENVIRONMENT (MDE) USING THE 153.44 MHZ RADIO FREQUENCY. THIS RADIO COMMUNICATION METHOD SERVES AS THE SECOND BACKUP METHOD FOR COMMUNICATING WITH THESE TWO AGENCIES DURING PLANT EMERGENCIES IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE SITE'S EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN AND ITS IMPLEMENTING PROCEDURES. THE PRIMARY METHOD (DEDICATED OFFSITE AGENCY PHONE) AND THE FIRST BACKUP METHOD (COMMERCIAL PHONE LINE TO THE AGENCIES) REMAIN FULLY FUNCTIONAL AT THIS TIME AND ARE NOT IMPACTED BY THE MANDATE. THE PHYSICAL CHANGES/REPLACEMENTS CONCERN THREE BASE STATIONS: ONE AT THE ERDMAN AVE. SUBSTATION, ONE AT THE MEMA HEADQUATERS, AND ONE AT THE MDE HEADQUARTERS. CCNPP HAS BEEN WORKING WITH BGE TO FACILITATE THE WORK REQUIRED TO ENSURE THAT THE THREE BASE STATIONS ARE COMPLIANT WITH THE MANDATE. TO THIS POINT, THE BASE STATIONS AT ERDMAN AVE. AND MEMA HAVE BEEN MODIFIED TO BE MANDATE COMPLIANT; HOWEVER, THE MDE BASE STATION STILL NEEDS TO BE MODIFIED/REPLACED. THE MDE WORK WAS SCHEDULED TO BE COMPLETED LAST WEEK, BUT RESOURCE CHALLENGES WITHIN BGE PREVENTED THE WORK FROM BEING COMPLETED PRIOR TO THE IMPLEMENTATION DATE/TIME OF THE MANDATE. BGE RESOURCES HAVE COMMITTED TO COMPLETING THE REQUIRED WORK ON THE MDE BASE STATION, ALONG WITH ANY ADDITIONAL WORK THAT MAY BE REQUIRED ON THE ERDMAN AVE. BASE STATION, ON WEDNESDAY, 1/2/13. EP HAS WORKED WITH OPERATIONS TO ENSURE THAT THE 153.44 MHZ RADIO CHANNEL WILL NOT BE UTILIZED AS A BACKUP METHOD IN THE EVENT OF EMERGENCY NOTIFICATION DUE TO THE FCC FINES THAT WOULD BE INCURRED FOR DOING SO. COMPENSATORY MEASURES ARE BEING PUT IN PLACE TO HAVE MEMA AND MDE PERSONNEL PROVIDE CELL PHONE NUMBERS FOR THE APPROPRIATE OPERATORS AT THOSE LOCATIONS TO THE CONTROL ROOM ON A SHIFTLY BASIS COMMENCING ON 12/31/12 NIGHTSHIFT UNTIL THE RADIO EQUIPMENT HAS BEEN ADEQUATELY MODIFIED TO BE MANDATE COMPLIANT AND TESTED. THESE COMPENSATORY MEASURES ARE CONSISTENT WITH THE ACTIONS DELINEATED IN ERPIP-901, ATTACHMENT 22 (LOSS OF COMMUNICATIONS) FOR HAVING A BACKUP METHOD LOST OR DEGRADED. Extent of Condition: INVESTIGATION LEADING UP TO THIS PHYSICAL WORK DID NOT IDENTIFY ANY OTHER FREQUENCIES IN USE AT CCNPP THAT ARE SUBJECT TO THE NARROWBANDING MANDATE. Identified by Comments: Immediate actions Taken: EP WORKED WITH THE SHIFT MANAGER TO IMPLEMENT COMPENSATORY MEASURES TO PREVENT INADVERTENT USAGE OF THE 153.44 MHz CHANNEL FOR COMMUNICATION WITH MEMA AND MDE: - TEMPORARY NOTE WAS PLACED ON THE CONTROL ROOM RADIO BASE STATION DIRECTING THAT THE FREQUENCY WAS NOT TO BE USED UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE BY EP. - MEMA AND MDE PERSONNEL WILL PROVIDE SHIFTLY CELL PHONE NUMBERS FOR THEIR PHONE OPERATORS UNTIL THE RADIO FREQUENCY CAN AGAIN BE UTILIZED.

Brief Description: CCNPP ANS SIREN C66 WAS STRUCK BY LIGHTNING

Detailed Description: SIREN #C66 LOCATED IN CALVERT CO. AT RT.4/WESTERN SHORES BLVD TOOK A DIRECT LIGHTNING STRIKE AS RESULT OF SEVERE THUNDERSTORM CELLS WHICH ROLLED THROUGH THE AREA IN EARLY MORNING ON 06/13/13 BETWEEN 1245A-0100A. SIREN HAD A LOSS OF POWER ALARM ACTIVE UPON ARRIVAL TO WORK ON 06/13/13. NO OTHER SIRENS FAILED DURING STORM EVENT, 72 OF 73 SIRENS REMAINED OPERABLE. SIREN C66 IS CURRENTLY BACK IN SERVICE.

Extent of Condition: Cat IV trend. All sirens currently operable, 73 of 73.

Identified by Comments: Daily check of siren status using ANS siren console at CCNPP

Immediate actions Taken: Notified on-site SGEM crews and dispatched to siren location. Contacted SMECO to ensure no local area power outage event occurring. Crews made repairs to siren. Siren growl tested successfully.

Brief Description: SIREN C15 INADVERTENLY ACTIVATED DUE TO ELECTRONIC COMPONENT FAILURE FOR APPROXIMATELY 15 MINUTES

Detailed Description: AT APPROXIMATELY 1255 PM, SIREN C15 LOCATED IN CALVERT CO WAS INADVERTENLY ACTIVATED DUE TO WATER INTRUSION WHICH CAUSED ELECTRONIC BOARDS TO MALFUNCTION. SIREN INTERMITTENTLY SOUNDED A FEW TIMES AS DESCRIBED BY ON SCENE EYEWITNESS PUBLIC CITIZEN VERBAL STATEMENTS. CENG CREWS ARRIVED TO FIND NO SIREN SOUNDED UPON ARRIVAL BUT DID DISCOVER WATER INTRUSION AFTER HIGH RAIN STORM EVENT THAT HAD OCCURRED WITHIN THE LAST HOUR. CREWS REPAIRED ELECTRONICS AND REPLACED DOOR GASKET AND COMPLETED GROWL TEST TO ENSURE SIREN OPERABLE. ALL OTHER 72 OF 73 SIRENS REMAINED OPERABLE DURING EVENT. VALIDATED WITH LIC THAT THIS IS NOT AN NRC REPORTABLE EVENT.

Extent of Condition: ALL OTHER SIRENS, 72 OF 73 REMAINED OPERABLE.

Identified by Comments: using CCNPP ANS Console

Immediate actions Taken: Repaired hardware at siren, completed post maintenance testing

Brief Description: APPENDIX R AFTER INPUT FROM EXELON, AN EXTENT OF CONDITION REVIEW OF CR-2013-008305 IDENTIFIED ADDITIONAL UNFUSED DC CIRCUITS FOR WHICH AN APPENDIX R FIRE IN ONE AREA COULD CAUSE A SECONDARY FIRE IN OTHER AREAS.

Detailed Description: APPENDIX R AFTER INPUT FROM EXELON, AN EXTENT OF CONDITION REVIEW OF CR-2013-008305 IDENTIFIED ADDITIONAL UNFUSED DC CIRCUITS FOR WHICH AN APPENDIX R FIRE IN ONE AREA COULD CAUSE SECONDARY FIRES IN OTHER AREAS. AFTER INPUT FROM EXELON TO ALL OF THEIR PLANTS, A SECOND EXTENT OF CONDITION REVIEW IDENTIFIED THAT THERE WERE UNFUSED 250 V DC CIRCUITS FOR THE BATTERY CHARGER AMMETERS AND THE CONTROL CIRCUITS FOR VARIOUS DC LUBE OIL PUMPS WHICH LEFT THE TURBINE BUILDING AND WENT THROUGH THE RESPECTIVE CABLE SPREADING ROOM AND UP INTO THE CONTROL ROOM. THESE EMERGENCY DC LUBE OIL PUMPS PROVIDE OIL WHEN THE PRIMARY AC LUBE OIL PUMPS ALLOW A PRESSURE DROP FOR THE TURBINE GENERATOR, THE STEAM GENERATOR FEED PUMPS, ETC. THESE CIRCUITS ARE PROTECTED BY 200 AMP FUSES AND IN SOME CASES 100 AMP FUSES. THE CONCERN IS THAT UNDER THE FIRE SAFE SHUTDOWN RULES, IT IS POSTULATED THAT A FIRE IN ONE FIRE AREA CAN DAMAGE THESE CIRCUITS AND CAUSE SHORT CIRCUITS WITHOUT PROTECTION THAT WOULD OVERHEAT THE CABLES AND POSSIBLY RESULT IN SECONDARY FIRES IN OTHER FIRE AREAS WHERE THE CABLES ARE ROUTED. THE SECONDARY FIRES COULD ADVERSELY AFFECT SAFE SHUTDOWN EQUIPMENT AND POTENTIALLY CAUSE THE LOSS OF THE ABILITY TO CONDUCT A SAFE SHUTDOWN.

Extent of Condition: The 250 V DC System 016.

Identified by Comments: After input from Exelon to all of their plants, a second extent of condition review identified unfused 250 V DC circuits which left the Turbine Building and went through the respective Cable Spreading Room and up into the Control Room.

Immediate Actions Taken: Discussed the issue with licensing, who explained that there would need to be a phone call to the NRC because this is an unanalyzed Appendix R condition. It will be the NRC's determination if this was made an extent of condition of their Event Notification No.: 49449 based on CR-2013-008305 or if this needs to be a new Event Notification Number.

Brief Description: POSTULATED HOT SHORT FIRE EVENT THAT COULD ADVERSELY IMPACT SAFE SHUTDOWN EQUIPMENT

Detailed Description: A REVIEW OF INDUSTRY OPERATING EXPERIENCE IDENTIFIED THAT THERE WERE UNPROTECTED DC CONTROL CIRCUITS FOR NON SAFETY RELATED DC MOTORS. THE EQUIPMENT OF CONCERN INCLUDES MO/EOP, THE MOTOR FOR PLO04 (TURBINE EMERGENCY DC LUBE OIL PUMP), CIRCULATING WATER PUMP A DISCHARGE BUTTERFLY VALVE MOV-3150, AND CIRCULATING WATER PUMP B DISCHARGE BUTTERFLY MOV-3151. THE CONTROL CIRCUITS ARE ROUTED IN THE SCREENHOUSE, "B" DIESEL GENERATOR ROOM, TURBINE BUILDING, AIR HANDLING ROOM, RELAY ROOM, AND THE CONTROL ROOM. FUSES USED TO PROTECT THE MOTOR POWER CONDUCTORS APPEAR TO BE INADEQUATE TO PROTECT THE CONTROL CONDUCTORS. THE CONCERN IS THAT UNDER FIRE SAFE SHUTDOWN CONDITIONS, IT IS POSTULATED THAT A FIRE IN ONE FIRE AREA CAN DAMAGE THESE CIRCUITS AND CAUSE SHORT CIRCUITS WITHOUT ADEQUATE PROTECTION THAT WOULD OVERHEAT THE CABLES AND POSSIBLY RESULT IN SECONDARY FIRES OR CABLE FAILURES IN OTHER FIRE AREAS WHERE THE CABLES ARE ROUTED. THE SECONDARY FIRES OR CABLE FAILURES COULD ADVERSELY AFFECT SAFE SHUTDOWN EQUIPMENT AND POTENTIALLY CAUSE THE LOSS OF THE ABILITY TO CONDUCT A SAFE SHUTDOWN. ALSO SEE CR-2014-001170

Extent of Condition: Identified by

Comments: Immediate actions Taken: Notified Engineering Management, Operations and Licensing

Brief Description: POTENTIAL KNOWLEDGE DEFICIENCY FOR NRC REPORTABILITY AS IT RELATES TO THE PPC PI INDICATIONS Detailed Description: WORK WAS PERFORMED UNDER WO C081406500 WHICH REMOVED PI FROM SERVICE. WO PLANNING WAS PROPERLY PERFORMED AND LICENSING AND EP ENGAGED AS TO THE REPORTABILITY FOR LOSS OF ASSESSMENT FUNCTION. BASED ON RESPONSE FROM EP IT WAS CONSIDERED A LOSS OF ASSESSMENT FUNCTION, AND LICENSING AGREED THAT LOSING PI MET THE REPORTING CRITERIA PER CNG-NL-1.01-1004, ATTACHMENT 2, FOR LOSS OF SPDS IF LOST FOR GREATER THAN 8 HOURS. THIS IS ALL BASED ON EOF AND TSC LOSING THE PI SIGNAL, NOT THE CONTROL ROOM LOSING SPDS. EPMP-EPP-13 DOES NOT SPECIFY PI AS BEING PART OF SPDS AND NEITHER DOES CNG-NL-1.01-1004. IT BRINGS INTO QUESTION IF WE HAVE MISSED 8 HOUR REPORTS FOR TIMES IN THE PAST WHEN PI HAS BEEN OUT OF SERVICE FOR GREATER THAN 8 HOURS. THE 6 SROS THAT WERE PRESENT AT SHIFT TURNOVER HAD NEVER CONSIDERED PI AS PART OF SPDS AND THE RESPONSE FROM LICENSING THROUGH EMAIL WAS THE FIRST TIME WE'VE HEARD THAT PI WAS CONSIDERED SPDS RELATED. RECOMMEND THAT THIS CR BE ASSIGNED TO LICENSING TO VALIDATE IF LOSING PI IS REPORTABLE AS A LOSS OF SPDS AS ORIGINALLY INDICATED THROUGH EMAIL. IF IT IS INDEED REPORTABLE THE RECOMMEND THAT LICENSING AND EP MAKE CHANGES TO CNG-NL-1.01-1004 AND EPMP-EPP-13 TO CAPTURE THIS. ALSO, N1-OP-42 AND THE N2-OP-91 PROCEDURE SHOULD INCLUDE SOME DISCUSSION ABOUT LOSS OF PI. Extent of Condition: Identified by Comments: Immediate actions Taken:
