Brief Description: UNIT 1 REACTOR SCRAM. Detailed Description: ON JULY 17 2012, AT 11:18, NINE MILE POINT UNIT 1 EXPERIENCED AN AUTOMATIC REACTOR SCRAM DUE TO HIGH NEUTRON FLUX AS MEASURED BY THE AVERAGE POWER RANGE MONITORING SYSTEM. THE CAUSE IS CURRENTLY UNDER INVESTIGATION. ALL CONTROL RODS FULLY INSERTED AND ALL PLANT SYSTEMS RESPONDED PER DESIGN FOLLOWING THE SCRAM. THE HIGH PRESSURE COOLANT INJECTION SYSTEM, WHICH IS AN OPERATING MODE OF THE FEEDWATER SYSTEM, INITIATED AS EXPECTED. THERE WERE NO PLANNED ACTIVITIES IN PROGRESS AT THE TIME WHICH COULD HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO THE EVENT. NINE MILE POINT UNIT 1 IS CURRENTLY IN HOT SHUTDOWN, WITH REACTOR WATER LEVEL AND PRESSURE MAINTAINED WITHIN NORMAL BANDS. DECAY HEAT IS BEING REMOVED VIA STEAM TO THE MAIN CONDENSER USING THE BYPASS VALVES. THE OFFSITE GRID IS STABLE WITH NO GRID RESTRICTIONS OR WARNINGS IN EFFECT. ALL EMERGENCY POWER SOURCES ARE AVAILABLE IN STANDBY. THE UNIT IS CURRENTLY IMPLEMENTING POST SCRAM RECOVERY PROCEDURES. Extent of Condition: Identified by Comments: Immediate actions Taken:

Brief Description: POTENTIAL VULNERABILITY UNCOVERED DURING NMP SHIFT STAFFING STUDY Detailed Description: DURING NMP SHIFT STAFFING STUDY, A POTENTIAL VULNERABILITY WAS UNCOVERED IN THAT THE ERDS SYSTEM IS REQUIRED TO BE ACTIVATED WITHIN 1 HOUR OF AN EVENT DECLARATION. CURRENTLY THIS TASK IS ASSIGNED TO THE TSC ENS OPERATOR AS ONE OF THEIR TASKS UPON ARRIVAL IN THE TSC. THE VULNERABILITY EXISTS IF THE ENS COMMUNICATOR DOES NOT REPORT WITHIN AN HOUR OF EVENT DECLARATION, AND THEREFORE WOULD NOT ACTIVATE ERDS WITHIN THE REQUIRED 1 HOUR AFTER EVENT DECLARATION. Extent of Condition: Identified by Comments: Immediate actions Taken: GSO's contacted to align on publishing Night Note to direct actions until procedure is updated.

Brief Description: NRC HAS IDENTIFIED A SEVERITY LEVEL IV NCV FOR INAPPROPRIATELY RETRACTED AN EVENT NOTIFICATION REPORT (ENR) AND SUBSEQUENTLY FAILING TO MAKE THE REQUIRED LICENSEE EVENT REPORT (LER) FOR A VALID ACTUATION OF THE HPCI SYSTEM.

Detailed Description: NRC INSPECTION REPORT 2013-002 (ATTACHED) DATED MAY 9, 2013 DOCUMENTS A GREEN NCV. THE INSPECTION REPORT STATES: "THE INSPECTORS IDENTIFIED A SEVERITY LEVEL IV NCV OF REGULATIONS IN THAT UNIT 1 INAPPROPRIATELY RETRACTED AN EVENT NOTIFICATION REPORT (ENR) AND SUBSEQUENTLY FAILED TO MAKE THE REQUIRED LICENSEE EVENT REPORT (LER) FOR A VALID ACTUATION OF THE HPCI SYSTEM. SPECIFICALLY, CONSTELLATION INAPPROPRIATELY RETRACTED ENR NUMBER 48477, AN 8-HOUR NOTIFICATION FOR A VALID HPCI ACTUATION AND FAILED TO SUBMIT AN LER WITHIN 60 DAYS OF DISCOVERY OF THE ACTUATION. CONSTELLATION ENTERED THIS ISSUE INTO THEIR CAP AS CR-2013-001859. THE INSPECTORS DETERMINED THAT THE INAPPROPRIATE RETRACTION OF A NOTIFICATION REQUIRED AND FAILURE TO MAKE A REQUIRED EVENT REPORT WERE PERFORMANCE DEFICIENCIES THAT WERE REASONABLY WITHIN CONSTELLATION'S ABILITY TO FORESEE AND CORRECT AND SHOULD HAVE BEEN PREVENTED. BECAUSE THIS ISSUE HAD THE POTENTIAL TO AFFECT THE NRC'S ABILITY TO PERFORM ITS REGULATORY FUNCTION, THE INSPECTORS EVALUATED THESE PERFORMANCE DEFICIENCIES IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE TRADITIONAL ENFORCEMENT PROCESS. USING EXAMPLE 6.9.D.9 FROM THE NRC ENFORCEMENT POLICY, THE INSPECTORS DETERMINED THAT THE VIOLATION WAS A SEVERITY LEVEL IV (MORE THAN MINOR CONCERN THAT RESULTED IN NO OR RELATIVELY INAPPRECIABLE POTENTIAL SAFETY OR SECURITY CONSEQUENCE) VIOLATION. BECAUSE THIS VIOLATION INVOLVES THE TRADITIONAL ENFORCEMENT PROCESS AND DOES NOT HAVE AN UNDERLYING TECHNICAL VIOLATION THAT WOULD BE CONSIDERED MORE THAN MINOR, THE INSPECTORS DID NOT ASSIGN A CROSS-CUTTING ASPECT TO THIS VIOLATION IN ACCORDANCE WITH PROCEDURES." THE SUBJECT EVENT WAS ADDRESSED IN A CAT 2, TIER 2 CR 2013-001859. SINCE THE INITIAL ANALYSIS IN APRIL 2013, THE NRC HAS CHARACTERIZED THE EVENT AS A LEVEL IV NCV WITH NO CROSS CUTTING ASPECT. THIS NEW CR IS BEING GENERATED TO REVISIT THE INITIAL EVALUATION AND COMPARE IT TO THE NRC'S CHARACTERIZATION OF THE EVENT AS DOCUMENTED IN THE ATTACHED INSPECTION REPORT. THE GOAL IS TO DETERMINE IF ANY ADDITIONAL CAUSE EVALUATIONS OR ACTIONS ARE WARRANTED BEYOND THOSE ALREADY TAKEN OR PLANNED. RECOMMEND ASSIGNMENT TO LICENSING (ORGANIZATION THAT DISPOSITIONED THE ORIGINAL CR) TO COMPLETE A GAP ANALYSIS. NOTE TO SCREENING COMMITTEE: PER CNG-CA-1.01-1000, ATTACHMENT 3, CR FOR NRC GREEN NCVS OR FINDINGS THAT HAVE NO CROSS CUTTING COMPONENT SHOULD BE CATEGORIZED AS CAT 2 TIER 2.

Brief Description: CR INITIATED TO CREATE WO TO CONDUCT THERMOGRAPHY AND VISUAL INSPECTIONS OF VALVES VLV-36-374 AND VLV-89-72

Detailed Description: CREATE WO TO CONDUCT THERMOGRAPHY AND VISUAL INSPECTIONS OF NMP1 VALVES VLV-36-374 AND VLV-89-72. CAUSE EVALUATION IS IN PROGRESS TO DETERMINE CAUSE(S) OF PROBLEM IDENTIFIED IN CR-2013-004347. THE PROBLEM STATEMENT IS: "ON MAY 14, 2013, AT 1154 HRS, WHILE IN THE STARTUP MODE AND AT 3% POWER, THE SECOND CHANNEL (12) OF TWO CHANNELS OF HIGH STEAM FLOW SENSING INSTRUMENTATION FOR EMERGENCY CONDENSER (EC) LOOP #11 ALARMED DUE TO GROSS FAILURE RESULTING IN LOSS OF EC LOOP 11 ISOLATION CAPABILITY DUE TO HIGH STEAM FLOW. THE FIRST CHANNEL (11) ALARMED AT 0840 HRS ON MAY 14, 2013. THIS IS SIGNIFICANT FROM A NUCLEAR SAFETY PERSPECTIVE BECAUSE THIS INSTRUMENTATION IS REQUIRED FOR THE MITIGATION OF THE CONSEQUENCES OF AN ACCIDENT. THE EVENT WAS REPORTABLE TO THE NRC." THE FAILURE MODES AND EFFECTS ANALYSIS (FMEA) INDICATED A POTENTIAL CAUSE AS MINOR LEAKBY OF VALVES VLV-36-374 AND VLV-89-72. THIS ACTIVITY IS INTENDED TO PROVIDE INFORMATION TO REFUTE OR SUBSTANTIATE THE FMEA. SINCE STARTUP FROM N1RF22, INSTRUMENTATION IS FUNCTIONING WITH NO ABNORMAL INDICATIONS. THE WO IS INTENDED TO CONDUCT THERMOGRAPHIC AND VISUAL INSPECTIONS OF THESE VALVES IN THE EAST INSTRUMENT ROOM (~281'EL).

Extent of Condition: Identified by

Comments: Immediate actions Taken:

Brief Description: TSC AIR CONDITIONING UNIT TRIPPED

Detailed Description: DURING A TRANSIT THROUGH THE TSC, THE TSC AIR CONDITIONING UNIT WAS FOUND TRIPPED. FIN ELECTRICIANS ATTEMPTED A RESET. THEY WERE ABLE TO START THE SECONDARY COILS, BUT THE PRIMARY COILS REMAINED TRIPPED. ROOM TEMPERATURE IS APPROXIMATELY 87 - 89B0F. THIS IS LIKELY DUE TO OPERATION ON ONLY THE SECONDARY COILS.

Extent of Condition: Identified by

Immediate actions Taken: Notified Control Room

Brief Description: CATEGORY 2 APPARENT CAUSE SHORTFALLS

Detailed Description: THE REVIEW OF 16 TIER 1 AND TIER 2 APPARENT CAUSE EVALUATIONS COMPLETED FROM 2011 TO 2013 CONCLUDED THAT THE CAUSE EVALUATIONS WERE LESS THAN ADEQUATE. SHORTFALLS IN CLEAR PROBLEM STATEMENTS, USE OF CAUSE ANALYSIS TOOLS, LACK OF DEPTH IN THE ANALYSIS, ALIGNMENT OF CORRECTIVE ACTIONS TO IDENTIFIED CAUSES, LACK OF DOCUMENTATION AND INCOMPLETE EFFECTIVENESS REVIEW PLANS. 

b " SOME PROBLEM STATEMENTS DO NOT CLEARLY STATE THE PROBLEM

1) CR-2012-001018 - THE PROBLEM STATEMENT WAS WRITTEN, " THIS CR DOCUMENTS THE OFFICIAL RESULTS OF AN NRC INSPECTION WHICH REVIEWED ACTIONS FOR AN UNRESOLVED ITEM (URI) CONCERNING THE SECOND LEVEL (DEGRADED GRID) VOLTAGE PROTECTION SCHEME STEMMING FROM THE 2008 NMP COMPONENT DESIGN BASIS INSPECTION (CDBI). SPECIFICALLY, THE NRC NOTED THE EXISTING NMP1 DEGRADED GRID RELAY'S TIME DELAY OF A NOMINAL TWENTY-ONE (21) SECONDS WAS LONGER THAN ASSUMED BY THE LOCA ANALYSES DESCRIBED IN THE UFSAR. AS DOCUMENTED IN THE CR INITIATION, THIS APPARENT CAUSE EVALUATION WILL REVISIT THE INITIAL EVALUATION AND WILL COMPARE IT TO THIS OFFICIAL NRC REPORT TO DETERMINE IF ANY ADDITIONAL CAUSE EVALUATIONS OR ACTIONS ARE WARRANTED BEYOND THOSE ALREADY TAKEN OR PLANNED." THIS IS NOT AN APPARENT CAUSE PROBLEM STATEMENT.

2) CR-2012-010806 - THE PROBLEM STATEMENT IS A VERBATIM RESTATEMENT OF THE CR DESCRIPTION AND NOT A PROBLEM STATEMENT. "ON 12/06/2011, AT APPROXIMATELY 20:31 HRS, UNIT 1 RECEIVED AN UNEXPECTED ANNUNCIATOR F2-6-8 , 11-14 APRM, ANNUNCIATOR F3-1-1, 15-18 APRM, AND ANNUNCIATOR F3-4-4, ROD BLOCK. REVIEW OF ALL APRMS INDICATED A SPIKE IN REACTOR POWER, WITH APRMS 12 AND 15 IN ALARM. REACTOR NARROW RANGE PRESSURE INDICATED A SPIKE IN PRESSURE FROM 1028 TO 1031 PSIG. TURBINE CONTROL VALVES POSITION INDICATION WENT FROM 97% OPEN TO 91% OPEN. ALL PARAMETERS IMMEDIATELY RETURNED TO PRE-TRANSIENT VALUES WITHOUT OPERATOR ACTION. THE ELECTRONIC PRESSURE REGULATOR (EPR) MOMENTARILY FAILED TO CONTROL PRESSURE, RESULTING IN A REACTOR PRESSURE INCREASE AND NEUTRON FLUX SPIKE."

b " SOME TIER 1 AND 2 ACES DO NOT PROPERLY USE CAUSAL ANALYSIS TOOLS BOTH IN DOCUMENTING THE CAUSAL TOOL RESULTS, EVALUATING OTHER DISCOUNTED CAUSES AND DRIVING PAST HARDWARE DISCUSSIONS TO ORGANIZATIONAL/PROGRAMMATIC ISSUES.

1) CR-2012-001018 USED A EVENT & CAUSAL FACTOR (E&CF) CHART AND COMPARATIVE TIMELINE. THE E&CF ONLY HAS THE EVENTS AND CAUSES. THERE IS NO ANALYSIS OF HOW THE EVALUATOR DETERMINED THE CAUSE. THE COMPARATIVE TIMELINE IN THE CR DOES NOT FOLLOW THE FORMAT FOR A COMPARATIVE TIMELINE. IT DROPPED THE ANALYSIS COLUMNS. THEREFORE IT IS NOT CLEAR HOW THE APPARENT AND CONTRIBUTING CAUSES WERE DETERMINED.

2) APPARENT CAUSE CR-2012-009540 STATED, "THE APPARENT CAUSE STATES THAT THE PERSONNEL INVOLVED IN THE PROCEDURE DEVELOPMENT DID NOT RECOGNIZE THE NEED FOR, NOR COORDINATE REVIEWS WITH OTHER KEY TEAM MEMBERS, I.E. NO CROSS-DISCIPLINARY REVIEWS. THIS CAUSE SHOULD HAVE GONE ONE LEVEL DEEPER TO DETERMINE WHY THE RESPONSIBLE INDIVIDUALS DID MADE THE ERROR AND DID NOT GET THE APPROPRIATE REVIEWS. THE CONTRIBUTING CAUSE STATED. "TRAINING DID NOT ADEQUATELY PREPARE PERSONNEL TO RECOGNIZE THE REPORTABLE CONDITION, WHICH THEN ALLOWED THE PROCEDURE TO BE PUT INTO PLACE, TRAIN ON AND IMPLEMENTED SEVERAL TIMES OVER THE YEARS UNTIL IT WAS RECOGNIZED ON 10/18/12. CONTRIBUTING CAUSE " THERE WAS NO DISCUSSION OF THE ADEQUACY OF PROGRAMS OR PROCESSES THAT ARE USED TO CONTROL PROCEDURE CHANGES. THE CAUSE ROAD MAP AND WHY STAIRCASE WERE USED BUT ONLY FOCUSED ON THE MINDSET AND USE OF ASSUMPTIONS CONCLUDING TRAINING WAS A PROBLEM. NOTE THE CAUSE IDENTIFIED FORM THE USE OF THE CAUSE ROAD MAP AND WHEY STAIRCASE ALIGN WITH THE CONTRIBUTING CAUSE NOT THE APPARENT CAUSE.

3) CR-2012-000476 - THERE IS NO EVIDENCE THAT ANY ANALYSIS TOOLS WERE USED FOR THIS CR. ALSO, THE EVALUATION NOTED THAT THERE WAS A PROCEDURE COMPLIANCE ISSUE BUT IT WAS NOT EVALUATED. THE APPARENT CAUSE IS A DIRECT CAUSE RATHER THAN A MORE FUNDAMENTAL CAUSE "THAT THE MOST PROBABLE DIRECT CAUSE FOR THE DEGRADED CELL WAS A MANUFACTURING DEFECT THAT LED TO A DIRECT SHORT." CC#1 IS NOT ALIGNED WITH THE PROBLEM IT IDENTIFIES SEVERAL ISSUES RELATED TO PROBLEMS WITH RAISING BATTERY CELL VOLTAGE IF IT IS FOUND DEGRADED.

4) CATEGORY 2 TIER 2, CR -2012-006661, "CHRONIC RECURRING ISSUE HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED ON THE UNIT 2 6TH POINT FEEDWATER HEATER" STATES THE FOLLOWING. "NOTES: 1) SINCE THIS CAUSAL EVALUATION HAS RESULTED IN THE SAME CONCLUSIONS AS PRIOR EVALUATIONS, AN ACTION HAS BEEN ESTABLISHED TO SUBMIT THE APPLICABLE TRENDING DATA, DRAWINGS, AND FMEA TO THE OEM OR INDUSTRY/FLEET SME'S FOR REVIEW TO CORROBORATE THESE CONCLUSIONS. 2) C91942585 HAS BEEN INITIATED FOR REPAIR AND WILL INCLUDE PERFORMANCE OF REPAIRS AS RECOMMENDED FROM THE REVIEW OUTLINED ABOVE AND THIS CAUSAL ANALYSIS." SUBSEQUENT ACTIONS TAKEN WITH THE VENDOR CONFIRMED THE CONCLUSIONS OF THE ACE WITH THE ONLY ESTABLISHED CORRECTIVE ACTION BEING TO REPAIR THE HEATER. THE APPARENT CAUSE DOES NOT INVESTIGATE WHY PREVIOUS CORRECTIVE ACTIONS FOR THE SAME CAUSE HAVE BEEN INEFFECTIVE AND MERELY ESTABLISHES ANOTHER REPAIR ACTION BASED ON VENDOR RECOMMENDATIONS.

5) CR-2013-003497 IDENTIFIES THAT THE TURBINE SYSTEM ENGINEER DID NOT INITIALLY STOP THE JOB AND GET THE SUPERVISOR INVOLVED WHEN THE ELECTRICIANS WERE UNRESPONSIVE TO THIS CONCERNS ABOUT JOB SAFETY. THE UNDERLYING CAUSE FOR THIS FAILED BARRIER IS NOT EVALUATED

b " SOME CORRECTIVE ACTIONS CREATED TO CONDUCT HARDWARE ANALYSES TO VALIDATE THE CAUSE ARE NOT BEING CLOSED PROPERLY.

1) PREVENTATIVE CA-2012-004915, STATED, "REVIEW FAILURE ANALYSIS OF FLEX HOSE (CA 2012-004725) AND ESTABLISH ADDITIONAL ACTIONS IF WARRANTED." THE ACTION WAS CLOSED TO A PENDING PCR WITH NO ACTIONS ADDED TO THE CR TO TRACK CLOSURE. ADDITIONALLY CLOSURE DOCUMENTATION IS NOT ATTACHED FOR THIS CATEGORY 2 TIER 2 ACTION AS REQUIRED BY CNG-CA-1.01-1000.

2) CATEGORY 3 CORRECTIVE CA-2012-004725 STATES, "REVIEW AND ATTACH FAILURE ANALYSIS TO THIS CONDITION REPORT AND DETERMINE IF FURTHER ACTIONS ARE REQUIRED BASED ON THE FAILURE ANALYSIS REPORT AND DOCUMENT FINDINGS IN THIS ACTION." THE CLOSURE FOR THIS ACTIONS STATES, "THE FLEXIBLE TUBING WAS REALIGNED AND SHOULD PROVIDE MANY YEARS OF SERVICE. A WORK ORDER C92253372 HAS BEEN WRITTEN AND IS CURRENTLY SCHEDULED FOR REMOVAL & REPLACEMENT IN 2015. THE WORK ORDER WILL SEND THE OLD TUBING TO THE SYSTEM ENGINEER AND HE WILL FORWARD TO THE GINNA MATERIALS LAB TO SEE IF THERE ARE SIGNS OF FATIGUE. IN ADDITION PROCEDURE N1-MPM-029-106, FEEDWATER PUMP #13 CLUTCH AND GEAR INSPECTION, HAS A PROCEDURE CHANGE REQUEST, PCR-13-02156, AND PRC-13-000019 TO REVISE THE TWO YEAR PM TO REPLACE THE $40 FLEXIBLE STEEL TUBING EACH REFUEL OUTAGE. SINCE THE FAILURE ANALYSIS REVIEW WAS COMPLETED, AND THE RECOMMENDATION IN THE FAILURE ANALYSIS WAS TO REALIGN THE FITTINGS, WORK ORDER C92253372 WILL REMOVE AND CHECK THAT THE ACTION TO REALIGN THE FITTINGS WAS SUCCESSFUL AND THAT THE CLUTCH OVERHAUL PROCEDURE, WHICH IS PERFORMED EVERY TWO YEARS, WILL BE REVISED TO HAVE THE TUBING REPLACED, THIS CORRECTIVE ACTION IS COMPLETE AND MAY BE CLOSED." CONTRARY TO THE REQUIREMENTS OF CA-2012-004725, AN ACTION WAS NOT CREATED TO INCORPORATE THE PCR INTO THE PROCEDURE.

3) PREVENTATIVE CA-2012-004394, STATES "OBTAIN FAILURE ANALYSIS RESULTS OF POTENTIOMETERS A3P AND A2P FROM EXELON POWER LABS FOR REVIEW AND ATTACH TO THIS CR. NEW ACTIONS ARE TO BE GENERATED IF THE RESULTS WARRANT." THE CLOSURE TO THIS ACTION STATES THAT A2P WAS FOUND NORMAL THROUGH ANALYSIS AND NOT A CONTRIBUTOR TO THE EVENT. CONTRARY TO THIS, THE ROOT CAUSE WAS NOT REVISED.

4) CORRECTIVE CA-2011-002504 (CR-2011-005458) STATES, "SHIP ACTUATOR BACK TO VENDOR FOR A COMPREHENSIVE TEST TO BE PERFORMED AND EVALUATE FINDINGS. CA UPDATED WITH VENDOR FAILURE ANALYSIS RESULTS. BASED ON VENDOR ANALYSIS ADDITIONAL ACTIONS MAY BE REQUIRED." THE CR STATES, "A CONTRIBUTING CAUSE OF THE ACTUATOR FAILURE IS THE PM WAS RESCHEDULED THREE TIMES DUE TO UNAVAILABILITY OF SPARE ACTUATORS. THE THIRD SCHEDULE CHANGE REQUIRED A PM DEFERRAL TO PREVENT EXCEEDING THE GRACE DATE. A DEFERRAL WAS REQUIRED DUE TO A PAST HISTORY OF PARTS HAVING VERY LONG LEAD TIMES AND DIFFICULTIES IN OBTAINING PROMPT FUNDING FOR REFURBISHMENT OF REMOVED ACTUATORS. THE PM WAS ORIGINALLY SCHEDULED FOR 1049J THEN CHANGED TO WORK WEEK 1118F. AS A RESULT OF THE PM DEFERRAL THE WORK WAS RESCHEDULED TO 1140B WEEK. THIS ACTUATOR FAILURE OCCURRED DURING WORK WEEK 1123J. THE 6 YEAR PM FOR REPLACEMENT OF THE UNIT EXCEEDED THE ORIGINAL GRACE DATE CAUSING THE SEAL TO DEGRADE FURTHER DUE TO EXCESSIVE TIME IN SERVICE." THE RESULTS OF THE FAILURE ANALYSIS CONFIRMED THAT THE CONTRIBUTING CAUSE WAS IN FACT THE APPARENT CAUSE. NO CORRECTIVE ACTIONS WERE CREATED TO ADDRESS THIS CAUSE. CR-2011-005559 DOCUMENTS THIS ADVERSE TREND AND WAS CLOSED TO CR-2011-005458.

5) CONDITION REPORT CR-2011-004307 DOCUMENTS THE FAILURE OF BV 70-69, REACTOR BUILDING CLOSED LOOP COOLING INLET TO 12 FUEL POOL HEAT EXCHANGER. THIS FAILURE WAS DETERMINED TO BE A CRITICAL COMPONENT FAILURE ACCORDING TO THE MAINTENANCE RULE PAGE. THE FOLLOWING APPARENT CAUSE WAS STATED, "THE PROBABLE CAUSE OF THE EVENT IS AN INTERMITTENT PROBLEM WITH THE SOV. "CA-2011-00931 WAS CREATED TO PERFORM A FAILURE ANALYSIS. CA-2011-001932 WAS WRITTEN TO, "DETERMINE PROBABLE CAUSE OF BV-70-69." SINCE THE SOLENOID WAS NEVER REMOVED FROM SERVICE, THE FOLLOWING CLOSURE WAS WRITTEN, "A FAILURE ANALYSIS WAS NOT COMPLETED BECAUSE THE ORIGINAL SOV WAS NEVER REMOVED FROM SERVICE. THIS ACTION CAN BE CLOSED SINCE SUBSEQUENT TESTING TO N1-ST-Q12 REVEALED NO ADDITIONAL PROBLEMS WITH THE VALVE. THE EVENT TOOK PLACE ON 4/27/11. N1-ST-Q12 WAS PERFORMED ON 5/2/11, 7/6/11, 10/31/11 AND MOST RECENTLY ON 1/5/12, ALL WITHOUT REPORTED ISSUES. APPARENT CAUSE OF VALVE NOT OPENING AS DISCUSSED IN CR-2011-004307 WAS INTERMITTENT SOV FAILURE. NO FURTHER ACTION IS REQUIRED. THIS ACTION CLOSURE HAS RECEIVED THE SAME LEVEL OF REVIEW AS THE ORIGINAL CR DISPOSITION." THE ONLY CORRECTIVE ACTION CLOSURE STATED FOR THIS CRITICAL COMPONENT FAILURE WAS, "A REQUIREMENT WAS ADDED TO WO C91299950 TO REPLACE THE SOV DURING VALVE MAINTENANCE. A NOTE TO PROVIDE THE REMOVED SOV TO THE AOV COMPONENT ENGINEER WAS ALSO ADDED TO THE WO. THE REMOVED SOV WILL BE SENT OUT FOR FAILURE ANALYSIS BY THE AOV COMPONENT ENGINEER. NO ACTIONS WERE CREATED IN THE CR TO COMPLETE THESE ACTIVITIES. THE CATEGORY 2 CR WAS CLOSED TO AN INTERMITTENT FAILURE AND NO CORRECTIVE ACTIONS TAKEN.

6) CR-2011-001455, "ADVERSE TREND IN PHASE SEQUENCE RELAY FAILURES ON IRON PREFILTER AIR COMPRESSORS," DETERMINED THE APPARENT CAUSE TO BE, "THE APPARENT CAUSE OF THE FAILURES IS HIGH AMBIENT TEMPERATURE RESULTING IN PHASE SEQUENCE RELAY COMPONENT DEGRADATION, AND ULTIMATELY PREMATURE FAILURE. SEE ATTACHED FMEA FOR ANALYSIS." CA-2011-000909, WAS CREATED TO, "SEND FAILED PHASE SEQUENCE RELAYS TO OUTSIDE VENDOR FOR FAILURE ANALYSIS" AND ADD ACTIONS AS NECESSARY. THE VENDOR ANALYSIS DETERMINED THAT THE TRANSFORMER WAS NOT PROPERLY RATED. A CORRECTIVE ACTION WAS CREATED TO REPLACE THE TRANSFORMER WITH A NEW DESIGN HOWEVER THE APPARENT CAUSE WAS NOT REVISED AND STILL EVALUATES AND PROVIDES THE BASIS OF HIGH AMBIENT TEMPERATURES WITH NO ASSOCIATED CORRECTIVE ACTIONS.

7) CR-2011-0057692 DETERMINED THAT FOREIGN MATERIAL INTRUSION INTO THE SPOOL AND CAGE ASSEMBLY WAS THE CAUSE OF THE #13 FEEDWATER CONTROL VALVE BINDING. SUBSEQUENT ENHANCEMENT ACTIONS LATER DETERMINED THAT SIDE THRUSTING OF THE CV-7 SIDE MANIFOLD WAS LEADING TO GALLING OF THE SPOOL AND CAGE. DUE TO THE SOFTER NITRONIC-60 MATERIAL OF THE SPOOL AND CAGE, FOREIGN MATERIAL WAS PRODUCED LEADING TO THE EVENTUAL BINDING OF THE FLOW CONTROL VALVE. THE LATER LEARNING'S GATHERED FROM ADDITIONAL ANALYSIS WERE NOT REVISED BACK INTO THE ACE. AS A RESULT ALTHOUGH ACTIONS TO CORRECT THE CONDITION WERE PROPERLY TAKEN, THE ACE STILL REFLECTS THAT THE REVISION TO THE PROCEDURE TO CLEAN THE PARTS PRIOR TO ASSEMBLY WOULD PREVENT REOCCURRENCE. ACTUAL ACTIONS THAT WERE TAKEN ARE NOT REFLECTED IN THE ACE NOR IS THE CAUSE OF EXTENT OF CAUSE CORRECT.

b " EQUIPMENT ACE ATTACHMENT 3 FOR AP-913 REVIEW NOT COMPLETED FOR SOME APPARENT CAUSE EVALUATIONS. CONDITION REPORTS 2012-002176 AND 2012-001566.

Brief Description: SERVICE WATER RAD MONITOR FLUSH NOT EFFECTIVE

Detailed Description: THE UNIT 1 SERVICE WATER RAD MONITOR, RAM-72-406, HAS BEEN FLUSHED BY OPERATIONS DUE TO DEGRADING FLOW. THE END RESULT WAS 2.02 GPM ON THE EAST SIDE (RBCLC) AND 2.17 GPM ON THE WEST SIDE (TBCLC). THE ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA IN N1-CTP-V203, SERVICE WATER RADIATION MONITOR FLOW ADJUSTMENT/PUMP SWITCH/AIR PURGE/PUMP STARTUP/SHUTDOWN, ASKS IF THE SERVICE WATER RADIATION MONITOR DIGITAL FLOW INDICATOR READS APPROXIMATELY 3 (2.0 TO 4.0) GPM. THE FLOWS BEFORE THE FLUSH WERE 2.02 GPM W AND 1.89 E. THE FLUSH HAS NOT GIVEN THE RAD MONITORS MUCH MARGIN TO BE IN THE ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA AND WILL IN THE NEAR FUTURE DEGRADE AGAIN AND WILL NEED TO BE FLUSHED AGAIN OR TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE. THIS WILL RESULT IN CHEMISTRY TO PERFORM N1-CTP-V203, SERVICE WATER RADIATION MONITOR PUMP SHUTDOWN. SERVICE WATER RADIATION MONITOR WILL BE OUT OF SERVICE DURING PUMP STARTUP/SHUTDOWN AND DLCO 3.6.14-1 WILL BE ENTERED.

PLANT IMPACT: WITH THE NUMBER OF CHANNELS FUNCTIONAL LESS THAN REQUIRED BY THE MINIMUM CHANNELS FUNCTIONAL REQUIREMENT, EFFLUENT RELEASES VIA THIS PATHWAY MAY CONTINUE PROVIDED THAT, AT LEAST ONCE PER 12 HOURS, GRAB SAMPLES ARE COLLECTED AND ANALYZED FOR GAMMA RADIOACTIVITY AT A LOWER LIMIT OF DETECTION OF AT LEAST 5 X 10E-7 MICROCURIE/ML. SERVICE WATER RADIATION MONITOR REPORTABILITY IS NOT REQUIRED AS A MAJOR LOSS OF EMERGENCY ASSESSMENT CAPABILITY PROVIDED (1) THE RADIATION MONITOR CAN BE RESTORED TO SERVICE WITHIN 1 HOUR OR VIABLE COMPENSATORY ACTIONS ARE IMPLEMENTED; AND (2) THE PLANNED OUTAGE IS NOT EXPECTED TO, AND SUBSEQUENTLY DID NOT EXCEED 72 HOURS.

Extent of Condition: Identified by

Comments: Immediate actions Taken: Notified the Control Room

Brief Description: STACK WRGMS UNEXPECTED ALARMS AFTER RESTORING FROM SCHEDULED SURVEILLANCE TEST

Detailed Description: AFTER RESTORING STACK WIDE RANGE GASEOUS MONITORING SYSTEM (WRGMS) TO THE AS FOUND CONDITION (SKID OUT OUT OF SERVICE), UNEXPECTED ALARMS WERE BEING RECEIVED IN THE CONTROL ROOM. INITIAL INVESTIGATION DETERMINED THAT THE INDICATED SAMPLE FLOW WAS APPROXIMATELY 0.51 SCFH, WITH THE LOW ALARM POINT BEING 0.50 SCFH. IN THIS CONDITION, THE MONITOR CONSIDERED ITSELF IN THE 'OPER' MODE. THE INDICATED FLOW WOULD OCCASIONALLY DRIFT DOWN TO 0.50 SCFH, AND CAUSE THE CONTROL ROOM ALARMS AND THE SKID WOULD LEAVE THE 'OPER' MODE. HOWEVER, THE SAMPLE SKID WAS COMPLETELY ISOLATED FROM ALL PROCESS FLOWS AND THE SAMPLE PUMPS WERE SECURED. THEREFORE THE SAMPLE FLOW RATE SHOULD HAVE READ APPROXIMATELY 0 (ZERO), AND THE SYSTEM SHOULD NOT HAVE BEEN IN 'OPER' MODE. THE ORIGINAL EQUIPMENT MANUFACTURER (OEM) HAS BEEN CONTACTED FOR GUIDANCE, AND TROUBLE SHOOTING HAS BEGUN. THIS CR IS TO DOCUMENT THE UNEXPECTED ALARMS, AND SHOULD BE EVALUATED FOR REWORK. 

Extent of Condition: Identified by

Brief Description: 8 HOUR NRC FOLLOW UP NOTIFICATION Detailed Description: 8 HOUR NRC FOLLOW UP NOTIFICATION COMPLETED FOR THE FOLLOWING: AN AUTOMATIC INITIATION OF EMERGENCY DIESEL GENERATORS WAS RECEIVED DUE TO A LOSS OF ONE OF TWO OFF-SITE POWER SOURCES. ON FEBRUARY 16, 2014 AT 1216, NINE MILE POINT UNIT 2 EXPERIENCED AN AUTOMATIC INITIATION OF THE DIVISION 1 AND 3 EMERGENCY DIESEL GENERATORS DUE TO A LOSS OF LINE 5. LINE 5 IS ONE OF THE TWO 115KV OFFSITE POWER SOURCES. LINE 5 WAS LOST DUE TO AN OFFSITE EVENT THAT IS CURRENTLY BEING EVALUATED BY THE GRID OPERATOR. DURING THE ELECTRICAL TRANSIENT, NINE MILE POINT UNIT 2 ALSO EXPERIENCED A FEEDWATER LEVEL CONTROL LOCKUP, REQUIRING MANUAL CONTROL. NO EMERGENCY CORE COOLING SYSTEMS ACTUATED, AND FEEDWATER LEVEL CONTROL WAS RETURNED TO AUTOMATIC. NINE MILE POINT UNIT 2 REMAINED AT 100% POWER DURING THE LOSS OF LINE 5, ONE OF THE OFFSITE POWER SOURCES. THE NRC RESIDENT HAS BEEN NOTIFIED. "*** UPDATE MONDAY FEB 17, 2014 TIME 1700 *** IN ADDITION TO THE INITIATION OF DIVISION 1 AND 3 EMERGENCY DIESEL GENERATORS, SERVICE WATER RADIATION MONITOR 2SWP*RE146A AND RADWASTE / REACTOR BUILDING VENT GASEOUS EFFLUENT MONITORING SYSTEMS WERE ALSO LOST. COMPENSATORY ACTIONS WERE ESTABLISHED AS REQUIRED BY STATION PROCEDURES AND THE OFFSITE DOSE CALCULATION MANUAL. THE LOSS OF THESE INSTRUMENTS IS REPORTABLE AS A MAJOR LOSS OF EMERGENCY ASSESSMENT CAPABILITY. THE SERVICE WATER RADIATION MONITOR 2SWP*RE146A WAS RESTORED TO SERVICE ON FEBRUARY 16, 2014 AT 1450. THE RADWASTE / REACTOR BUILDING VENT GASEOUS EFFLUENT MONITORING SYSTEM WERE RESTORED TO SERVICE ON FEBRUARY 17, 2014 AT 0240. IT IS RECOGNIZED THAT THIS NOTIFICATION IS NOT WITHIN EIGHT HOURS OF THE EVENT. LINE 5 IS RESTORED TO OPERABLE FEBRUARY 17, 2014 AT 1628. THE NRC RESIDENT HAS BEEN INFORMED OF THIS ADDITIONAL REPORTABLE CONDITION. THE CONDITION HAS BEEN ENTERED INTO THE CORRECTIVE ACTION PROGRAM." Extent of Condition: Identified by Comments: Immediate actions Taken: 8 Hour NRC notification complete.

Brief Description: AIR LEAK IDENTIFIED IN THE 3/8" TUBING SUPPLY TO 2MSS*AOV6D

Brief Description: SHORTCOMINGS IN IMPLEMENTING SURVEILLANCE PROGRAM AND TECHNICAL SPECIFICATION APPLICABILITY REQUIREMENTS

Detailed Description: DURING PERFORMANCE OF A TYPE B LEAKRATE FOR THE NMP1 PERSONNEL AIR LOCK WHEN TEST PRESSURE WAS NOT ABLE TO BE ATTAINED AND THE PERFORMANCE OF THE TEST COULD NOT BE COMPLETED, THE SURVEILLANCE WAS PLACED ON HOLD. THE PREVALENT BELIEVE WAS THAT THERE WAS A PROBLEM WITH THE INNER DOOR SEAL ALLOWING AIR FROM INSIDE THE AIRLOCK TO GO PAST THE DOOR SEALS AND INTO THE CONTAINMENT. THOUGH THE BELIEF WAS THAT THERE WAS A SEAL PROBLEM REQUIRING REPLACEMENT AND THE TEST WAS NOT ABLE TO BE SATISFACTORILY COMPLETED THE TEST WAS NOT DECLARED UNSAT IN ACCORDANCE WITH STATION PROCEDURES AND TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS. THIS THEN RESULTED IN THE FAILURE TO ENTER THE RESPECTIVE TECHNICAL SPECIFICATION (TS) LIMITING CONDITION FOR OPERATION (LCO) ACTION AND FAILURE TO ENTERED A ONE-HOUR SHUTDOWN ACTION STATEMENT DURING THE COURSE OF INVESTIGATION AND REPAIR OF THE AIRLOCK. 

SUPPORTING INFORMATION: 
1. MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL WERE NOT ABLE TO ATTAIN THE REQUIRED TEST PRESSURE WHEN TESTING THE PERSONNEL AIR LOCK AT NMP1 INDICATING THAT THERE WAS A SIGNIFICANT LEAK FROM THE AIRLOCK SYSTEM. AS A RESULT THE TEST WAS PUT ON HOLD AND PLANS WERE MADE TO REPLACE THE INNER DOOR SEAL. 
2. THE INNER DOOR SEAL WAS POSTULATED TO BE THE CAUSE OF THE INABILITY TO PRESSURIZE THE AIRLOCK BASED ON HAVING SNOOPED THE OUTER DOOR AND FINDING NO LEAKS COUPLED WITH THE HISTORICAL OE NMP HAS HAD WITH INNER DOOR SEAL PROBLEMS. 
3. NO CR WAS WRITTEN FOR THE DEGRADED CONDITION OF THE PERSONNEL AIRLOCK OR INABILITY TO ATTAIN TEST PRESSURE DURING THE SURVEILLANCE CONDUCTED MAY 15, 2013. THUS NO FORMAL OPERABILITY SCREENING WAS PERFORMED. 
4. BASED ON SOMS LOGS THE OCC STAFF WAS AWARE OF THIS CONDITION AS EARLY AS 1329. THE CONTROL ROOM WAS NOT INFORMED UNTIL 1430. 
5. THERE WERE SOME DISCUSSIONS AMONG SUPERVISION THAT THIS TEST MAY BE A "NO-TEST", HOWEVER THE DECLARATION OF A "NO-TEST" WAS NOT DONE NOR DOCUMENTED. IN ADDITION, THE PROCEDURAL CONDITIONS REQUIRED TO CONSIDER THE FAILED TEST A "NO-TEST" WERE NOT MET. N1-SAT-01 REQUIRES IN PART TO BE CONSIDERED A "NO-TEST", THAT THE COMPLETED PORTION OF THE TEST HAS NOT PRODUCED ANY UNACCEPTABLE RESULTS AND THAT IF THE TEST CANNOT BE COMPLETED, THE REASON IS NOT DUE TO FAILED COMPONENTS WITHIN THE SCOPE OF THE TEST. TYPICAL REASONS THAT ARE NOT CONSIDERED DUE TO COMPONENTS OF THE TEST WOULD BE A FLAWED TEST METHODOLOGY OR DEGRADED TEST EQUIPMENT. THE CONDITIONS ENCOUNTERED DURING THIS SURVEILLANCE TEST WOULD NOT HAVE LEGITIMATELY MET THE REQUIREMENTS NEEDED TO BE ABLE TO CALL IT A "NO-TEST". 
6. THE OUTER AIRLOCK DOOR WAS SUBSEQUENTLY BREACHED ON NIGHTSHIFT TO INSPECT AND REPAIR THE INNER DOOR SEAL. THE INNER DOOR SEAL WAS FOUND TO BE ROLLED FROM ITS PROPER LOCATION AND REPLACED. WHILE THE OUTER DOOR WAS OPEN AND THE INNER DOOR SEAL INOPERABLE THE EFFECT WAS THAT THE AIRLOCK SYSTEM WAS INOPERABLE. THIS CONDITION WAS AN UNRECOGNIZED ONE-HOUR SHUTDOWN LCO ACTION.

IN SUMMARY, THOUGH NUMEROUS SUPERVISORS/GENERAL SUPERVISORS ACROSS SEVERAL DEPARTMENTS AND THE OCC STAFF WERE AWARE OF THE CONDITION, FOLLOW-THROUGH ON THE SURVEILLANCE ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA WAS NOT PERFORMED, THE CORRECTIVE ACTION PROGRAM NOT USED, AND APPROPRIATE TS LCO ACTIONS NEVER ENTERED. THE INNER DOOR WAS FOUND TO BE INOPERABLE UPON INSPECTION AND HAD BEEN FOR SEVERAL HOURS WITHOUT APPROPRIATE ACTIONS BEING TAKEN TO ADDRESS OPERABILITY OR TO DECLARE THE AIRLOCK SYSTEM OR AT LEAST THE INNER DOOR INOPERABLE. 

REFERENCES: 
1. INSTRUMENT SURVEILLANCE PROCEDURE, N1-ISP-201-501, TYPE "B" CONTAINMENT ISOLATION AIRLOCK DOORS LEAK RATE TEST, STEP 10.2.2. 
2. GENERATION ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURE, GAP-SAT-01, SURVEILLANCE TEST PROGRAM, STEP 3.6.4. 
3. NMP1 TECHNICAL SPECIFICATION 4.0.1. 
4. NMP1 TECHNICAL SPECIFICATION BASES

Brief Description: SECONDARY CONTAINMENT DIFFERENTIAL PRESSURE WENT POSITIVE. EOP-SSC WAS ENTERED AFTER DIVISION 2 GTS WAS STARTED AND N2-OP-61B H.6.0 MANUAL CONTROL OF 2GTS*PV5A(B) FOR ABNORMAL ATMOSPHERIC CONDITIONS WAS USED TO PLACE THE CONTROLLER FOR 2GTS*PV5B IN MANUAL AND ITS OUTPUT ADJUSTED TO MAXIMIZE NEGATIVE DIFFERENTIAL PRESSURE. ROUTINE MONITORING DETERMINED THAT THE BUILDING DIFFERENTIAL PRESSURE REACHED MORE POSITIVE THAN THE REQUIRED TECHNICAL SPECIFICATION SPEC OF -0.25 INCHES VACUUM AND ACTUALLY ROSE TO GREATER THAN 0" REQUIRING ENTRY INTO SECONDARY CONTAINMENT CONTROL EMERGENCY OPERATING PROCEDURE. Brief Description: STACK WRGMS HIGH ALARM SETPOINT NONCONSERVATIVE

Detailed Description: ON 5/14/13, CHEMISTRY PERFORMED N2-CSP-RMS-Q308 WRGMS ALARM SETPOINT DETERMINATION ON THE STACK AND VENT WRGMS. DURING PERFORMANCE OF THE PROCEDURE, IT WAS IDENTIFIED THAT THE STACK HIGH ALARM AND ALERT SETPOINTS WERE NONCONSERVATIVE PER STEPS 6.1.11 AND 6.1.12. PER STEP 6.1.11.1, CHEMISTRY SUPERVISION AND THE SM WERE NOTIFIED ON THE NONCONSERVATISM AND THAT THE NOBLE GAS CHANNEL SHOULD BE DECLARED NONFUNCTIONAL. DURING PERFORMANCE OF THE PROCEDURE, THE LAST STACK WRGMS NOBLE GAS GRAB IS USED TO VERIFY THE SETPOINTS ARE CONSERVATIVE. IT APPEARS THAT ON THE LAST GRAB ON 5/1/13, KR-88 RELEASE RATE WAS 2 -3 TIMES RECENT VALUES OF 1-2 UCI/SEC. THIS RELEASE RATE COUPLED WITH A HIGH PLUME SHINE PARAMETER (V) OF 7.04E-3 MREM/YEAR PER UCI/SEC FOR THIS ISOTOPE GAVE A CALCULATED HIGH ALARM SETPOINT, 46500UCI/SEC, WHICH IS LOWER THAN THE CURRENT HIGH ALARM SETPOINTS OF 48000 UCI/SEC. THE ALERT SETPOINT CALCULATED, 465 UCI/SEC WAS ALSO LOWER THAN THE CURRENT ALERT SETPOINT OF 480UCI/SEC. PER STEP 6.1.11.3 I & C IS TO UPDATE WRGMS DATABASE WITH NEW ALARM SETPOINTS.

This IR is for initiating an OPEX level 3 review for ICES report 312951. The purpose of the review is associated with the reportability requirement for loss of air conditioning for the station TSC as described in ICES report 312951. The ICES contained the following information: "At 0613 CDT on 9/6/2014, Technical Support Center roof mounted condensing units were found tripped by operations personnel. An attempt was made to restart both condensing units, neither condensing unit would restart. This caused a loss of Technical Support Center cooling capability. Technical Support Center Air Handling system is in service and required filtration remains available. Wet bulb temperature of the TSC, taken at 0950 CDT is 78.0 degrees F. The cause of the problem was a failure of the motor master controller fuses. The fuses have been replaced. "This event affects an emergency response facility." ENS notification 50431 was performed.

At the EOF/JIC the network communications are currently down, and primary Voice over IP phone communication. Telephones are operating in a backup capacity. Corporate IR 2400249 exists to document any Human Performance issues that may have led to the event.
1B RHR pump tripped during LOP-RH-07, SDC startup. Followed LOA-RH-101 and found DS36 light illuminated. The 1E12-F009 valve closed.

During control rod insertion for shutdown for L1M21, the Unit reactor operator identified that B, D, and F APRMs exceeded their Technical Specification Surveillance Requirement for 2% difference between calculated CTP and APRM readings in the non-conservative direction as part of his critical parameter monitoring. Technical Specifications requires at least 2 operable APRM channels per trip system (there are 2 RPS trip systems, A and B). For this condition, all 3 channels in the B RPS trip system were inoperable. Per LCO 3.3.1.1 Actions Note 2, entry into associated Conditions and Required Actions may be delayed for up to 2 hours. LOS-NR-SR1, APRM gain adjustments were performed to restore operability within 30 minutes. This APRM gain issue is not reportable since no procedural errors, equipment failures, design, analysis, fabrication, construction and/or procedural inadequacies contributed to the inoperability.

The Resident was unable to reach the Unit 1, Unit 2 and Fitzpatrick Main Control Rooms (MCR) for the daily status call via the Emergency Notification System (ENS) line. The Inspector was able to get in touch with the Unit 2 Unit Supervisor via the normal telephone line (315-349-4492). The ENS line was tested and worked as expected when calling from the U2 MCR. Additionally, if called the U2 MCR, the line worked with the exception of no audible ring to notify personnel that a call was incoming. Per discussion, both the Unit 1 and Unit 2 MCR normal telephone line phone numbers (315-349-4392 and 315-349-4492 respectively) have been identified as the primary means of reaching each MCR. Also, the Inspector stated that they would be putting in an IT ticket request for the identified issue. Shift Managers at both units have been informed.

AREVA letter to TMI-1 dated November 25, 2014 (FAB14-00624) determined that the lack of adequate thermal conductivity degradation (TCD) modeling in current AREVA TACO-3/GDTACO computer codes used for TMI-1 LOCA analyses may lead to an under prediction of 393 F in the peak cladding temperature (PCT) during a LOCA. In order to preserve the existing TMI LOCA analysis of record for PCT, AREVA recommended, and TMI has implemented, a 2 kw/ft penalty to LHR limits in Cycle 20 (10/20/14). The penalty has been applied through more restrictive operational imbalance limits. Statements Supporting Operability: Current TMI LOCA analyses have margin that is reduced by a 2 kw/ft penalty that offsets the deficient conductivity degradation modeling. Revised core operating limits for the current TMI-1 operating cycle ensure that PCT remains within the acceptance criteria for emergency core cooling systems (ECCS; <2200 F). In addition, a review of TMI-1 core operation over the past 3 years has shown that TMI has operated within the tighter Fq (LOCA LHR) limits imposed by AREVA on B&W-plants to ensure the current LOCA analysis remains unaffected by the TACO-3 TCD deficiency. Therefore, TMI-1's current LOCA PCT of 1890 F remains valid. Statements Supporting Reportability: The algebraic addition of the thermal conductivity degradation modeling deficiency with LHR penalty applied to TMI-1's current existing LOCA analyses results in a PCT within the required ECCS limits. Therefore TMI-1 continues to operate within the envelope of analyzed conditions. This newly analyzed condition is not an unanalyzed condition that significantly degrades plant safety. This condition does represent a significant change to the TMI-1 ECCS model temperature calculation and must be reported within 30 days.

This IR is being initiated to meet the requirements of LS-AA-1003, "NRC Inspection Preparation and Response." Per the procedure, once an NRC inspection report is issued with a Finding, Violation, or Unresolved Issue (URI) the NRC Coordinator is responsible for initiating an IR that requires the responsible organization to review the NRC violation and ensure that the station response and corrective actions properly address the violation. From the NRC 3rd Quarter 2014 Integrated Inspection Report (2014-004) issued on November 13, 2014:

Introduction:
The inspectors identified a finding of very low safety significance (Green) and an associated NCV when licensee personnel failed to adhere to Operability Determination Process standards after identifying a non-conforming condition that had the potential to impact the operability of the UHS.

Description:
On June 24, 2014, the licensee identified that station procedures used to address a failure of the Braidwood cooling lake dike did not include steps to secure nonsafety-related pumps, including circulating water pumps and non-essential service water pumps, that take a suction from the UHS and discharge to a location outside of the UHS. Securing these nonsafety-related pumps was a design assumption that was specified in the UFSAR and supported in an associated calculation. Following the discovery of this issue, the licensee generated IR 1674557, "Question on UHS License Amendment Request Impact on Pumps," which documented that Abnormal Operating Procedure BwOA ENV.3, "Braidwood Cooling Lake Low Level," did not direct nonsafety-related pumps that take a suction from the UHS and discharge outside of the UHS to be secured following a dike failure. During the review of this IR, on June 25, 2014, the inspectors noted that the "Operability" section of IR 1674557 was left blank, and the "Reviewed" section stated, in part, that the issue was "a process issue regarding future planned actions." The inspectors concluded from their review of IR 1674557 that although the title of IR 1674557 suggested that this issue only impacted future planned actions, the context discussed within the IR documented a condition that could adversely impact current UHS operability. As a result, the inspectors promptly discussed this issue with the Operations Shift Manager, who was not aware of any operability concerns associated with the issue or station actions to address the issue. Later, during that shift, the Shift Manager determined that the issue was reportable as an "Unanalyzed Condition." On June 25, 2014, IR1675291, "Unanalyzed Condition Identified During IR 1674557 Response," was generated by the Engineering department. The licensee also implemented a Standing Order that included interim guidance. 

The Standing Order stated, in part, that:
"To preserve the UHS function in the event of cooling pond dike failure, the following guidance is provided until 0/1/2BwOA ENV.3 is revised. Braidwood Operations will take the following actions in the event of a dike failure and lake level is just above 590' (1ft. on 0LI.CW041): 
- Trip both Units 
- Secure all circulation water pumps 
- Secure all non-essential service water pumps by placing them in pull to lock 
- Secure all running main fire pumps (jockey pumps are excluded) 
- Perform the actions of 0/1/2BwOA ENV.3 and the Braidwood Cooling Pond Safety Emergency Plan"

The inspectors noted that IR 1674557 included a preliminary determination that operation of a single nonsafety-related service water pump at full flow would deplete the UHS in approximately 3.6 days and did not meet the 30 day mission time required by design. However, the inspectors also noted that the licensee's operability discussion in the IR stated, "The UHS meets its surveillance requirements for minimum level, maximum temperature, and maximum bottom level. Limiting Condition for Operation 3.7.9 UHS is met and the UHS is operable." The inspectors expressed a concern that the operability assessment did not specifically address the 30 day mission time discussed in the IR. 

The inspectors also noted that Step 2.14 of OP.AA.108.115 stated, in part, that, "In order to be considered operable, structures, systems and components must be capable of performing safety functions specified by its design, within the required range of design physical conditions, initiation times and mission times." Contrary to what the procedure specified, the licensee's operability assessment did not address mission time. Following conversations with site personnel, the licensee updated their operability assessment to reflect that even though procedural guidance did not explicitly reflect the assumptions in the UHS analysis in that nonsafety-related pumps were not directed to be secured, the UHS would still be able to perform its safety function since operators would recognize the problem and take actions to secure the nonsafety-related pumps. When questioned by the inspectors on what would prompt the operators to take action to secure nonsafety-related pumps, what procedures would be used, and how these actions ensured the specified safety function would be met, the licensee was unable to provide further information other than what had already been presented. In July 2014, the licensee completed a past operability evaluation, which provided the bases for UHS TS operability consistent with the definition of operability in the site-specific TSs. In the evaluation, the licensee concluded that based on the breach size evaluated in station calculations of record it would take approximately 16 hours to drain the lake level from 594 feet to 591 feet 10 inches. The UHS TS minimum level was 590 feet. At 591 feet 10 inches, minimum submergence to satisfy net positive suction head requirements for the nonsafety-related service water pumps would not be met. The vendor for the pump specified that at that point a vortex could form, which could introduce air into the pump. The vendor also specified that unless the pump became air bound, the pump would continue to operate, but with reduced performance. Based upon this information, the licensee did not predict at what lake level the pump would cease to operate. The licensee concluded that mechanical pump vibrations, fluctuations in pump discharge pressure, and variations in motor currents would likely require that an operator trip the nonsafety-related service water pumps to prevent damage before 590' lake level was reached.

The inspectors reviewed the licensee's past operability determination, timeline of events, and the Operability Determination Procedure, and identified the following examples where the procedure standard was not followed:
- Step 4.1.2 of OP.AA.108.115, stated that, "If the originator or supervisor identifies any potential operability or reportability issues, the originator or supervisor shall personally contact Operations Shift Management of the affected facility/unit and discuss the issue." However, upon discovery on June 24, 2014, that nonsafety-related pumps would not be secured following a lake dike failure, although this was assumed in design basis calculations, licensee personnel did not inform Operations Shift Management. The licensee documented this issue in IR 1681326 "Untimely Notification to Shift Manager of a Potential Plant Issue."
- Step 2.14 of OP.AA.108.115, stated, in part, that, "In order to be considered operable, structures, systems and components must be capable of performing safety functions specified by its design, within the required range of design physical conditions, initiation times and mission times." However, the licensee's operability assessment discussed in IR 1674557 and IR 1675291 did not address mission time even though Engineering had determined that the identified issue had the potential to affect mission time. The operability assessment specified that operators would recognize the problem and take actions to ensure that the UHS would still be able to perform its safety function and meet all design basis requirements. However, the licensee did not adequately consider what would prompt the operators to take action, what procedures they would use, and how the actions correlated to meeting the specified safety function.
- Step 4.5.2.5 of OP.AA.108.115 stated, in part, that, "The technical acceptability and effectiveness of a compensatory measure with respect to the degraded or non-conforming condition and the affected structures, systems and components should be evaluated. The evaluation should also consider the effects of the compensatory measures to other aspects of the facility." However, when instituting the Standing Order, no evaluation was performed even though the Standing Order met the procedural definition of what constituted a compensatory measure. 

The licensee entered the issues described above into their CAP as IR1674557 and IR 1675291. Corrective actions for this issue included revising procedures to secure nonsafety-related pumps upon reaching a low lake level condition consistent with plant design calculations, and addressing the untimely notification of the shift.

Analysis:
The inspectors determined that the failure to adhere to the Operability Determination Process standard outlined in OP.AA.108.115, Revision 13, during the evaluation of a non-conforming condition that affected the UHS was a performance deficiency. The inspectors determined that the performance deficiency was more than minor in accordance with IMC 0612, Appendix B, "Issue Screening," because the issue was associated with the Design Control attribute of the Mitigating Systems Cornerstone and adversely affected the cornerstone objective of ensuring the availability, reliability, and capability of systems that respond to initiating events to prevent undesirable consequences (i.e., core damage). Specifically, based on the analysis of record at the time of discovery, there was reasonable doubt that the UHS could meet its mission time of 30 days. The inspectors determined the finding could be evaluated using the SDP in accordance with IMC 0609, "Significance Determination Process," Attachment 0609.04, "Initial Characterization of Findings," dated June 19, 2012, and Appendix A, "The Significance Determination Process for Findings At-Power," Exhibit 2, "Mitigating Systems Screening Questions," dated June 19, 2012. The inspectors determined that the finding did not result in the confirmed loss of operability, and therefore the finding screened as having very low safety significance (Green). The inspectors concluded that this finding had a cross-cutting aspect in the Conservative Bias component of the Human Performance cross-cutting area because the licensee failed to use conservative assumptions in their decision-making when analyzing the operability of the UHS. Specifically, Operations did not request a documented evaluation to support understanding why the UHS was operable, and verify that their assumptions regarding operator actions were feasible (H.14).

Enforcement:
Criterion V, "Instructions, Procedures, and Drawings," requires, in part, that activities affecting quality be prescribed and accomplished by instructions, procedures, and drawings appropriate to the circumstances, and shall be accomplished in accordance with those instructions, procedures, and drawings. The licensee implemented the operability determination process (an activity affecting quality) using procedure OP.AA.108.115, "Operability Determination Procedure," Revision 13. Step 2.14 of OP.AA.108.115 stated, in part: "In order to be considered operable structures, systems and components must be capable of performing safety functions specified by its design, within the required range of design, physical conditions, initiation times, and mission times." Step 4.1.2 of OP.AA.108.115 stated: "If the originator or supervisor identifies any potential operability or reportability issues, the originator or supervisor shall personally contact Operations Shift Management of the affected facility/unit and discuss the issue." Step 4.1.3 of OP.AA.108.115 stated: "Route the issue for immediate review by Operations Shift Management when immediate actions are required by operations." Step 4.5.2.5 of OP.AA.108.115 stated, in part: "The technical acceptability and effectiveness of a Compensatory Measure with respect to the degraded or non-conforming condition and the affected structures, systems and components should be evaluated. The evaluation should also consider the effects of the compensatory measures on other aspects of the facility." Contrary to the above, on June 25, 2014, following the discovery of a non-conforming condition in the UHS, licensee personnel failed to notify the shift management upon discovery of a potential operability concern, failed to adequately assess operability based on information provided by Engineering which specified that the condition could lead to not meeting the mission time, and failed to evaluate compensatory measures as required by procedure OP.AA.108.115. Corrective actions for this issue included revising procedures to secure nonsafety-related pumps prior to reaching a low lake level condition consistent with plant design calculations, and addressing the untimely notification of the shift management. Because this violation was of very low safety significance and it was entered into the licensee's CAP as IR 1674557 and IR 1675291, this violation is being treated as an NCV, consistent with Section 2.3.2 of the NRC Enforcement Policy (NCV 05000456/2014004.02; 05000457/2014004.02, Multiple Failures to Follow Operability Evaluation Process Following Discovery of a Non-Conforming Condition in the Ultimate Heat Sink).

SITE: Three Mile Island
SUBJECT: OFFSITE NOTIFICATION DUE TO EMERGENCY SIREN INADVERTENTLY SOUNDING; OE Number 50654
SUMMARY: At 1150 EST, the Shift Manager was notified that TMI Three Mile Island emergency plan siren 128 was inadvertently sounding. This siren is no longer alarming. Repairs to the siren have been completed. The licensee has notified the NRC Resident Inspector. The licensee notified applicable state and local authorities.
At 0417 on 12-17-2014 the AMP 200 that is set up for backup monitor of the U2 main vent stack (10meter line) alarmed and peaked at 60R/hr. About 3 minutes later it returned to reading 0 mR/hr.

During routine trending of radiochemistry data, Reactor Engineering identified trends in Unit 2 which would indicate the presence of one or more failed fuel pins. Based on the relevant isotopes, magnitudes, and durations, the nature of this failure is consistent with that of the late cycle, peripheral low power, grid-to-rod-fretting failures we've seen at CCNPP in recent operating cycles. The Xe133/Xe135 to Kr88/Xe133 ratio is divergent which indicates the presence of failed fuel. I-131 remains steady with Xe-133 trending upward; both indicate the presence of low power leaker(s) indicative of the type seen at CCNPP for several years. It cannot be determined from the data if the failures are in the 24 Westinghouse Turbo assemblies or the 24 Areva HTP assemblies. This is an Action Level 1 failure per NF-AA-430 (the least severe level). No Tech Spec related limits (including DEI) are challenged. This condition does not result in principal safety barriers being seriously degraded or operating in an unanalyzed condition that significantly degrades plant safety.

2LWS-DSP408, the radwaste computer crashed at 1530. The crash took away all level indication for all tanks in radwaste and all control functions for every pump and every valve the computer controlled. Alarms that showed up on the alarm typer are as follows; EVENT HDS TRIGGER #2, #3, #4, #5, #6, #7, #9, #10 and #12, along with a message displaying DDC ANL OUT FAIL LOOP 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 12, and 13.

At 08:12, CMO entered 0A VC Plenum to obtain vibration data on 0VC02CA (0A VC Return Fan). At 0923, the 0A VC M/U filter/fan and charcoal absorber was started per BOP VC-5 for pending 2B AF pump ASME run surveillance. Upon startup, it was discovered that 0VC312Y (Outside air intake) was open and 0VC25Y (turbine building intake) was closed. This was an unexpected condition and 0VC312Y should have been closed and 0VC25Y should have been open. Operators verified the M/U filter select switch was in Auto as expected. At 09:39, the HELB Detection Panel (0VC01JE) red light was lit indicating HELB switch actuation had occurred. After initial troubleshooting, it was discovered that the most likely cause of the HELB actuation was from the 0A VC Return fan vibration data gathering when the plenum door was opened causing pressure transients. At 10:08, the 0A VC M/U fan was shut-down and the HELB signal was reset. The 0A VC M/U fan and filter were placed back online and the dampers operated as expected (0VC312Y Closed and OVC25Y Open). Currently both VC trains are operable with both train's HELB signals verified Reset. Engineering provided the following information regarding the VC HELB actuation signal. Once a HELB activation (or test) is in place, the detection system will NOT allow the TB damper to open until MANUALLY reset. An SI or high radiation signal will NOT override the HELB detection circuitry automatically. There are NO logical or electrical cross-ties between the circuitry for the VC HELB Detection system and any other HELB detection or protection system. Electrically, the HELB detection system for the 0A VC train is fed from the ESF Division 11, 120V instrument bus distribution panel 111 (1IP01J). 0B VC train HELB detection is fed from ESF Div 12, 120V instrument bus distribution panel 114 (1IP04J). Loss of power to the detection panel will be interpreted as an initiating event and activate the protection relays.
NRC notified via ENS #50792 of the U2 Reactor SCRAM due to a FWLC transient. This event is reportable per LS-AA-1110 Section SAF 1.5, 1.6, and 1.7. The NRC Resident Inspector has been notified.

The Backup Gamma Spec computer was found "off" as the result of an unknown hardware issue. The Primary computer remains functional. Gamma spec is used as EP equipment currently to monitor Fuel Clad Threshold an FC.1 EAL (DEI-131 > 300 uCi/g) under EP-AA-1007, Addendum 3. The Primary computer can still be used to count samples but the system reliability (i.e. "2 out of 2") as required by the original design is reduced. Therefore, if the Primary computer is lost, the Site can no longer declare analyze reactor coolant for monitoring threshold FC.1. However, Chemistry does have CY-PB-130-5001 to provide alternate means of determination with other radiation monitors (e.g. hand-held portable ion-chambers). This procedure can be used as a Compensatory Measure if the primary and back up computers were non-functional. Prior discussion recommends that this be placed on the Priority Work List (PWL). Additional Background: Chemistry has disagreed with Corporate EP's assessment that gamma spec is "EP/ Plant Equipment" from interpretation of NEI 99-01 by EP-AA-1007 that a direct coolant measurement is the only means of assessment because many other real-time measurements (i.e. DWVRM, other area rad monitors) that would indicate severe core damage well before a coolant sample is taken to determine that an FG1 is reached.

CONDITION DESCRIPTION: H03D SITE: North Anna Power Station Unit 1 SUBJECT: Inadvertent Loss of Vital Instrumentation During Maintenance Due to Personnel Error . ICES #: 3382014002 SUMMARY: On December 10, 2014, at 1344 hours, two channels of the Unit 1 Refueling Water Storage Tank (RWST) level instrumentation were inadvertently removed from service at the same time during maintenance. Operations personnel responded by entering abnormal procedure 1-AP-3, Loss of Vital Instrumentation. Additionally, Technical Specification (TS) 3.0.3 was entered due to two channels being inoperable that affect Recirculation Spray (RS) pump auto-start logic. Had a Containment Depressurization Actuation (CDA) occurred during this time, accident mitigation may have been impacted. At 1356 hours, both level indications returned to normal. At 1417 hours, Channel II was declared operable and TS 3.0.3 was cleared. At 1439 hours, Channel I was declared operable and TS Actions were cleared. The health and safety of the public were not affected by this event. DETAILED ISSUE DESCRIPTION: On December 10, 2014, at 1100 hours with Unit 1 (U1) in Mode 1 at 100 percent power, station technicians commenced scheduled periodic channel calibrations of level transmitters for U1 Refueling Water Storage Tank (EIIS System - BP, Component - TK) Level Channel I instrument loop (1-QS-L-100C) and Channel II instrument loop (1-QSL- 100D). A pre-job brief was performed emphasizing one channel instrument loop calibration at a time. Initial job preparations were established for Channel I instrument loop (1-QS-L-100C) calibration. Test equipment was staged in the instrument rack room and at the U1 Refueling Water Storage Tank (RWST) level transmitter (EIIS Component - LT). The lead technician proceeded to the Main Control Room (EIIS System - NA) to brief the Operations Senior Reactor Operator (SRO). Required procedure step signatures were obtained and permission was granted to perform the Channel II calibration. At 1258 hours Operations entered the 72 hour action statement for Technical Specification (TS) for performance of the Channel II instrument loop (1-QS-L-100D) calibration. Upon arrival to the instrument rack room the lead technician discovered Operations signatures were made in the test procedure for 1-QS-L-100D. At this time the test equipment was moved from the cabinet for 1-QS-L-100C to the cabinet for 1-QS-L-100D. When it was identified that the procedure was for the 1-QS-L-100D task, the lead technician did not specifically communicate the change to the field team. Subsequently, 1-QS-L-100D was removed from service and placed in test. The lead technician remained in the instrument rack room while two technicians proceeded to the RWST level transmitter for field work activities. At this point technicians simultaneously verified they were on transmitter 1-QS-L-100C using the working copy of the procedure and began isolating and draining the level transmitter. At 1344 hours, RWST Channel I instrument loop (1-QS-L-100C) level indication failed low with Channel II instrument loop (1-QS-L-100D) level transmitter having already been removed from service. Operations personnel responded by entering abnormal procedure 1-AP-3, Loss of Vital Instrumentation. Additionally, TS 3.0.3 was entered due to two channels inoperable that affect Recirculation Spray (RS) pump (EIIS System - BE, Component - P) auto-start capability. At 1356 hours, both level indications returned to normal. At 1417 hours, Channel II was declared operable and TS 3.0.3 was cleared. Had a Containment Depressurization Actuation (CDA) occurred during this time, accident mitigation may have been impacted. At 1439 hours, Channel I was declared operable. CAUSE: The cause of the event was due to personnel error. Station technicians failed to assess risk associated with the RWST level channel calibration tasks. Inattention as a result of repetition and/or becoming complacent and overconfident with the job task caused the team not to use human performance tools to mitigate the errors. Had the correct rigor for the task been addressed the event could have been prevented. CORRECTIVE ACTION: Channel II instrument loop (1-QS-L-100D) was returned to service by procedure and verified, a channel check was completed on the Main Control Room (MCR) board to verify proper indication. The TS Action of 3.0.3 was cleared. Channel I instrument loop (1-QS-L-100C) was returned to service by procedure and verified, a channel check was completed on the MCR board to verify proper indication. The TS Actions of 3.3.2.d and 3.3.2.i were cleared. ADDITIONAL CORRECTIVE ACTIONS Completed interim actions included removing the qualifications of the individuals involved until remediation was conducted; performed a stand down to ensure lessons learned are integrated into the daily work activities and department standards and expectations were reinforced; and supervisors have increased oversight for pre-job briefs and are maintaining field presence to ensure high risk, error likely tasks are briefed adequately, barriers and defenses used and standards and expectations reinforced.

On March 26, 2015 Exelon will perform an upgrade to their digital access cross connect system (DACS). This upgrade will involve taking 431 nuclear and Com-Ed circuits off line for a period of 4 hours. This outage will involve the following EP communications systems at the Simulator, MCR, TSC, OSC and EOF: Zion: NARS and Director's Hotline Braidwood, Dresden and LaSalle, Quad Cities, Byron: NARS (Will County Sheriff's Office), Director's Hotline, Technical Hotline, Operations Status Line and EP siren data circuits Clinton: Director's Hotline and Operations Status Line Morrison Alternate Facility for Quad Cities Station: FAX line, OSC Director telephone, Security Coordinator telephone and Logistics Coordinator/General Use telephone. All telephone systems have viable proceduralized compensatory measures in place which include the use of analog telephones to completed required communications. The siren data circuits affected are circuits that are used to monitor the health of the sirens and the siren network. A cellular back-up system is in place to perform the monitoring activity throughout the outage. The monitoring of the siren network is the responsibility of the siren vendor. This outage does not affect the ability of the off-site response organizations to sound the sirens in a nuclear emergency.

ERV-121 failed to actuate during step 3 of task 70 of WO#92990043. Observations: Technicians in the field observed no actuation of ERV-121. The control room operators attempted to stroke ERV-121 from auto to open. The ERV failed to stroke. The red "open" light did not illuminate, and when the control switch was returned to "auto" the blue continuity light didn't light. The green close light re-illuminated. The current status of the switch is in auto and the green light is on. The blue continuity light isn't on.

In 2Q14 NRC issued NCV 12-012-01 on 05/01/4, concerning the Exelon Fleet had provided information on the status of its decommissioning funding that was not complete and accurate in all material respects, when it submitted the decommissioning funding status (DFS) reports. In multiple instances, the amount reported was a discounted value that was less than the minimum required amount specified. The submittal of incomplete and inaccurate material information was contrary to regulations concerning how Exelon was calculating the required decommissioning funds, therefore this issue was identified as a Severity Level IV violation. (IRs 1469921, 1661844) In 4Q14 NRC issued NCV 14-005-02 on 01/29/15, The inspectors identified a Severity Level IV non-cited violation when licensee personnel failed to submit a report required for a loss of emergency assessment capability when an unplanned loss of the station seismograph was identified. (IRs 2392264, 2415243) This results in two (2) Traditional Enforcement Severity Level IV violations in the same area, "Impeding the Regulatory Process," in this rolling 12 month period. Based on these two violations, per LS-AA-1006, NRC Cross-Cutting Analysis and Trending, Step 4.6.4, an IR and Regulatory Analysis are to be performed if two or more Severity Level IV Traditional Violations occur in the same area during any 12 month period. These two violations have no common cause other than they are both Traditional Severity Level IV violations. Note: There are no operability or reportability issues related to this IR, and there are no plant equipment issues concerning this IR. This IR is issued for documentation purposes to perform a Regulatory Analysis related to these two NRC Traditional Severity Level IV violations.

TMI reviewed the current and past seismic monitor operability following receipt of action from IR 2473472. Currently there are no known operability or functionality concerns with the seismic monitor. A review of seismic monitoring issues over the past three years found one instance (IR 1398226 dated 8/7/12) in which the seismic monitor computer would not have alarmed an OBE. However, the equipment would have continued to monitor, store, and trigger alarm PRF-1-2, Threshold Seismic Condition, during the occurrence of an actual event. Reportability: While Exelon procedural direction allowed the use of offsite sources to obtain seismic data when the seismic monitor is incapable of assessing emergency plan Emergency Action Levels (EALs), this was not explicitly referenced in the approved EALs. The loss of assessment capability is reportable to the NRC within 8 hours of discovery. This report is required as an event that occurred within 3 years of the date of discovery.

OPXR - BROWNS FERRY OE - 50925 - OFFSITE TRANSPORTATION OF CONTAMINATED AND INJURED INDIVIDUAL Power ReactorEvent Number: 50925 Facility: BROWNS FERRY Region: 2 State: AL Unit: ] 2] ] RX Type: 1] GE-4,2] GE-4,3] GE-4 NRC Notified By: WESLEY CONKLE HQ OPS Officer: JOHN SHOEMAKER Notification Date: 03/25/2015 Notification Time: 21:37 ET] Event Date: 03/25/2015 Event Time: 14:57 CDT] Last Update Date: 03/25/2015 Emergency Class: NON EMERGENCY Person (Organization): DAVID AYRES (R2DO) UnitSCRAM CodeRX CRITInitial PWRInitial RX ModeCurrent PWRCurrent RX Mode 2NN0Refueling0Refueling Event Text 50925 - OFFSITE TRANSPORTATION OF CONTAMINATED AND INJURED INDIVIDUAL On March 25, 2015, at approximately 1413 CDT, a Browns Ferry Nuclear (BFN) employee fell approximately 6 feet and sustained a laceration to his forehead and potential other injuries. The individual had been working in the Unit 2 drywell, which is a contaminated area. The individual was able to be removed from his anti-contamination clothing prior to leaving the Radiological Controlled Area (RCA). The individual was surveyed by a Radiation Protection (RP) technician and had slight contamination (150 cpm counts per minute]) on his forehead in the area near the laceration. No survey of his back was performed due to being on a stretcher. At 1457 CDT, the individual was transported to an off-site medical facility. A BFN RP technician accompanied the individual to the hospital. Subsequent survey of the individual at the medical facility determined that no other areas of contamination existed. The individual was successfully decontaminated at the medical facility during initial treatment and all locations have been free released. All contaminated materials have been properly controlled. The NRC Resident Inspector has been notified. The individual was transported to Decatur Morgan General Hospital in Decatur, Alabama for decontamination and follow-up medical treatment. PLANT OE CONTACT: JOHN MORRIS 256-614-7195

It was noted over the entire quarter that the outfall was frozen and/or filled/covered in snow. As of 3/31/15, the outfall remains hidden by several feet of naturally occurring snow, and photographs documenting this condition are stored on the Ginna "S" drive.

While conducting a visual inspection of the E42 (1806) cubicle for EOC of the App. R mod wiring, the transfer switch was found to have 14 gauge wire installed for the fuses, rather than the expected 8 gauge wire. Similar issue has been identified in IR 2465711 and evaluated in AR A1991702-01.

Clinton Power Station (CPS) has completed a review of the station seismic monitor performance. The CPS seismic monitor laptop is currently operable; however, this review identified 3 times in the last 3 years that the seismic monitoring laptop was declared non-functional such that the capability to perform an EAL assessment in accordance with the Radiological Emergency Plan Annex would be adversely impacted. A loss of the seismic laptop computer prevents active seismic data from processing through the central recording unit and will not alarm in the main control room. The seismic monitor laptop became non-functional and unresponsive on the following dates: 1) Jan 4, 2013 2) July 19, 2013 3) Nov 2, 2014 The loss of assessment capability is reportable to the NRC within 8 hours of discovery. The NRC Resident inspector has been notified.

SITE: HATCH SUBJECT: UNANALYZED CONDITION DUE TO DISCOVERY OF DEGRADED FIRE BARRIER WALLS ICES #: Significant Event Number: 50351 SUMMARY/DETAILED ISSUE DESCRIPTION: During a fire inspection activity involving inspection of fire walls that serve as Appendix R barriers, degradation of some fire walls was identified that was sufficient to prevent these walls from meeting Appendix R requirements as 3-hour fire barriers. In the event of a postulated fire in the affected areas, both safe shutdown paths on the affected unit could be compromised. Compensatory measures were already in place in accordance with the plant's Fire Hazard Analysis (FHA) as a result of previous conditions involving degraded penetrations in these same fire areas. The presence of the compensatory measures in addition to automatic fire detection in these fire areas ensure that the safe shutdown paths are preserved until the degraded conditions can be corrected. The nonconforming conditions observed for the affected penetrations and fire barriers were identified as affecting both safe shutdown paths for Unit 1. Compensatory measures were already in place in accordance with the plant's Fire Hazard Analysis (FHA) as a result of previous conditions involving degraded barriers in the same fire areas and will remain in place until the fire barriers are repaired. The presence of the compensatory measures in addition to portable fire protection equipment located in adjacent areas ensures the safe shutdown paths are preserved until the degraded conditions are repaired. The expanded scope inspection activity is continuing, and this and any subsequent similar condition(s) that meets the reporting requirements will be included in an ENS Update Report as required and will be documented in a revised LER at the end of the inspection activity.

The inspectors identified a Green NCV of Technical Specification (TS) Limiting Condition for Operation (LCO) 3. 7.5, "Component Cooling (CC) System," and 3.0.3, because Exelon operated Units 1 and 2 CC systems in an unanalyzed condition on 18 occasions and operated in a condition prohibited by TS on two occasions within the last three years. The inspectors determined that Exelon's operation with both CC loops inoperable and the subsequent failure to place the unit in Mode 5 within 37 hours as required by TS is a performance deficiency. Exelon entered this issue into their corrective action program (CAP) as IR02439913. Exelon's immediate corrective actions included the submission of event notification (EN) 50752 and prohibiting operation of the CC system in a configuration outside of that specified in the TS bases while further analysis was conducted. The inspectors reviewed IMC 0612, Appendix B, "Issue Screening," and determined the issue is more than minor because it is associated with the configuration control attribute of the Mitigating Systems cornerstone and adversely affected the cornerstone objective to ensure the availability, reliability, and capability of systems that respond to initiating events to prevent undesirable consequences. Specifically, the station operated with two CC loops unable to perform their safety function of maintaining component cooling heat exchanger (CCHX) outlet temperatures at or below 120F. In accordance with IMC 0609, Attachment 4, "Initial Characterization of Findings," issued on June 19, 2012, and IMC 0609, Appendix A, "The Significance Determination Process (SDP) for Findings At-Power," Exhibit 2, "Mitigating Systems Screening Questions," issued on June 19, 2012, the inspectors determined that a detailed risk evaluation was necessary to disposition the significance of this finding because the finding represented a loss of a system and/or function. The detailed risk evaluation considered that the deficiency could have, under some ultimate heat sink temperature conditions, resulted in the CCHX outlet temperatures exceeding the design analyzed limit of 120F following the recirculation actuation signal (RAS) during a loss of coolant accident (LOCA). The Senior Reactor Analyst performed a bounding significance determination by conservatively assuming a complete loss of safety function for the CCHXs for the applicable limited exposure time. Emergency operating procedures also had contingencies for a postulated loss of the CC function which directed the re-alignment of a containment spray (CS) pump to ensure adequate safety injection is maintained. This evaluation determined the issue was of very low safety significance (Green). The inspectors determined that the finding has a cross-cutting aspect in the area of Human Performance, Design Margins, because Exelon did not operate and maintain equipment within design margins. Specifically, Exelon operated the CC system outside its design safety-related specification, resulting in an operating condition prohibited by TS.

SITE: HARRIS 
SUBJECT: UNANALYZED CONDITION DUE TO OPEN HIGH ENERGY LINE BREAK DOORS 
ICES #: Event Number: 51178 

SUMMARY: On June 16, 2015 at 1145 EDT while in Mode 1 at 100% power steady-state conditions, two fire doors between the Reactor Auxiliary building (RAB) and steam tunnel were opened under administrative controls to support maintenance. These doors are credited in high energy line break equipment qualification and internal flooding analyses and opening of the doors is not addressed in the analyses. A high energy line break in the steam tunnel with the doors open could result in equipment in the RAB experiencing high temperature, pressure, or humidity beyond conditions analyzed for equipment qualification which has the potential to render redundant safety-related equipment inoperable. "The event was determined to be reportable on June 24, 2015 at approximately 1550 EDT]. During that reportability evaluation, it was determined that the doors may have been in a similar condition multiple times in the May-June time frame. 

"There was no adverse impact to public health and safety or to plant employees."

SITE: ARKANSAS NUCLEAR SUBJECT: UPDATE - SEISMIC MONITOR DECLARED NON FUNCTIONAL ICES #: Event Number: 51184 

SUMMARY: This notification is being made as an event that will result in a major loss of emergency assessment capability, offsite response capability, or offsite communications capability (e.g. significant portion of control room indication, Emergency Notification System or offsite notification system.) The emergency preparedness plan requires seismic monitoring instruments to diagnose an earthquake for emergency action levels (EAL) HU6 (Natural or destructive phenomena affecting Protected Area) and HA6 (Natural and destructive phenomena affecting Vital Areas). At 2149 CST on June 26, 2015, the ACS-8003 seismic monitor was declared non-functional due to having a fault light indicated on the C529 seismic cabinet. The ACS-8001 seismic monitor had previously been declared non-functional due to the same condition. With these 2 monitors out of service the seismic alarm capability is not available. ANO procedures provide compensatory measures of using offsite sources to obtain seismic data. The NRC Resident Inspector has been notified. 

* * * UPDATE ON 6/28/15 AT 1552 EDT FROM KENYON MCNEAILL TO DONG PARK * * *
On 6/28/15 at 1232 CDT, batteries have been replaced in ACS-8001 and ACS-8003 seismic monitors. Both monitors have been restored to a fully functional status. Seismic alarm capability is restored and Emergency Assessment Capability has been restored. The licensee will notify the NRC Resident Inspector. Notified R4DO (Campbell).

During the Liquid Penetrant examination on the weld build up for CRDM Penetration 31, two indications were identified during the examination that exceed ASME Section III criteria. The first is a 9/32" rounded indication located at 270 degrees, at the intersection of the J-Groove Weld buildup and Nozzle buildup transition of the head to penetration. The second is a 0.10" linear indication located on the vertical portion of the penetration at 270 degrees and 3/16" down the penetration from the intersection of the J-Groove Weld buildup and Nozzle buildup transition. 0 Degrees is located at the outermost portion of the penetration on the flange side. The transition is the point where the vertical portion of the penetration meets the horizontal area of the reactor head. These two indications are documented in NDE report number 2015-240.

MCR received unexpected alarm 5009-2A, Accl Excded Seis Sw/Oper Bas Earthqke, and 5009-3A Activated Seismic Recorder. Entered CPS 4301.01, Earthquake Off-normal. Stationed the Incident Assessor. Verified with Security no ground motion was felt onsite. USGS Earthquake website shows no seismic events at this same time. Contacted Braidwood Station, LaSalle Stations, Callaway, Duane Arnold and the National Earthquake Information Service (Don), no ground motion or seismic alarms were received or noted. Appendix A: Event Validation Display section A.2 performance revealed 1VT-EM005 Vert: -0.4170, E/W: -0.3006, and N/S: -0.3125 values exceeded both OBE and SSE Values. Area Operators were dispatched to perform a walk down of plant areas. All indications in the MCR appear normal for normal full power operation. 15:15 -- Per Appendix A Event Validation Criteria, the event is being classified as VALID per 4301.01 Earthquake Appendix A. (Step A.1.1 - If only 1 accelerometer triggered, and the Seismic Switch 1VT-EM014 alarmed, Then the alarm shall be treated as VALID until detailed Engineering analyses determines otherwise). However, based on the above information, declared Seismic Instrumentation INOPERABLE. Entered the following ORM Action Statement: - ORM 2.2.7 Action 3.2.7.A, Restore Seismic Instrumentation within 30 days or initiate a condition report.
