This IR is being initiated to meet the requirements of LS-AA-1003, "NRC Inspection Preparation and Response." Per the procedure, once an NRC inspection report is issued with a Finding, Violation, or Unresolved Issue (URI) the NRC Coordinator is responsible for initiating an IR that requires the responsible organization to review the NRC violation and ensure that the station response and corrective actions properly address the violation. NRC Triennial Fire Protection Inspection Report (2015-007): .6 Circuit Analyses b. Findings Failure to Ensure Circuits Associated with Pressurizer Power Operated Relief Valve Block Valves were Free of Fire Damage Introduction: The inspectors identified a finding of very low safety significance (Green), and an associated Non-Cited Violation (NCV) of the Braidwood Station Operating License for the licensee's failure to ensure that the safe shutdown capability was independent of the fire area and free of fire damage. Specifically, in the event of a fire in the control room, cable spreading rooms, or electrical cable penetration areas the circuits associated with the Pressurizer Power Operated Relief Valve (PORV) block valves, which were relied upon to safely shutdown the plant, may be affected and not available. Description: The pressurizer is equipped with two types of devices for pressure relief, pressurizer safety relief valves and PORVs. The PORVs are direct current (DC) solenoid controlled air operated valves that are controlled to open at a specific set pressure when the pressurizer pressure increases and close when the pressurizer pressure decreases. The PORVs may also be manually operated from the control room. These valves provide the primary overpressure protection of the Reactor Coolant System (RCS) during most modes of operation. Each PORV discharge line has a normally open motor operated block valve immediately upstream of the PORV itself. The block valves are used to isolate the PORVs in case of excessive leakage or a stuck open PORV. Both PORV discharge lines are routed to the pressurizer relief tank (PRT). The PRT is sized to accept and quench the PORV discharge only for a limited time. Certain post-fire scenarios may require or result in a discharge for a longer time. If a PORV were to discharge to the PRT for a sufficiently long time the PRT pressure would rise to the rupture disc relief pressure, and the PRT contents would be released to the containment atmosphere. The licensee identified in the Braidwood Station safe shutdown analysis (SSA) that the PORVs and their associated block valves formed a high-low pressure interface between the RCS and low-pressure systems. A detailed evaluation of the high-low pressure interface of these valves was provided in subsection 2.4.3.2 of the SSA. Section 2.4.3.2 indicated that the Division 12(22) PORV and block valves both had control cables in the main control room and in two of the lower cable spreading rooms. The SSA stated that should a fire in any of these zones cause the spurious opening of the PORVs, coincident with control circuit damage to the block valves, the block valves could still be closed. A "remote/local" isolation switch and control switch were provided for the block valves at their motor control center (MCC), located in the Division 12(22) electrical penetration area. The block valves could be closed by placing the "remote/local" isolation switch in "local" and then closing the valves with the control switch provided. The evaluation also indicated that in fire zones where one of the PORVs had a control cable present in the zone that can spuriously open the PORV and its associated block valve and alternating current (AC) power wasn't available, the PORV could be failed closed by pulling its control power fuse at its DC distribution panel. These actions were depicted in the safe shutdown procedures. Operating Procedure 1(2)Bw0A-PRI-5, "Control Room Inaccessibility," Revision 106 included steps indicating that if any PORV block valve can NOT be closed, THEN locally remove the PORV control power fuses to fail its associated PORV closed. While reviewing the schematic diagrams associated with the pressurizer relief isolation block valves (1/2RY8000A and 1/2RY8000B) the inspectors identified a circuit deficiency for which a design basis fire in either the main control room, cable spreading rooms (lower and upper), or electrical cable penetration areas could prevent the Pressurizer PORV block valves from being closed from the local control switches at their associated MCCs. The inspectors identified that a potential fire induced ground in any of these fire areas could clear/open the associated control power fuses (the normal and alternate), which would prevent the valves from operating at the local or remote control switches. The licensee, in response to the inspectors' identification of the circuit deficiency, initially determined that the existing SSA and procedures included mitigating actions if such a condition occurred. The actions included steps to locally remove the PORV control power fuse to fail its associated PORV closed. The inspectors were concerned that because the PORVs and their associated block valves formed a high-low pressure interface that required postulating a proper polarity cable to cable fault, these actions may not be effective in preventing the PORVs from spuriously opening or ensuring closing them during a design basis fire in any of these areas. The inspectors concluded that the licensee's credited actions to remove the control power fuses to close the PORVs did not meet their design and licensing basis for the PORVs and their associated block valves for high-low pressure interface components as specified in the SSA Section 2.4.1.5.2, "Cable Damage Assumption," which stated, in part, that for components which do form part of a high-low pressure interface between the RCS and a lower pressure system, credible circuit failures include multiple open circuits, short circuits, shorts to ground, and multiple hot shorts within the control circuit. In addition, the SSA stated 3-phase AC power circuit cable-to-cable proper phase sequence faults and 2-wire ungrounded DC circuit cable-to-cable proper polarity faults are considered to be credible, and must be evaluated. Upon discovery, the licensee entered this issue into their Corrective Action Program (CAP) as Action Request (AR) 02542045, AR 02544447, and AR 2550306 and established fire watches as immediate compensatory actions. In order to resolve this issue the licensee intended to perform plant modifications. On September 2, the licensee updated the previous notification adding that the local actions to close the block valves at the MCC may not be effective because the MCC may not have electrical power during the design basis fire and therefore, the credited safe shutdown action to remove the PORV control power fuses may not prevent the PORV from spuriously opening and may not ensure the closing of the PORV during a design basis fire in the cable spreading rooms. Analysis: The inspectors determined that the licensee's failure to ensure that the shutdown capability was independent of the fire area and free of fire damage was contrary to Braidwood Station Operating License conditions for the Fire Protection Program and was a performance deficiency. Specifically, in the event of a design basis fire in the control room, cable spreading rooms, or electrical cable penetration areas the licensee failed to ensure that the shutdown capability for Pressurizer PORV block valves would not be affected by fire damage that could impair the operation and closing of the valves from the local control switches located at their associated MCCs in the event of spurious operation of their associated PORVs. The performance deficiency was determined to be more than minor because it was associated with the Mitigating Systems Cornerstone attribute of Protection Against External Events (Fire), and affected the cornerstone objective of ensuring the availability, reliability, and capability of systems that respond to initiating events to prevent undesirable consequences (i.e., core damage). Specifically, in the event of a fire in the control room or the upper and lower cable spreading rooms, fire-induced circuit failures could result in spurious operation of the Pressurizer PORVs and impair the operation and the closing of their associated block valves thus affecting and complicating the plant shutdown in the event of a fire in any of these areas. The actions to close the block valve were required in the event of spurious opening of the associated PORV because the action to remove the control power fuse was not consistent with the circuit analysis for high-low pressure interface component and may not prevent the PORV from spuriously opening and did not ensure the closing of the PORV. In accordance with Inspection Manual Chapter (IMC) 0609, "Significance Determination Process," Attachment 0609.04, "Initial Characterization of Findings," Table 2 the inspectors determined the finding affected the Mitigating Systems Cornerstone. The finding degraded fire protection defense-in-depth strategies, and the inspectors determined, using Table 3, that it could be evaluated using Appendix F, "Fire Protection Significance Determination Process." Using IMC 0609, Appendix F, Attachment 1, "Fire Protection Significance Determination Process Worksheet," the inspectors were not able to screen out the finding using the data available to them, therefore a detailed risk-evaluation was performed by a Region III Senior Reactor Analyst (SRA). The inspectors assigned the finding to the category of "Post-Fire Safe Shutdown." In Task 1.4.5, "Post-fire Safe Shutdown," the inspectors answered "Yes" to Question C, "Could the fire result in a piece of equipment required for safe shutdown not being available." The inspectors contacted the Region III SRA for assistance with the risk evaluation. The change in core damage frequency (?CDF) risk for this deficiency is represented by core damage sequences that include the potential for spurious operation of a pressurizer PORV following certain fires in the main control room, cable spreading rooms, and electrical cable penetration areas that also fail the ability to operate the associated PORV block valve. The ?CDF values in this analysis apply to both Unit 1 and Unit 2 and the total ?CDF applies to each unit separately. Main Control Room The ?CDF for the main control room was evaluated in two cases. The first case is when evacuation is not required. The second case is when evacuation is required. Each case is discussed below. Case1: Evacuation Not Required The frequency of fire for the main control room cabinet (Cabinet 1PM05J) that contained the pressurizer block valves and PORVs was 2.29E-05/yr as listed in the Braidwood Individual Plant Examination of External Events (IPEEE). To estimate the spurious actuation likelihood of the PORVs, the SRA used NUREG/CR-7150, "Joint Assessment of Cable Damage and Quantification of Effects from Fire," Volume 2, Table 8-1, "Summary of Mean Conditional Probability of Spurious Operation for Single Break Control Circuits." The spurious actuation likelihood given inter-cable shorts with thermoset cables was listed as 6.3E-03. The likelihood of a proper polarity hot short then is (6.3E-03)2 or 4.0E-05. Since there are two PORVs, the likelihood of a proper polarity hot short for either PORV is 8.0E-05. In addition, spurious action likelihood given an inter-cable (6.3E-03) and a ground fault equivalent (0.17) hot short was calculated to be 1.1E-03 (6.3E-03 x 0.17). Since there are two PORVs, the hot short probability for this particular failure mode for either PORV is 2.2E-03. Thus, the overall probability of fire-induced spurious operation to open of either pressurizer PORV due to all possible failure modes was calculated to be 2.3E-03. For the conditional core damage probability (CCDP), using the Braidwood Standardized Plant Analysis Risk model, Version 8.24, and "Systems Analysis Programs for Hands-on Integrated Reliability Evaluations" Version 8.1.2. The SRA performed an initiating event assessment assuming a small break loss of coolant accident as a result of the block/PORV valves being open. In addition, the SRA assumed one division of electrical equipment was rendered unavailable due to fire. The result was a CCDP of 2.46E-02. Using the above data and assumptions, the main control room fire risk contribution for Case 1 is 1.30E-09/yr:
?CDF Case 1 = (2.29E-05/yr) * (2.3E-03) * (2.46E-02) = 1.30E-09/yr Case 2: Evacuation Required The frequency of fire for the main control room was again assumed to be 2.29E-05/yr. The fire is assumed to result in abandonment of the main control room given suppression attempts fail at 15-minutes. Table 5-2 of NUREG-2169, "Nuclear Power Plant Fire Ignition Frequency and Non-Suppression Probability Estimation Using the Updated Fire Events Database: United States Fire Event Experience Through 2009," lists the 15-minute non-suppression probability as 8.0E-03. As stated in Case 1, the probability of fire-induced spurious operation to open of either pressurizer PORV is 2.3E-03. For the CCDP, the SRA used a single overall human error probability of 0.1 as a screening CCDP surrogate. Using the above data and assumptions, the main control room fire risk contribution for Case 2 is negligible: ?CDF Case 2 = (2.29E-05/yr) * (8.0E-03) * (2.3E-03) * (1.0E-01) = 4.21E-11/yr The total ?CDF for the main control room is estimated as the sum of the two cases, or a ?CDF value of 1.34E-09/yr. Cable Spreading Rooms The SRA estimated the frequency of fire in the two upper and two lower cable spreading rooms as 1.4E-03/yr using Table A1.3 of IMC 0609 Attachment 1, "Fire Frequency Evaluation Worksheet." This value is conservative as it assumes that the cable spreading rooms contain nonqualified cables with high loading. Fires in the cable spreading rooms are not assumed to result in control room abandonment. The upper cable spreading room uses an automatic halon suppression system. NUREG/CR-6850, "Fire PRA Methodology for Nuclear Power Facilities," lists the 11 non-suppression probability for automatic halon systems as 0.05. The lower cable spreading room uses an automatic CO2 suppression system. The NUREG lists the non-suppression probability for automatic CO2 systems as 0.04. The SRA used the higher non-suppression probability of 5E-02 for fires in the upper and lower cable spreading rooms. As stated in Case 1 above, the probability of fire-induced spurious operation to open of either pressurizer PORV is 2.3E-03. For the CCDP, the SRA used the 2.46E-02 value assuming a small break loss of coolant accident. Using the above data and assumptions, the ?CDF for the cable spreading room fire for both the upper and lower rooms' contribution to the risk of this issue is estimated at 1.58E-8/yr: ?CDF cable spreading rooms = (4 rooms) * (1.4E-03/yr) * (5.0E-02) * (2.3E-03) * (2.46E-02) = 1.58E-8/yr Division 11(21) Electrical Penetration Area The SRA estimated the frequency of fire in the Division 11(21) Electrical Penetration Area as 1.4E-03/yr using Table A1.3 of IMC 0609 Attachment 1, "Fire Frequency Evaluation Worksheet." This value is conservative as it assumes that the electrical penetration areas contain nonqualified cables with high loading. Fires in the Division 11(21) Electrical Penetration Area are not assumed to result in control room abandonment. The Division 11(21) Electrical Penetration Area has no automatic fire suppression, although there is detection, and the area is accessible to the fire brigade. Table 5-2 of NUREG-2169 lists the 15-minute non-suppression probability for cable fires as 0.126. As stated in Case 1 above, the probability of fire-induced spurious operation to open of either pressurizer PORV is 2.3E-03. For the CCDP, the SRA assumed only random failures of equipment, and calculated a value of 5.49E-03 assuming a small break loss of coolant accident. Using the above data and assumptions, the ?CDF for the Division 11(21) Electrical Penetration Area fire contributions to the risk of this issue is estimated at 2.2E-09/yr: ?CDF Division 11(21) Electrical Penetration Area = (1.4E-03/yr) * (0.126) * (2.3E-03) * (5.49E-3) = 2.2E-09/yr Division 21(22) Electrical Penetration Area The ?CDF for the Division 21(22) Electrical Penetration Area was estimated assuming the areas are symmetrical and the same data and assumptions applied as for the Division 11(21) Electrical Penetration Area. The ?CDF for the Division 21(22) Electrical Penetration Area fire contributions to the risk of this issue is estimated at 2.2E-09/yr. Total ?CDF The total ?CDF due to this performance deficiency is estimated as the sum of the individual ?CDF values, or 2.2E-08/yr. The dominant core damage sequences involved small break loss of coolant accident scenarios. Based on the detailed risk evaluation, the SRA determined that the finding was of very low risk significance (Green). The inspectors did not identify a cross-cutting aspect associated with this finding, because the finding was not representative of the licensee's current performance. The last opportunity for the licensee to identify and evaluate this issue was during the Multiple Spurious Operations (MSOs) project in 2012. However, it was outside the scope of the MSO project to look at the detailed wiring configuration for the PORVs and their associated block valves because the scenario of spurious operation of the PORVs and its mitigating strategy was thought to be previously very well thought out. Enforcement: License Conditions 2.E of the Braidwood Station operating licenses, for Units 1 and 2, required, in part, that the licensee implement and maintain in effect all provisions of the fire protection program as described in the Final Safety Analysis Report, as supplemented and amended, and as approved in Safety Evaluation Reports and their supplements. Section 2.4.3.2, "Pressurizer PORVs and Block Valves" of the SSA, stated, in part, that the Division 12(22) PORV and block valves both have control cables in the main control room and in two of the lower cable spreading rooms. Should a fire in any of these zones cause the spurious opening of the PORV, coincident with control circuit damage to the block valve, the block valve could still be closed. Refer to IR 2623885. Completed an 8 Hour Non-emergency notification to the NRC via ENS # 51721 for the loss of secondary containment. Per LS-AA-1110, REPORTABLE EVENT SAF 1.8: Event or Condition That Could Have Prevented Fulfillment of a Safety Function. A breach of secondary containment is considered reportable if the following conditions are met: 1) secondary containment is required in the current mode or other specific condition; 2) secondary containment is declared inoperable in accordance with the plant's Technical Specifications; and 3) the reason(s) for inoperability is (are) not part of a planned evolution. Description: At 21:42 on February 9, 2016, Reactor Building differential pressure did not meet the required 0.25 inches of vacuum water gauge due to failure of the control system. At 22:05, the Unit 3 Reactor Building Ventilation System was secured and manually isolated. The Reactor Building differential pressure returned to  0.25 inches of vacuum water gauge at 22:07. This condition represents a failure to meet Surveillance Requirement 3.6.4.1.1. As a result, entry into Technical Specifications 3.6.4.1 condition A was made due to Secondary Containment being inoperable. The NRC Resident Inspector has been notified.

Received unexpected annunciators 5015-1C LOW LEVEL LP HTR 2A and 5015-3C NOT FULLY CLOSED LP HTR 2A EMERG DRN VLVS. Entered CPS 4005.01 Loss of Feedwater Off-Normal. Initial reported reactor power was 99.2% and 3445 MW Thermal. Station Tapia as the IA Extraction Steam has automatically isolated to 2A, 3A, and 4A heaters and Feedwater temperature has begun to lower. Initial FW Temperature is 424.1F. 03:39 - Feedwater temperature is 413F and lowering, Reactor Power is 3463 MW Thermal. Reducing reactor power by lowing flow using both A and B flow control valves. Highest Reactor Power seen during the transient is 3482 MW Thermal for less than 2 minutes. The MELLA limit has been exceeded, Enter the following LCO actions. Restore APLHGR to within limits in 2 hours Restore MCPR to within limits in 2 hours Restore LHGR to within limits in 2 hours evaluated by: Kalmer/Tapia Commence inserting control rods in reverse sequence to get back inside the MELLA limit. 03:45 - The plant has stabilized at approximately 3440 MW Thermal. Feedwater temperature is 401.5F 04:28 - Back below the MELLA limit. Reactor power is 96.7%, 3360 MW Thermal, and FW temperature is 395.8F. Exit Plant stable, secure IA 04:52 - Based upon RE recommendation inserted control rods in reverse sequence to obtain FCL <99.7% on the 10 minute average. 05:00- Current status of controllers on 1PA05J are: MSDT: Normal; Setting - Auto; Position - Closed; Setpoint +6"; Actual 0" Emergency: Setting - Auto; Position - 30% open; Setpoint 0"; Actual 0" 6A HTR: Normal; Setting - Auto; Position - 55%; Setpoint +1" Emergency: Setting - Auto; Position - Closed; Setpoint +3"; Actual +1" 5A HTR: Normal; Setting - Manual; Position - Closed; Setpoint +6"; Actual - cycling Emergency; Setting - Auto; Position - Cycling 50%-100% open; Setpoint +1"; Actual +1 to +4 4A HTR: Normal; Setting - Auto; Position - Open; Setpoint +2"; Actual +4.5" Emergency; Setting - Auto; Position - Closed; Setpoint +6" 3A HTR: Normal; Setting - Auto; Position - Closed; Setpoint +4"; Actual +3" Emergency: Setting - Auto; Position - Closed; Setpoint +8" 2A HTR: Normal; Setting - Auto; Position - Open; Setpoint +2.2"; Acutal +6.2 Emergency; Setting - Auto; Position - 35% open; Setpoint +6.2

During performance of C025915502 NS4 wiring mod for the test box, logic fuse 10-C623 F15D was found blown following installation of a temporary jumper at step 6.B.1.b. Additionally the fuse for the temporary jumper was found blown. The temporary fused jumper installation is part of the installation plan. F15D is part of the NS4 isolation logic. A similar issue was encountered during the DIV 1 mod PMT's Ref. IR 02646407
200' Delta Temperature data to all temperature recorders is degraded due to 200' temperature aspirator shield not being in the correct position on main 200' tower.

This issue reports an NRC Severity Level IV NCV for failing to report when both divisions of RT differential flow instruments were placed in bypass, which rendered the instruments inoperable and resulted in a loss of the isolation function. This issue is also discussed in IR 2645140 (3D Classification with a Work Group Evaluation) and IR 2652522 (2B Classification with ACE). LS-AA-1003 requires that the responsible organization reviews the NRC issues and ensures the station response and corrective actions properly address the violation and the crosscutting aspect.

Introduction: The Inspectors identified a Severity Level IV NCV for failing to report an event or condition, that at the time of discovery could have prevented the fulfillment of a safety function, to the NRC within eight hours. Specifically, control room operators placed both divisions of RT differential flow instruments in bypass, which rendered the instruments inoperable and resulted in a loss of the isolation function.

Description: On January 25, 2016, control room personnel placed the RT 'A' filter demineralizer in hold for backwash and pre-coat per Station Procedure CPS 3303.01, "Reactor Water Cleanup," Section 8.1.3, and Station Procedure CPS 3302.02, "Reactor Water Cleanup Filter Demineralizer 'A' Operating Procedure," Sections 8.2 and 8.5. While placing the RT 'A' filter demineralizer back into service per Station Procedure CPS 3302.02, Section 8.6, the control room received an RT differential flow alarm. The control room operators placed both divisions of RT differential flow instruments in bypass per Station Procedure CPS 3303.01, which rendered the instruments inoperable and resulted in a loss of the isolation function. The licensee entered TS 3.3.6.1, action D.1, which stated to place channel in trip in 24 hours and action E.1, which stated to restore RT isolation capability in 1 hour. The procedure section to place the RT 'A' filter demineralizer in service was completed and the control room operators placed both divisions of RT differential flow instruments in normal, performed a channel check, and exited TS 3.3.6.1, actions D.1 and E.1. The operations logs documented that the licensee reviewed NRC's guidance for reporting events, NUREG.1022, Section 3.2.7, "Event or Condition that Could Have Prevented Fulfillment of a Safety Function." The operators determined that the condition was not reportable to the NRC based on the statement that "reports are not required when systems are declared inoperable as part of a planned evolution for maintenance or surveillance testing when done in accordance with an approved procedure and the plant's TS (unless a condition is discovered that would have resulted in the system being declared inoperable)." After reviewing the logs on the following day the inspectors asked the control room operators why the activity was considered a planned evolution for maintenance and not considered routine operation of the RT system. The licensee did not provide information to support the activity was a maintenance activity, so the inspectors reviewed the requirements and determined that the condition was reportable. The licensee documented the issue in their CAP as AR 02652522 and created an action to submit a licensee event report (LER). The inspectors' review focused on the reportability aspect of placing the RT differential flow switches in bypass. The inspectors have not reviewed the technical justification or analyses associated with putting the differential flow switches in bypass while the system is in operation, therefore, they have not determined whether this action is in compliance with regulatory requirements. The inspectors planned to review the technical justification and analyses following the receipt of the licensee's LER.

Analysis: The inspectors determined that the failure to report an event or condition, that at the time of discovery could have prevented the fulfillment of a safety function, to the NRC within eight hours was a performance deficiency. Specifically, the licensee failed to notify the NRC after placing both divisions of RT differential flow instrumentation in bypass, which rendered the instruments inoperable and resulted in a loss of the isolation function. The inspectors reviewed this issue in accordance with IMC 0612 and the Enforcement Manual. Violations are dispositioned using the traditional enforcement process because they are considered to be violations that potentially impede or impact the regulatory process. The inspectors reviewed the NRC Enforcement Policy and determined this violation was a Severity Level IV violation because the licensee's failure to make the report did not cause the NRC to reconsider a regulatory position or undertake substantial further inquiry. No cross-cutting aspect was assigned because cross-cutting aspects are not assigned to traditional enforcement only violations.

Enforcement: Requirements in part, state that the licensee report within eight hours any event or condition, that at the time of discovery, could have prevented the fulfillment of a safety function needed to mitigate the consequence of an accident. Contrary to the above, on January 25, 2016, the licensee failed to report, within eight hours, a condition that, at the time of discovery, could have prevented the fulfillment of a safety function needed to mitigate the consequence of an accident. Specifically, control room personnel placed both divisions of RT differential flow instrumentation in bypass, which rendered the instruments inoperable and resulted in a loss of the isolation function needed to mitigate the consequences of an accident. In accordance with the Enforcement Policy, the violation was classified as a Severity Level IV violation. Because this violation was of very low safety significance, was not repetitive or willful, and was entered into the licensee's CAP as AR 02652522, it is being treated as an NCV. Corrective actions included creating an action to submit an LER.

DW (primary containment) venting, in Modes 1-3, will mask the DW pressure response from an RCS leak/LOCA; potentially challenging design basis assumptions and safety systems which actuate at 2.5 psig DW Pressure.

The compressor #1 and compressor #2 for the 0VV030C (TSC Condensing Unit) are repeatedly tripping during hot weather. Attempts to restart via BwOP VV-33/34 were only temporarily successful. The BwAR suggests calling upon EMD for troubleshooting if the compressors cant be maintained running. OPS trouble shooting is still ongoing, but this IR is being generated ASAP because this is a potentially 1-HR reportable item.

On 7-18-16 at 14:50 hrs the weekly ERO notification test for Quad Cities station failed. At 16:00 hrs the site EPM performed an announced ERO Call-in Drill to determine the extent of the Everbridge failure. At that point it was determined that the entire Everbridge ERO Notification System was not working. The ERO was notified at 15:42 hrs that a possible issue with notification was occurring and to stand-by for additional testing. After working with the Mid-Atlantic Fleet owners of the Everbridge system the system was restored. A follow-up Call-In Drill test was performed satisfactory at 19:34 hrs.

Informed by EP that at time 1500, there was a problem with the Everbridge notification system and there is not enough evidence to suggest that Everbridge would have worked per design to comply with EP/ERO requirements, and they agree this is reportable. An 8 hour notification is required by time 2300CDT. Corporate has initiated a prompt investigation. @1957 as requested by EP, initiated an ERO call in drill per EP-AA-112-100-F-06 "ERO NOTIFICATION OR AUGMENTATION". At 2030 notified by EP that the call in drill was successful. @2030 Dresden notification for per OP-AA-106-101 for the ENS reporting are complete @2107 ENS 52098 notification complete. "This 8-hour non-emergency report is being made based upon requirements which states, The licensee shall notify the NRC as soon as practical and in all cases within eight hours of the occurrence of any event that results in a major loss of emergency assessment capability, offsite response capability, or offsite communications capability (e.g., significant portion of control room indication, Emergency Notification System, or offsite notification system). Loss of EP Offsite Communications Capability Testing of the Everbridge ERO Notification system identified the system cannot notify all ERO individuals. This constitutes a loss of Offsite Communications Capability. Compensatory measures (ERO Phone lists) were put in place. The Everbridge system capability loss for Dresden Station was identified at 15:00 CDT on July 18, 2016, due to an undetermined loss of system communications. Emergency Response Data System (ERDS) capability was not lost. This event is reportable as a major loss of communication capability. On July 18, 2016 at 19:57 CDT an Everbridge ERO call in drill was initiated and verified successful at 20:30 The NRC Resident Inspector has been notified.

During testing it was found that the Everbridge ERO notification system may not have been able to notify corporate ERO members within the required ten minutes from system initiation. The system issue did not affect the capability to notify Byron site ERO members - only corporate EOF ERO members. The Everbridge vendor was notified and has since fixed the problem. The corporate ERO notification system was successfully tested with the system activating normally. Additionally, Byron EP staff successfully conducted a test of this system for site ERO members - the system responded as expected. This did not affect the Emergency Response Data System (ERDS).

Received notification that other Exelon Mid-West sites have experienced issues with Everbridge completing the required emergency response team notification in a timely manner. Received notification that the Everbridge system would not have notified the corporate EOF if the system had been activated for an event at LaSalle Station. This issue would have impaired the ability to implement the functions of the emergency plan if an emergency would have occurred.

Notified NRC via ENS notification 52107 of planned maintenance on the TSC ventilation system. The TSC outage is reportable per SAF 1.10 for an 8-hour Non-emergency notification. TSC ventilation work is scheduled to be completed within 14 hours.

At 0934 the MCR received a call from an engineer in the field asking why the 1B DOST room's watertight door (0DSSD192) was open. There was no planned reason for the door to be open. The T1 Operator was dispatched to investigate. The operator found nothing unusual except for the open door. The T1 Operator closed the door. Security determined that the last entry to the security door protected by the watertight door was at 0628 on 8/2/16. This leaves a three hour and six minute period of time where the watertight door was potentially open and unattended. The alarm that sounds when the door is open was not working. That issue is documented in a subsequent IR.
Received alarm 229 C-4, 'B' CAC/CAD ANALYZER TROUBLE. Performed actions of ARC 20C284 C-4. EO reports sample pump breaker is not tripped.

During the performance of RT-O-57A-745-2 Balance of Plant and Miscellaneous Battery Monthly Check, Step 6.1.6 on Data Sheet 16 "10D040 Unit 1 54VDC Omni-Telephone Battery" was unsat. This step checks the pilot cell voltage. The reading for Pilot Cell (#4) was 2.09 VDC, acceptance criteria is greater than or equal to 2.13 VDC. This step is a black box step.

Through wall steam leak found on 1-2301-55, *U1 HPCI STM LINE DRN LINE STM TRAP OUTLET VLV. Leak is on the top of the body, down stream side near the corner where bonnet transitions to piping connection. No visible plume, but is audible near the valve. A screwdriver tip was placed in front of the leak to locate the exact location. Steam condensed on the screwdriver, indicating the leak. The leak cannot be felt from about 3 feet away.

During the performance of RT-O-57A-745-2 Balance of Plant and Miscellaneous Battery Monthly Check, Step 6.1.6 on Data Sheet 16 "10D040 Unit 1 54VDC Omni-Telephone Battery" was unsat. This step checks the pilot cell voltage. The reading for Pilot Cell (#4) was 2.08 VDC, acceptance criteria is greater than or equal to 2.13 VDC. This step is a black box step. This is a follow up issue on IR# 02724006 (A2062105). The retest as requested was unsat and this should be routed back to engineering for recommendations.

On January 2, 2017 at 12:52 LaSalle County 911 inadvertently activated 2 Exelon sirens (LS07 and LS10) located in Seneca. LaSalle County 911 stated that an individual was performing service work on the radio console and may have accidentally activated the 2 Seneca Sirens.

THIS IR ACTION IS BEING GENERATED TO TRACK THE LAB TESTING FOR THE CHARCOAL SAMPLE REMOVED PER SYSTEM ENGINEERING PROCEDURE N1-TTP-046 AND WORK ORDER C93292338. THE CHARCOAL SAMPLE REMOVED DURING PERFORMANCE OF N1-TTP-046 STEP 7.2.6 REQUIRES AN IR TO BE INITIATED TO INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: COMPID OF SAMPLED FILTER: 212-39 DATE OF SAMPLE REMOVAL: 1/3/17 REQUIRED COMPLETION DATE: 2/3/17 (SAMPLE DATE + 31 DAYS) IR ASSIGNED TO SYSTEM MANAGER TALON SPROUSE

This IR documents a historical condition that was identified during time line development for the reportable condition associated with IR 3955705 (HV-011-015A ESW Return FSSD issue). During the time period of January 17, 2016 and April 8, 2016 a blank flange was installed by ECR LG14-00193 at flow element FE-011-011B to allow installation of a new manual valve 011-0125B in series with valve HV-011-011B. With this blank flange installed, only one of the two credited "B" loop ESW return paths to the spray pond was available. The blank flange was removed during 1R16 after completion of scheduled RHRSW piping maintenance and installation of new manual valve 011-0125B. This is analogous to the condition identified in IR 3955705 which also had one of the two credited ESW loop return paths to the spray pond unavailable. The existing fire safe shutdown analysis (FSSD) credits both return paths in order to mitigate certain single spurious fire induced valve operations. IR 3955705 identified a non-compliant FSSD condition with the "A" ESW return loop. This IR is identifying a historical non-compliant FSSD unanalyzed condition on the "B" ESW return loop. FSSD Impact: A contract was issued to have the Limerick FSSD SME review this historical condition. This review identified that the three fire area analyses were impacted by the blank flange installed by ECR LG14-00193. The three impacted fire areas are 16, 45E and 82. The historical impact of ECR LG14-00193 to these fire areas is as follows: Fire Area 016 . Some credited B/D train safe shutdown equipment would no longer be available, however sufficient redundant equipment remained available to meet the FSSD regulatory requirements. No additional manual actions required to compensate for the additional failures. Fire Area 082 . Some credited B/D train safe shutdown equipment would no longer be available, however sufficient redundant equipment remained available to meet the FSSD regulatory requirements. No additional manual actions required to compensate for the additional failures. Fire Area 045E . NO credited safe shutdown method remain available. This review identified that fire area 45E (Eastern Half of Limerick Unit 1 Reactor Enclosure Elevation 253'-0") was not in compliance with the existing FSSD analysis while the blank flange was installed. The review results for the impacted areas were also confirmed by Site Engineering personnel. ECR LG14-00193 and its associated screening did not identify and address that fire area 45E would not be compliant with the existing analysis documented in UFSAR chapter 9A (FPER). The FSSD analysis credits both return flow paths so that Emergency Service Water can be returned to the spray pond while remaining tolerant to certain spurious valve operations. For fire area 45E, with only one of the two return flow paths available, a single spurious fire induced closure of valve HV-011-015B can result in deadheading of a B loop ESW pump. This will cause a loss of cooling water to the credited B RHR pump compartment room coolers and the credited RHR pump motor oil cooler. Fire Area 45E credits Fire Safe Shutdown Method C. If the credited B RHR pump fails due to loss of compartment cooling and motor oil cooling caused by the single spurious fire induced closure of HV-011-015B, it will prevent "B" LPCI injection which is credited for RPV inventory control at approximately 20 to 25 minutes into the post fire event. This could result in the only credited safe shutdown method (C) being unavailable. The plant would not have been able to achieve safe shutdown, because the single credited safe shutdown method could have been lost. This historical issue may be reportable. It can result in a noncompliance with current fire safe shutdown analysis documented in the fire protection evaluation report and fire protection program which is the current Limerick licensing basis (CLB). The current Limerick licensing basis assumes a single spurious actuation of safe shutdown components during any single deterministic fire event for plant areas as documented in Limerick UFSAR FPER section 9A. 5. The identified historical issue results in a single spurious actuation that can impact the ability to safely shutdown. With the loss of the single credited safe shutdown method during the postulated area wide fire in fire area 45E, the plant could not have been able to achieve safe shutdown. This condition is therefore unanalyzed.

While performing WO# 1940764-01 for an operability surveillance for the TSC AFU's IAW DOP 5750-05, it was discovered that the 2/3-5772-122 TSC HVAC AFU OUTSIDE AIR DAMPER is not re-positioning for achieve required flow. The acceptance criteria for AFU flow is between 900-1100 cfm. Flow was recorded at 670 cfm. Per the system engineer, the 2/3-5772-122 provides 250 cfm of outside air flow, but with it closed there is 0 flow.

Concurrent with tagout U1X-33B-0131 application, a turbine trip signal and HPCI initiation occurred. This tagout was the first in a series of tagouts to establish 345kV backfeed. Major equipment removed from service: Generator Disconnect Switch (SW-18) Station Power Board supply breakers (PB-11 and 12 normal supply breakers) Generator Excitation (AVR) 345kV Metering circuits Generator leads cooling fans Turbine Trip Handle

During realignment of SFP purification from 21 RWT to the SFP inventory was inadvertently transferred from 21 RWT to the SFP. This caused a low level alarm in 21RWT, with minimum wide range level recorded on the plant computer of 38.2', and a high level alarm in the spent fuel pool with a final level of approximately 67'4". Following identification of issue 12 SFP cooling pump was secured which stopped the transfer, and 21 RWT level was restored to a level of 38.86' approximately 45 minutes later.

We noticed R-17 Counts rising in Main Control Room. Trended R-17 (Rising-High Warning), CCW Surge Tank Level (Rising), VCT Level (Lowering more rapidly than before PZR Steam Space sample started). Notified US/SM of condition, and entered AP-CCW.1. Upon notifying Chemistry to secure PZR Steam Space Sample, R-17 counts began to lower, CCW Surge Tank Level stabilized at approx. 50% and VCT Level began to lower at a Pre-Event Rate. Exited AP-CCW.1.

An issue was identified at Oyster Creek related to EAL E-HU1, Damage to a loaded cask CONFINEMENT BOUNDARY documented under IR 4003001. Byron Station reviewed ISFSI cask documentation certificates of compliance for all dry casks loaded at the site. It was identified that all dry cask containers are identical however they were loaded under different certificates of compliance. The variations between these certificates included different limit values for the measured dose rates on a loaded OVERPACK. The first six casks at Byron were loaded under certificate of compliance No. 1014 revision 3 which contained limit values for the measure dose rates on a loaded OVERPACK of > 20 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the top of the spent fuel cask or > 110mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the side of the spent fuel cask, excluding inlet and outlet ducts. Whereas the remainder of the casks were loaded under certificate of compliance No. 1014 revision 7 and 9 revision 1. These certificates contained limit values for the measure dose rates on a loaded OVERPACK of > 30 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the top of the spent fuel cask or > 300 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the side of the spent fuel cask, excluding inlet and outlet ducts. It was identified that the current EAL action level in EP-AA-1002 Addendum 3, Emergency Action Levels for Byron Station, Revision 1 UE EAL E-HU1 is based on the certificate of compliance No. 1014 Revision 9 revision 1. (limit values for the measure dose rates on a loaded OVERPACK of > 30 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the top of the spent fuel cask or > 300 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the side of the spent fuel cask, excluding inlet and outlet ducts) NEI 99-01 requires that the UE EAL is 2 times the TS initial loading limit. Resulting in the EAL threshold values of > 60mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the top of the spent fuel cask or > 600mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the side of the spent fuel cask, excluding inlet and outlet ducts. This difference was not recognized when the EALs were revised in February 2016 to revision 6 of NEI 99-01. Reportability was reviewed using EP-AA-120-1006, EP Reportability. Loss of Emergency Preparedness Capabilities and discussed with corporate EP and found this condition is not reportable as this is an EAL threshold value problem and not a loss of emergency assessment capability from a loss of a structure or equipment, including indications, display systems and annunciators that prevent the evaluation of all EALs for an emergency Initiating Condition (IC).

An issue was identified at Oyster Creek related to EAL E-HU1, Damage to a loaded cask CONFINEMENT BOUNDARY documented under IR 4003001. PB Station Engineering reviewed ISFSI cask documentation certificates of compliance for all dry casks loaded at the site. It was identified that all dry cask containers are essentially the same; however, they were loaded under two different certificates of compliance amendments. The variations between these amendments included different limit values for the measured dose rates. There exists three casks (45, 46 and 47) at PB loaded under Certificate of Compliance (C of C) 1027 / Technical Specification Amendment 0; with the remaining 77 casks have been analyzed to be in compliance with C of C 1027 / Technical Specification Amendment 1. It was identified that the current EAL threshold values listed in EP-AA-1007 Addendum 3, Emergency Action Levels for Peach Bottom Station, Revision 4, UE EAL E-HU1 are based on the certificate of compliance 1027 Technical Specification Amendment 1 TS 5.2.3.3 limits assuming design basis fuel is loaded in the casks. These values are different than the certificate of compliance 1027, Technical Specification Amendment 0 values of measured dose rates. Additionally, most loaded TN casks assume cask specific lower limiting dose rates as in accordance with TS 5.2.3.2, not TS 5.2.3.3. For amendment 0 casks (45, 46, 47), the TS dose limits are about 2/3 of what they are for amendment 1 casks (of which the EAL is based on). Also, the TS 5.2.3.2 cask specific dose rates (of which is credited in the PBAPS analysis) are also substantially lower limits than the TS 5.2.3.3 dose rates for design basis fuel (which PBAPS does not credit for all loaded casks). It appears that by calculating the PBAPS EAL as twice the values of the TS 5.2.3.3, this would make the EAL threshold artificially high. This difference in certificate of compliances was not recognized when the EALs were revised in December 2015 to revision 6 of NEI 99-01. Reportability specific to EP was reviewed using EP-AA-120-1006, EP Reportability. Loss of Emergency Preparedness Capabilities and discussed with corporate EP and found this condition is not reportable as this is an EAL threshold value problem and not a loss of emergency assessment capability from a loss of structure or equipment, including indications, display systems and annunciators that prevent the evaluation of all EALs for an emergency Initiating Condition (IC). Actions are: -Engineering to perform the required reviews to determine the accurate EAL threshold values for the two certificate of compliance casks; -EP to process these changes into EP-AA-1007, Appendix 3 for Initiating Condition E-HU1.

An issue was identified at Oyster Creek related to EAL E-HU1, "Damage to a loaded cask CONFINEMENT BOUNDARY," as documented under IR 4003001, where Oyster had two types of DCS canisters on the pad and the EAL was based on the limits for only one type. As a result, Quad Cities reviewed ISFSI dry cask storage (DCS) Certificate of Compliance (CoC) documentation for all DCS containers placed on the ISFSI pad. It was identified that all DCS containers are of the same type; however, they were loaded under different CoC Amendments/Revisions. The variations between these CoC Amendments/Revisions includes different maximum dose rate limits for the measured dose rates on a loaded OVERPACK as specified in DCS Technical Specification (TS) 5.7.4. The first 37 casks at Quad Cities were loaded under CoC No. 1014 Amendment Nos. 2 and 3. The associated DCS TS 5.7.4 for these Amendments states that the measured dose rates on a loaded OVERPACK shall not exceed the following values: a. 20 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the top of the OVERPACK b. 110 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the side of the OVERPACK, excluding inlet and outlet ducts. The last 11 casks loaded on the ISFSI at Quad Cities meet the requirements of CoC No. 1014 Amendment No. 8, Revision No. 1. The associated DCS TS 3.7.4 states that the measured dose rates on a loaded OVERPACK shall not exceed the following values: a. 30 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the top of the OVERPACK b. 300 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the side of the OVERPACK, excluding inlet and outlet ducts. It was identified that the current EAL action level in EP-AA-1006 Addendum 3, "Emergency Action Levels for Quad Cities Station," Revision 3, for UE EAL E-HU1 is based on the limits from CoC No. 1014 Amendment No. 2 and 3, i.e., 40 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the top of the OVERPACK and 220 mr/hr (gamma + neutron) on the side of the OVERPACK, excluding inlet and outlet ducts. The current EALs are based on NEI 99-01, "Development of Emergency Action Levels for Non-Passive Reactors," Revision 6. As described in NEI 99-01, Revision 6, the basis for this UE EAL threshold is "2 times the site-specific cask specific technical specification allowable radiation level." Furthermore, NEI 99-01, Revision 6 states that emphasis for this classification is the degradation in the level of safety of the spent fuel cask and not the magnitude of the associated dose or dose rate. At issue is the magnitude of the dose rate at the cask at which the site will declare an unusual event; there are no potential escalation paths for this EAL. When a HI-STORM is loaded onto the ISFSI pad, the TS limit is verified per RP-QC-304. While the procedure was updated to reflect the higher TS limits as discussed above, this procedure also verifies the dose rate is lower than an administrative limit (25 mr/hr for the side and 8.5 mr/hr for the top) that ensures that the fuel loaded onto the ISFSI had a baseline dose rate that was significantly less than the dose rate limits of the amendments used to establish the EAL. The DCS work orders for the eleven casks loaded to Amendment 8 Revision 1 (WPs 01614866 and 01805377) were reviewed and the maximum dose rates measured per RP-QC-304 were 1.7 mr/hr on the side and 1.3 mr/hr on the top. The fact that the casks loaded on the ISFSI pad at Quad Cities Station comply with different CoC Amendments/Revisions and have different DCS TS 5.7.4 limits was not recognized when the EALs were revised to meet NEI 99-01, Revision 6. The need to specify different EAL thresholds associated with the different CoC Amendments/Revisions is being questioned. Since the baseline dose rates of the casks are significantly lower than the dose rates used to establish the current EAL at Quad Cities, the use of the current EAL is appropriate while this issue is investigated further.

During the performance of RT-O-57M-790-2 OMNI Battery Quarterly Inspection, the voltage reading for 10D040 cell #14 was 2.06VDC. Acceptance criteria per step 6.1.13 is greater than or equal to 2.13 VDC. This step is a black box step.

A non radioactive sealand from outside the protected area was shipped to local scrap yard. Upon arrival the sealand alarmed the radiation monitor at the scrap yard. The trucking company brought the sealand back to site.

During scheduled work under WO C93221528, Network Intrusion Detection Phase II, an unexpected network error occurred causing brief loss of plant network connectivity. This impacted U2 PI data, DRMS, and TARS. Unit 1 Control Room noticed a computer trouble alarm which cleared immediately.

Low DP alarm came in for the TSC HVAC. After investigating the issue it was determined that the belts for the moter/fan assembly had broken due to extended use. Belts were inspected to insure no fire was present and to determine cause of failure.

A plant maintenance technician identified an unattended duffel bag in a site parking lot located within the Owner Controlled Area at 0149 on August 23, 2017. Plant Security personnel investigated and subsequently contacted the local law enforcement agency (Oswego County Sheriff's Department) for assistance at 0155. Local Law Enforcement Agencies are actively investigating the unattended bag. The NRC resident inspector (Ken Kolaczyk) and the Nuclear Duty Officer (Randy Dus) have been notified. A four hour NRC Event Notification has been made since notification to other government agencies had been made. This condition was screened for a Prompt Investigation and did not meet the criterion per OP-AA-106-101-1001.

R-1 radiation reading for the control room went into high warning at 1.79mrem/hr and then returned to approximately .1mrem/hr. After a review of PPCS plot for R-1 it was determined that it started spiking up in reading on 08/31/17 at approximately 2216.

During the planned Reactor Building loading during pre-outage activities, the equipment hatch inner door was able to be cycled open while the outer door was not fully closed. The door interlock between the inner and outer doors failed allowing the inner door to be open without the exterior door being fully closed. The total time of both doors being open simultaneously was less than 15 seconds based on report from technicians in the field.

During second set of Red Floor checks, the Overvoltage target and reset light on MCC 18/19-5 were found lit. Target is only halfway open. Red light above target is lit. Overfrequency relay on 18/19-5 already has a known issue, reference IR 4025916

This IR identifies a non-conforming condition with the both Emergency Diesel Generator (EDG) fuel oil day tank vents with respect to tornado missile protection. Inadequate function of vents can result in a loss of fuel oil supply to EDGs. Since the fuel oil supply is an integral component of the EDG's and is not protected against tornado missiles, the design does not meet the licensing basis and a non-conforming condition exists. NRC Enforcement Guidance Memorandum EGM 15-002, Revision 1, provides for application of NRC enforcement discretion which allow the diesel generators EG-Y-1A and EG-Y-1B to be returned to an operable status based on the application of Comp Measures which are intended to reduce the likelihood that the tornado event would result in a failure of the EDGs. Application of the guidance in EGM 15-002, Revision 1, and, NRC DSS-ISG-2016-01 Revision 1 Appendix A, describes acceptable initial and comprehensive compensatory measures necessary to ensure that the identified nonconforming condition in this issue report can be treated by the NRC with enforcement discretion. Per guidance in NRC DSS-ISG-2016-01 Revision 1, "The measures listed below should be verified as current and readily deployable within a very short timeframe." The initial IR (#4081290) and the ENS notification (#53106), with respect to tornado missile protection, are issued on December 6th, 2017.

This IR identifies a non-conforming condition with Borated water supply for safe shutdown after a design basis tornado. Neither of the emergency sources, currently described in emergency procedures, the Borated Water Storage Tank (DH-T-1) or the Boric Acid Mix Tank (CA-T-1) are protected against the tornado-generated missiles. A borated water supply is required to maintain sufficient RCS inventory to support RCS heat removal and raise RCS boron concentration to maintain the reactor shutdown after Xenon decays. The borated water supply function does not meet the licensing basis and a non-conforming condition exists. NRC Enforcement Guidance Memorandum EGM 15-002, Revision 1, provides for application of NRC enforcement discretion which allow the components associated with Borated Water Supply function to be returned to an operable status based on the application of Comp Measures which are intended to reduce the likelihood that the tornado event would result in a failure of the borated water supply. Application of the guidance in EGM 15-002, Revision 1, and, NRC DSS-ISG-2016-01 Revision 1 Appendix A, describes acceptable initial and comprehensive compensatory measures necessary to ensure that the identified nonconforming condition in this issue report can be treated by the NRC with enforcement discretion. Per guidance in NRC DSS-ISG-2016-01 Revision 1, "The measures listed below should be verified as current and readily deployable within a very short timeframe." The initial IR (#4081290) and the ENS notification (#53106), with respect to tornado missile protection, are issued on December 6th, 2017.

During a review of Ginna EAL's to identify single point vulnerabilities as an Extent of Condition for AR 04074137, it was identified that High Lake Level used for classification of HU1.5 & HA1.5 presents a single point vulnerability. Per EP-AA-1012 Addendum 3, "High lake level may be determined using markers attached to a metal pole mounted on the discharge canal bridge upstream of the submarine net. The high level markers are at lake levels of 252 ft and 253 ft". Ginna has one pole with one 252 foot marker for the UE level indication and one 253 foot marker for the Alert level indication. If either of these markers are lost, we would not have indication of its associated EAL threshold. Also if the entire pole was lost, damaged, or not visible for any reason, we would not have indications available to classify the event. This would require an 8 hour NRC report due to a Loss of Emergency Preparedness Capabilities caused by a Loss of Emergency Classification Capability.
Control Room was notified by the FIN Supervisor of a small fire occurred at MSR 1B HIGH LOAD CONTROL VALVE. Fire Brigade was dispatched to address the condition and extinguished the fire.

During performance of QCOS 2300-30 on U-2, when a HPCI full initiation signal was inserted, the HPCI Auxiliary Oil Pump failed to start. Due to the failure of the HPCI Auxiliary Oil Pump to start, subsequent actions that occur following Auxiliary Oil Pump start failed to occur as well. The HPCI Auxiliary Oil Pump was started per QCOS 2300-17 and operated as expected. Further troubleshooting revealed that PS 2-2341-4 contacts 3-4 are open with no HPCI Oil Pumps running and the oil system depressurized. Follow up troubleshooting is recommended to verify the failure. A continuity check was performed from 902-39 EE-78 and AA-45 and revealed open contacts from the pressure switch. The pressure switch contacts should be closed which in turn energizes relay 2-2330-166 and automatically starts the HPCI Auxiliary Oil Pump. Reference 4E-2532. The logic test was suspended in the current lineup to allow further troubleshooting as necessary.

During a walkdown performed in the Drywell Basement, it was identified that box guide support 2305-G-102.2 has two (2) of four (4) broken welds in the attachment to the beam (Item 3 on detail drawing M-328G Sheet 21) with the other 2 welds being intact. This support is located in the drywell basement on line number 2-2305-10"-B which is the HPCI Steam Supply Line (Isometric: M-3118 Sheet 1). This is an ASME Class 1 support. Support 2305-G-102.2 is not part of the Q2R24 (2018) ISI Scope, but it is part of Q2R25 (2020) ISI Scope. There is no required ISI scope expansion as this was not identified during a scheduled ISI exam. This support has been previously examined per ASME Section XI in Q2R20 (2010) and Q2R16 (2002) with no indications. Reviewed drawings and discussed extent of condition (EOC) with NDE personnel who identified the issue, and confirmed the adjacent support was already walked down with no issues identified. Contacted Design Engineering and it was agreed that the welds of this support need to be fixed.

Formal review of the following for applicability: Power Reactor Event Number: 53388 Facility: CALLAWAY Region: 4 State: MO Unit: 1 RX Type: 1 W-4-LP NRC Notified By: JEREMY MORTON HQ OPS Officer: DAN LIVERMORE Notification Date: 05/07/2018 Notification Time: 16:31 ET Event Date: 05/07/2018 Event Time: 13:35 CDT Last Update Date: 05/07/2018 Emergency Class: NON EMERGENCY Person (Organization): MARK HAIRE (R4DO) Unit SCRAM Code RX CRIT Initial PWR Initial RX Mode Current PWR Current RX Mode 1 N Y 100 Power Operation 100 Power Operation DISCOVERY OF A CONDITION THAT COULD HAVE PREVENTED FULFILLMENT OF A SAFETY FUNCTION "On May 7, 2018, during an engineering review of mission time requirements for Technical Specification related equipment, a deficiency was discovered regarding the Emergency Operating Procedure (EOP) guidance for natural circulation cooldown with a stagnant loop. This condition could be the result of a postulated Main Steam Line Break with a loss of offsite power. "During a natural circulation cooldown with a faulted steam generator, flow in the stagnant reactor coolant system (RCS) loop associated with the isolated faulted steam generator (SG) could stagnate and result in elevated temperatures in that loop. This becomes an issue when RCS depressurization to residual heat removal system (RHR) entry conditions is attempted. The liquid in the stagnant loop will flash to steam and prevent RCS depressurization. In this condition, the time required to complete the cooldown would be sufficiently long that the nitrogen accumulators associated with Callaway's atmospheric steam dumps and turbine driven auxiliary feedwater pump flow control valves would be exhausted. The atmospheric steam dumps and turbine driven auxiliary feedwater pump would not be capable of performing their specified safety functions of cooling the plant to entry conditions for RHR operation. This issue has been analyzed by Westinghouse in WCAP-16632-P. This WCAP determined that to prevent loop stagnation, the RCS cooldown rate in these conditions should be limited to a rate dependent on the temperature differential present in the active loops. "The WCAP analysis was used to support a revision to the generic Emergency Response Guideline (ERG) for ES-0.2 "Natural Circulation Cooldown." Figure 1 in ES-0.2 provides a curve of the maximum allowable cooldown rate as a function of active loop temperature differential which is directly proportional to the level of core decay heat. At the time of discovery of this condition, Callaway's EOP structure did not ensure that the ES-0.2 guidance would be implemented for a natural circulation cooldown with a stagnant loop. "Callaway has issued interim guidance to the on-shift personnel regarding this concern and is in the process of revising the applicable EOPs. "This condition is reportable for any event or condition that at the time of discovery could have prevented the fulfillment of the safety function of structures or systems that are needed to (A) Shutdown the reactor and maintain it in a safe shutdown condition, (B) Remove residual heat, or (D) mitigate the consequences of an accident."

This IR identifies a non-conforming condition with the Unit 1 Saltwater system header and associated piping for both subsystems located in the Intake Structure with respect to tornado missile protection. The Saltwater system header and some piping is vulnerable to a tornado missile that enters the Intake Structure through the watertight door, IS-2. The saltwater system provides a heat sink for the removal of process and operating heat from safety-related components during a transient or design basis accident. Since the saltwater system header and associated piping are not protected against a tornado missile entering through watertight door IS-2, the design does not meet the licensing basis and a non-conforming condition exists. NRC Enforcement Guidance Memorandum EGM 15-002, Revision 1, provides for application of NRC enforcement discretion which allow Unit 1 Saltwater System to be returned to an operable status based on the application of compensatory measures which are intended to reduce the likelihood that the tornado event would result in a failure of the Saltwater system. Application of the guidance in EGM 15-002, Revision 1, and NRC DSS-ISG-2016-01 Revision 1 Appendix A, describes acceptable initial and comprehensive compensatory measures necessary to ensure that the identified nonconforming condition in this issue report can be treated by the NRC with enforcement discretion. "The measures listed below should be verified as current and readily deployable within a very short timeframe." The resident inspector has been informed of this issue and of the intent to utilize enforcement discretion in accordance with EGM 15-002 (Rev 1).
