MCR received a high rad alarm on 0PR34J at 0814. The high alarm came in and cleared within 30 seconds. The spike occurred when a light bulb was being replaced in the "Instrument Available" light on the RM-80 panel for the 0PR34J. Per the BwAR, automatic VC actions were verified and VV, VL, and VW were verified tripped locally at 0824. All systems were restored to normal at 0832. The bulb remains lit for the 0PR34J "Instrument Available" light.

Received unexpected TSC HVAC trouble annunciator. Upon inspection of the local panel, the 0VV23C low DP and Condensing Unit No. 1 trouble alarms were lit. 0VV23C showed it was still running with no DP. Inspection of the fan showed that the belt had come off the motor, and the fan was running uncoupled. The supply fan was secured and the Unit 1 supervisor notified.

On Tuesday August 3, 2021 the Braidwood EP Manager was notified by the Corporate EP Specialist that at 1440hrs Will County 911 accidently activated the 'Braidwood All Call'. This activated the Will County sirens around the Braidwood station. Once the error was noticed, they immediately sent out an 'All Call Cancel' command. The sirens were activated for 10 seconds as confirmed by J&D Ingenuities. At this time a press release is not planned.

Technical evaluation of DC power control circuits identified during extent of condition review from IR 04259118 CA#16 found four (4) cables that require additional protective devices (fuses) that must be installed to avoid a secondary fire that would impact JAF Appendix R compliance strategies. Specifically, cable 1ZBNNNC013 for 71EDSC-10017(M) (115 kV Bus Tie Disconnect), cable 1PCPARK107 for 27MOV-123 (TORUS EXHAUST ISOL VALVES 27AOV-117 & 118 OUTBD BYPASS VALVE), cable 1HPIBBK006 for 23MOV-14 (HPCI TURB STEAM INLET ISOL VALVE), and cable 1HPIBBK024 for 23MOV-24 (HPCI FULL FLOW TEST RETURN TO COND STOR DNSTR ISOL VALVE) are under-sized for the potential current that it could be subjected to. Recommend additional protective devices (i.e. fuses) installed to protect the cables from starting a fire in one area from a hot short resulting in a secondary fire or cable failure in another area which the cables are routed.

This issue report is a follow-up to IR 4442083, "Correction Required for Byron 2021 NRC Exercise Report": "While reviewing EP tasks remaining for the year and referencing EP-AA-120-F-03 it was identified that the currently submitted drill report for Byron Station's NRC Graded Exercise does not take credit for completing a Core Damage Assessment Drill. Review of the exercise material and data indicate credit can and should be be sic taken for this annual requirement." Consequently, I was assigned the task to "draft and submit corrected drill report for Byron Station 2021 NRC Exercise noting that Core Damage Assessment is an additional drill credited to the exercise" (4442083-02). In support of this assignment, site EP emailed the following: "I spoke to corporate EP manager last week and per his direction I have created IR 04442083 to have the Byron Station NRC Graded Exercise Drill Report corrected. We did not take credit for the Core Damage Assessment annual drill requirement and we should have. We graded objective I.2 and it was satisfactory which is the minimum requirement to take credit for the CDAM drill. I also reviewed all of the demonstration criteria and they were satisfactory as well. I have attached a pdf that includes the checklists for the Core Thermal Engineer, Tech Manager, and CDAM reports as well for supporting documentation." "Under ERO Performance Objective Summary add "Core Damage Assessment" under the item "Additional drills credited to this Exercise"" "Once corrected please resubmit for review and approval. Once approved I will forward to records management." The pdf attached to this email is titled "CDAM Info." As stated, it includes the exercise participants CDAM reports, which are date and time stamped as follows: 08:32 03/23/2021: No Core Damage 09:57 03/23/2021: Cladding Failure <1% based on CETs (<1% = No Core Damage) 10:42 03/23/2021: 2% Cladding Failure based on Containment Radiation 10:58 03/23/2021: 46% Cladding Failure based on CETs 11:09 03/23/2021: 83% Cladding Failure based on CETs Base on this CDAM Info, I do not believe Objective I.2 was satisfied. For comparison, this exercise scenario was developed with a core damage estimate of 4% clad failure based on the peak containment radiation (2456 R/hr) at 1151. This exercise scenario was developed with a core damage estimate of 4% clad failure, whereas the exercise participants estimated 83% clad failure. This is an exceptionally large disparity that was not justified or documented in the original report according to EP-AA-122-300-F-04 Drill & Exercise Post-Event Critique & Report Development Guidance. The 'CDAM Info' was not provided by site EP or reported by the TSC Lead Evaluator during the formal report writing meeting on August 24. Contrary to one claim, it was not discussed during the formal report writing meeting. Apparently, it was never discussed with the TSC Lead Evaluator. It was not included in her emailed lists of "DCs UNSAT and SAT w/ comments" or "Additional Comments for the TSC from Byron Critique. In retrospect, the 'CDAM Info' was conspicuously missing during the formal evaluation and report development of this regulated and NRC graded exercise -- information which indicates Objective I.2 should have been failed. Relevant Scenario and CDAM Timeline: 0832 Core Damage Assessment: No Core Damage 0945: Large break LOCA into Containment and a Potential Loss of the Containment (SAE T=0) 0957 Core Damage Assessment: Cladding Failure <1% based on CETs 0958: SAE declaration 1040: Containment high range rad monitors increased > 1.05 E+03 R/hr with a radiological release in progress (GE T=0) 1042: Core Damage Assessment: 2% Cladding Failure based on Containment Radiation 1043: GE declaration was made based on containment radiation (> 1.05 E+03 R/hr) 1057 (approximately): CETs indicated > 1200 *F for 5 minutes 1058: Core Damage Assessment: 46% Cladding Failure based on CETs 1109: Core Damage Assessment: 83% Cladding Failure based on CETs 1151: Containment radiation peaks at 2456 R/hr 1210: Exercise termination - Radiological release rate increased until exercise termination. Based on the CDAM Info provided by site EP, the exercise participants did not perform any core damage assessments between 1109 and 1210 (exercise termination). Because containment radiation levels (and radiological release rates) continued to increase well after 1109, additional core damage assessment were required by EP-AA-112-200-F-11, CORE / THERMAL HYDRAULIC ENGINEER CHECKLIST, to satisfy Objective I.2. Based on the CDAM Info, the participants stopped assessing core damage at 1109 even though there were clear indications degrading core conditions at 1151. Given this information, it seems Objective I.2 should have been failed. The following questions remain unanswered by site and corporate EP: Why did the participants stop assessing core damage after 1109? Are there core damage assessments missing from the "CDAM Info" provided by site EP? If the participants performed core damage assessments after 1109, did they believe reestablishing core cooling repaired 79% clad failure? The exercise scenario was developed using the Containment Radiation method to assess core damage because it is "optimized for large break LOCA conditions" which existed in this exercise scenario. Given this, why didn't the participants use the Containment Radiation method to assess core damage after 1109? The participants used the wrong method to assess core damage. They used the CET Temperature method to perform the 1058 (46% clad failure) and 1109 (83% clad failure) core damage assessments. After 1109, the CET temperatures were less than 1200*F because core cooling had been reestablished; therefore, if any later core damage assessments were performed using the CET method, they would have indicated less than 1% clad damage (no core damage). Because reestablishing core cooling cannot repair or reduce the level of clad damage, the CET method was obviously inaccurate and should not have been used. The participants used the Containment Radiation method at 1042 (2%) and, the General Emergency was declared at 1043 based on containment radiation. Why did they not use the Containment Radiation method after 1109? If the participants had used the Containment Radiation method after 1109, it would have indicated approximate 4% as the scenario was developed (2456 R/hr at 1151). Nevertheless, they would have failed Objective I.2 because their prior core damage assessments (46% and 83%) were grossly inaccurate. Notably, reestablishing core cooling will not repair clad damage. This information was discussed and emailed to site and corporate EP. Despite my questions and concerns, site and corporate EP still contend that Objective I.2 was satisfied without answering direct questions or providing formal justification for inclusion in the revised report. Several times, I stated that without justification documented in the report, I did not feel comfortable revising the report to include credit for successfully satisfying the I.2 Objective or signing it. Because I was assigned to revised and sign the report, I also stated, I believe I have a legitimate need - if not the right - for the information I have requested. In response, I received the follow replies from site EP: -"A report would not be required after 1109 unless there was an increase in potential core damage." -"The 1109 core damage assessment report included in the email I sent was the highest predicted over the course of the exercise and an additional report would not have been generated until a more accurate assessment would have been generated utilizing chemistry sample results which wouldn't have been available until after the exercise had already been terminated." -"As stated during the teams meeting last week and demonstration provided in the two CDAM assessments above the participants 1109 core damage assessment was accurate for the data provided." -"The demonstration criteria was considered sat Satisfied and therefore would not have additional information provided." -"You are signing as the preparer of the report based off of the information and grading provided to you by the lead evaluator in the Emergency Response Facility and the EP staff at the station." Under these circumstances, I find it problematic to revise the Byron NRC Graded Exercise Report and sign-off that Objective I.2 was satisfied, particularly in a regulated exercise such as this. Accordingly, I respectfully request that my concerns and questions be evaluated in Byron's Corrective Action Program.

On 12/12/21 at 1949, Nine Mile Point (NMP) lost all local MET tower indications. Affected parameters included 30ft and 200ft Wind Speed and Wind Direction as well as Air temperature differences. TRM 3.3.10 Condition A was entered for each applicable channel with the required action to restore operability. James A. Fitzpatrick (JAF) contacted NMP and reported loss of Line: Feeder 29951. A loss of this line causes a loss of power to the JAF and NMP Meteorological Towers, the NMP Training Center, and the alternate feeder to the NMP Construction Loop.

A self-revealed Green non-cited violation of Technical Specification 5.4.1.a, "Procedures," when Exelon failed to provide adequate written procedures as required by Regulatory Guide 1.33, "Quality Assurance Program Requirements (Operation)," Revision 2, February 1978, Appendix A, Section 3, "Procedures for Startup, Operation, and Shutdown of Safety Related PWR Systems." Specifically, Exelon failed to adequately convey technical requirements into Procedure O-2.1, "Normal Shutdown to Hot Shutdown," Revision 153, which resulted in low-low 'A' steam generator water level less than 17% on October 4, 2021. The issue also resulted in the steam generator water level in the 'B' steam generator to fill high in band which also caused a reactor coolant system temperature reduction, over cooling event. Lastly, this event resulted in a valid auxiliary feedwater start signal which was subsequently reported to the NRC via Event Notification 55504. The NRC assigned Cross-Cutting Aspect H.4 - Teamwork. NRC IMC 0310 describes H.4 as follows: "Teamwork: Individuals and work groups communicate and coordinate their activities within and across organizational boundaries to ensure nuclear safety is maintained." NOTE: 1) The IR for the actual Event is 04450520. 2) This IR's Condition Description is the NRC's Summary. The wording of the entire violation from NRC Inspection Report 05000244/2021004 is captured in Assignment -05 to this IR.

On Tuesday, February 1, 2022 during the monthly siren test, Grundy County had issues with siren activation from their primary controller. The buttons to activate were being pressed but the intended sirens were not initiating for the intended sirens. The operator continued to attempt activation unknowingly activation the sirens in the NE quadrant several times between 10:00-10:15am. Since this was the normal monthly test the public was not alarmed at the activations but the concern was the number of activations and the length of time the sirens sounded. Grundy county sent out a communication via Social Media and Nixle to the public to make them aware of the issue. A complete investigation was conducted and the activation logs and photos are attached.

During 1R19 outage trip testing, the HV-050-112 trip linkage moved in the trip direction at the appropriate setpoint without tripping the valve as designed. The turbine remained spinning, uncharacteristic of a tripped valve and upon further review, the valve linkage was still intact with no MCR alarm. Was directed to manually close the HV-050-112 and while closing, the trip linkage appeared to move the remaining distance.

In response to sealed in annunciator 09-3-3-18 HPCI EXH DRN POT LVL HI, IMD was dispatched and discovered 23LS-98 HPCI Turbine Exhaust Drain Pot Level Switch was full of water. After further investigation, operators discovered that condensate was present in the HPCI turbine casing.

While performing Tendon Grease Can Level Check PM P600011, Tendon Can #78 was found to have low grease. Although a layer of thick grease was observed covering the top of the tendon buttonhead hardware, draw-down was observed in the center hole of the button head. This indicates that the grease level would have dropped below the bottom of the buttonhead hardware and portions of the supporting buttonhead shims. Despite the lowered grease level, a coating of grease covers hardware components. Approximately (2) gallons of grease were added to the tendon can to restore its level. No free water was identified in the grease during the PM activities.

There are no safety or operability impacts from this notification, and all MAPLHGRs remain valid as related to this IR. The Nine Mile Point Unit 1 (NMP1) TRACG-LOCA analysis basedeck utilized a generic scram control rod drive (CRD) position curve with no delay consistent with NEDE-33005P-A (TRACG Application for Emergency Core Cooling Systems / Loss-of-Coolant-Accident Analyses for BWR/2-6", Revision 2, May 2018); however, NEDE-33005P-A further stipulates that the plant technical specification scram curve should be utilized. The NMP1 basedeck is updated with the inputs corresponding to the NMP1 scram curve and a conservative delay between LOCA signal and CRD motion, which results in the core power level being slightly elevated for a short period of time. The current analysis of record peak clad temperature is 2105 deg F with a limit of 2200 deg F. Previous assessments include an 8 deg F improvement for a net PCT of 2097 deg F as reported in NMP1L3444 dated January 27, 2022. The Nine Mile Point Unit 1 TRACG-LOCA basedeck is updated with the correct scram reactivity curve and conservative delay. The estimated PCT impact is 0 deg F. The estimated maximum local oxidation impact is < 0.2%. There is no impact on the Core-Wide Metal-Water reaction. The notification is applicable to NMP Unit 1 only. The PCT impact of 0 deg F is well less than the 50 deg F reporting requirement. The discrepancy will be reported with the annual reporting letter due 1/27/2023. There is no SAF 1.4 applicability from this issue based on remaining within LOCA limits. In addition to PCT limits discussed above, the LOCA analysis also analyzes for cladding oxidation and Core-Wide Metal-Water reaction. From the analysis of record, Maximum local oxidation is less than 12.5% and core-wide metal-water reaction rate (hydrogen generation) is less than 1.0%. Coolable geometry and long-term cooling are maintained. NMP Unit 1 has a local oxidation limit of 13% based on the TRACG-LOCA implementation. The estimated maximum local oxidation impact is < 0.2%. There is no impact on the Core-Wide Metal-Water reaction.

At 1116 CDT on 7/30/22, a repeat condition (IR 4513848) occurred where crib house suction bay levels were reported < 501.5' due to buildup of grass on bar racks. Entered TS 3.7.3 condition A (RA A.1 mode 3 in 12 hours, RA A.2 mode 4 in 36 hours). Actions were in-progress to clear grass debris off the intake bar racks. At 1745 CDT on 7/30/22, crib house suction bay levels were reported at >501.5'. Exit TS 3.7.3 condition A.

On 10/2/2022 at 0215 the 1AR12J rad levels rose to alert. BAR actions were followed however the alert cleared 10 seconds later. Trending the 1AR12J rad levels has shown that they have risen over the last 90 days. The BAR allows Rad Protection to evaluate for a setpoint change based on rad levels. This IR is being written to initiate the process for the evaluation.

1AR012J Alert alarm is coming in and clearing in the Main Control Room. This is getting more frequent as time goes by (approximately 20 times per shift). It is becoming a Main Control Room distraction. IR#4526257 has already been written on this issue and the problem has not been resolved. The solution is easy. Raise the setpoints on the 1AR012J. This is not an issue with the 1AR012J. The reason that the setpoints need to be raised is because background radiation levels rise in containment over time. Every day the units are diluted, neutron leakage increases, and background radiation levels go up. Please have Health Physics perform their calculation and give the new setpoints to Ops. That way we can make the proper changes to 1AR012J and eliminate this Main Control Room Distraction.

ENS phone in the Main Control Room did not ring. The NRC received a busy signal when calling for plant status. The MCR ENS phone appears mechanically sound and has the appropriate connections, but has no dial tone. The NRC HOO contacted the LaSalle Unit 1 Supervisor at extension 2300 to verify a communication link. MCR was able to contact the NRC via the Main phone number listed on the ENS phone (301-816-5100). Commercial phone lines are functional and are a viable method of communicating information about an emergency. MCR is not experiencing a major loss of communications.

This report is a follow-up to IR 4368043, 'MSIVs are NOT PCIVs,' and IR 4300127, which provide sufficient evidence to conclude that MSIV leakage rate Technical Specification Surveillance Requirement (TSSR) 3.6.1.3.10 is potentially inadequate. IR 4300127 explains: "As described In SAND2008-6601, the MSIV leakage misconception becomes embarrassingly obvious. It is both a regulatory and a design basis misconception. The MSIVs are considered primary CONTAINMENT isolation valves in current plant UFSAR/technical specifications and not REACTOR isolation valves. Their design basis/TS allowable leakage rates are based on PRIMARY CONTAINMENT pressure ~50 psig when their actual leakage rates are a function of REACTOR pressure ~1000 psig." Note: SAND2008-6601, "Analysis of Main Steam Isolation Valve Leakage in Design Basis Accidents ... "is the Sandia National Laboratories study that discredited NRC Regulatory Guide 1.183. IR 4368043 states: "flow rates are directly proportional to pressure," which is consistent with Bernoulli's Law. Flow (MSIV leakage rate) is proportional to the square root of differential pressure; therefore, TSSR 3.6.1.3.10 is also non-conservative. IR 4368043 exposed the systematic removal of 'Reactor Coolant Isolation Valve' and similar descriptions of MSIVs from plant TS and UFSAR. NRC Generic Letter 91-08, "Removal of Component Lists From Technical Specifications," prompted the effort by eliminating lists that identified MSIVs as "Reactor Coolant Isolation Valves." Aided by GL 91-08, NUREG-1433/1434 effectively blurred the regulatory distinctions between MSIVs (GDC-55) and PCIVs (GDC-56). Notably, the one Constellation BWR plant that did NOT adopt "Standard Technical Specifications" (equivalent to NUREG-1433), currently identifies MSIVs as "Reactor Coolant System Isolation Valves" in TS 3.2.7/4.2.7 and lists MSIVs in UFSAR Table Vl-3a, titled "Reactor Coolant System Isolation Valves." Nine Mile Point Unit 1, UFSAR Section VI (Rev. 26, October 2019) includes the following definitions: -"Containment isolation valves (also called isolation valves) are defined as any valves which are relied upon to perform a containment isolation function on lines penetrating the primary reactor containment and include all reactor coolant isolation valves and all primary containment isolation valves." -"Primary containment isolation valves are containment isolation valves on lines penetrating the primary reactor containment connecting directly to the free space enclosed by the containment." -"Reactor coolant isolation valves are containment isolation valves which are on lines penetrating the primary reactor containment and are connected to the RCS (or a system containing reactor coolant) and function as reactor coolant pressure boundary (RCPB) components." The concerns and information identified in IR 4368043 are consistent with the NRC approved, MSIV Technical Specifications at NMP1. By company procedure, IR 4368043 recommended that TSSR 3.6.1.3.10 be evaluated in accordance with NRC Administrative Letter 98-10, "Dispositioning of Technical Specifications That Are Insufficient to Assure Plant Safety. " Despite the possibility that TSSR 3.6.1.3.10 might be inadequate, the company failed to comply with AL 98-10, asserting that evaluating the adequacy of the TSSR would "require that the station violate the current technical specifications and licensing basis documents in favor for other regulatory reports or NRC administrative documents (CAP 4368043-02)." The company unreasonably claimed that using the guidance provided AL 98-10 (now NRC Regulatory Guide 1.239/NEI 15-03, "Licensee Actions to Address Nonconservative Technical Specifications) --as the NRC intended-- is somehow illegal, because it would violate the (potentially) inadequate technical specification, or some other unspecified technical specifications or documents. Constellation (formerly Exelon) is the leading member of the Nuclear Energy Institute, the industry lobbying organization that developed NEI 15-03. Remarkably, the company defied the industry guidance which they developed and persuaded the NRC to adopt as RG 1.239. In their evaluation of IR 4368043, the company states: "The station will continue following current station technical specifications and licensing basis documents until told that these documents require revision as directed by a regulatory body." (4368043-02) Despite the company's indefensible defiance of RG 1.239, the NRC has not required them to disposition the potentially inadequate TSSR 3.6.1.3.10. There have been no regulatory consequences. Conversely, if the company complied with RG 1.239, they would be compelled to perform an Operability Evaluation (OP-AA-108-115, Attachment 1), which could not support MSIVs Operability because TSSR 3.6.1.3.10 does NOT ensure that MSIVs can satisfy their high pressure safety function to isolate the reactor coolant system. In the case of MSIV lnoperability, the company would legally be required to shut down the two Quad Cities reactors. Consequently, the NRC would have little choice but to admit that every BWR that adopted NUREG-1433/1434 has been legally unsafe since NUREG-1433/1434 were published (1995). The company's defiance of RG 1.239, "Licensee Actions to Address Nonconservative Technical Specifications," exposes a broad range of ethical, legal, and regulatory implications. Most important is the Operability of MSIVs (Units 1 and 2) which has yet to be evaluated.

On February 6th, 2023, at 0630hrs. EST, the Corporate MA EP Equipment Specialist was reviewing the Everbridge automated csv file data and identified a discrepancy in the total number of ERO members uploaded into Everbridge. Further review indicated an issue with all stations csv file uploads and did not include the vast majority of ERO members being uploaded into the Everbridge system. It was determined that, in the event of an actual emergency, Everbridge would not have notified the majority of the ERO (applicable to all stations). Additionally, the Main Control Room would have been notified by the Everbridge system of a successful activation of the ERO and would not have known to activate the backup notification systems within the required timeframe.

On February 6th, 2023, at 0630hrs. EST, the Corporate MA EP Equipment Specialist was reviewing the Everbridge automated csv file data and identified a discrepancy in the total number of ERO members uploaded into Everbridge. The individual reviewing the uploaded files discovered that the data files did not upload properly and that Everbridge may not notify all ERO individuals within the required 10 minutes of system initiation. During the time period of 0416 to 0752, Control Room Operators would have been unaware that the ERO notification was not successful. Therefore, this issue constitutes a loss of offsite communications capability. This loss of offsite communications capability affected all Constellation Nuclear Stations. Ginna had 2 records loaded at 0416 from the initial upload and 237 records loaded at 0737 completing Ginna's file restoration. Constellation resolved the issue for all the sites by 0752. Immediate actions taken by Corporate as found in IR 4552911: 1)The Corporate MA EP Equipment Specialist notified the Corporate EP Managers and IT SME's for the EP ERO Database system responsible for the automated upload process to Everbridge. 2)The Corporate MA EP Equipment Specialist began the process to restore all stations ERO Contacts using csv files previously uploaded to Everbridge from January 30, 2023. The first station's Everbridge csv file was restored at 0642 EST and the last stations Everbridge csv file was restored at 0752 EST. The Ginna file was restored at 07:37 EST and ERO notification sent at 0841 EST. 3)Corporate EP Management discussed reportability with Licensing and determined this event is an 8-hour report to the NRC. Report will be made by Corporate EP for all stations in our fleet. 4)Corporate EP Management discussed reportability with Fleet EP Managers and requirement to report to the NRC within 8 hours of discovery. Recommended Actions for Corporate as found in IR 4552911: 1)Determine cause of csv file discrepancies for all stations. 2)Corporate EP to perform a prompt investigation. 3)Corporate EP to perform a HURB. 4)Complete ENS Notification for the fleet. 5)Corporate EP to perform a Work Group Evaluation to determine cause and corrective actions for csv file discrepancies for all stations. What activities, processes, or procedures were involved? Why did the condition happen? What are the consequences? Determined to be an NRC Reportable Event for all Constellation Stations in the Nuclear Fleet. Any procedural requirements impacted? Identify any adverse physical conditions: List of Knowledgeable individuals and people notified: David Draghi, Michael Braswell, Christina Nelson, Tony Hightower

On February 6th, 2023, at 0530 CST, the Corporate MA EP Equipment Specialist was reviewing the Everbridge automated csv file data and identified a discrepancy in the total number of ERO members uploaded into Everbridge. Everbridge is the primary system used to notify ERO members in the event of an emergency and it is updated weekly via an automated cvs type file. Further review indicated an issue with all stations csv file uploads and did not include the vast majority of ERO members being uploaded into the Everbridge system. The ERO members who were not included in the automated cvs file were removed from the Everbridge system. While the csv file discrepancy existed, the Everbridge ERO Notification System would not have notified the majority of the ERO if required to be activated per the Emergency Plan. During this time, Control Room Operators would not have been aware that the primary system was not successful in notifying the ERO of an activation, and would not have recognized a need to implement a backup system. Loss of the Automated Callout System (all methods) results in a Loss of Emergency Preparedness function.

On 6/5/23 at 1741hrs., Corporate EP was notified by Monroe County that two residents reported that a Ginna Siren had sounded for approximately 1 minute. Corporate siren vendor ANS was notified and after conducting a poll of the Ginna siren system was able to confirm that siren 10 had a spurious activation. A siren technician has been dispatched. Upon arrival the technician disabled the siren. Siren 10 has been taken out of service. Troubleshooting and repairs of siren 10 have been scheduled. This siren impacts 0.0% of the total EPZ Population. This percentage DOES NOT MEET the reportable threshold. The spurious siren actuation DOES MEET a reportable threshold per LS-AA-1110 in SAF-1.9

Cycle 44 routine RCS radiochemistry samples indicate the presence of a fuel defect. Additional RCS radiochemistry samples have been obtained since IR 04676504 and analyzed by Station, Nuclear Fuels, and Westinghouse subject-matter experts who have concluded that there is a fuel defect present in the Cycle 44 core. This IR is being generated per NF-AA-430, Failed Fuel Action Plan, step 4.2.2. The fuel defect meets the threshold of Action Level 1 per NF-AA-430 Attachment 2 based on the observed step change in I-131 and Xe-133 activities, as well as the Xe-133/Xe-135 activity ratio exceeding 1.0. The current RCS radionuclide activities do not challenge Technical Specification LCO 3.4.16, RCS Specific Activity Limits for Dose Equivalent Xenon (DEX) or Dose Equivalent Iodine (DEI). The most recent DEX and DEI samples are 1.91 uCi/gm and 1.44 E-3 uCi/gm, respectively, compared to limits of less than 650 uCi/gm for DEX and 1.0 uCi/gm for DEI.

Aux Relay Cabinets Power Failure alarm was received. U1 remained in a stable operating condition. BwAR 1-4-A2 was utilized. NSO checked the 1PA024,5,6,7,8J cabinets in the AEER. On the 1PA028J, the "Cont PWR On" for DC 112 light was dark. The light was changed to verify it wasn't a bulb issue. EO was dispatched and reported DC 112, compt BR1, CKT 20 breaker was in the tripped position. 20E-1-4030DC22 shows this breaker feeding: 1RY8025 sol#2, which is normally closed and stayed closed. 1RE9159B sol #2, which is normally closed and stayed closed. 1CV8116, which is normally open and fails open. light indication was lost for 1CV8116. 1SD054B/D, these are the steam generator blowdown tap control valves for the 1A and 1D steam generators. 1A and 1D blowdown tap flows dropped to 0.

At approximately 1600 on 8/25, a loss of the commercial phone communications system occurred that affects the emergency notification system (ENS) and the functionality of an emergency response facility. This is an eight-hour, non-emergency notification of a loss of Emergency Assessment Capability. Communications via alternate methods were subsequently established. A timeline for repairs to communications by Frontier has not been established. Site maintenance, IT, and supply are engaged to drive the issue. This condition resulted in a complete loss of all internet access at the site and all commercial offsite phones except one cell phone in MCR and one for security and the MCR FLEX satellite phones.

At approximately 11:32 on 9/29/23, operations found that all onsite internet, the intranet, and network phone lines were no longer working. Test calls were used to confirm that the ENS, NARS, cellular phones, and a dedicated commercial phone line were all still functional.

During performance of PM P312155 under WO C93843350, procedure M-95 instructs craft to remove top cover of CV-2024 & CV-2025 to inspect internals and verify freedom of movement. Both valves are rusted and stuck in a partial open position. Attempts to exercise flapper were unsuccessful.

At approximately 16:40 on 10/10/23, operations found that all onsite internet, the intranet, and network phone lines were no longer working. Test calls were used to confirm that the ENS, NARS, cellular phones, and a dedicated commercial phone line all were still functional.

Previously written, IR 04718861 identified an air void in the HPCI discharge piping. An evaluation of the air void was performed and determine the HPCI system will function as designed and as specified in the UFSAR. This conclusion was based on the results of calculations DRE24-0002 (Rev. 000) and DRE24-0003 (Rev. 000). These calculations were documented under DCR 640811.

Approximately 0237 on 4/30/24, meteorological (MET) data was lost to the plant process computer (PPC). NSO noted that data from the MET tower was showing to be invalid on PPC points from R226 to R237. (Excluding R233)

NRC received a busy signal when calling for plant status. The ENS phone in the Main Control Room did not ring. The NRC HOO contacted the LaSalle Unit 1 Supervisor at extension 2300 to verify a communication link and obtain plant status. The MCR was able to contact the NRC via the Main phone number listed on the ENS phone (301-816-5100). The MCR ENS phone appears mechanically sound and has the appropriate connections but has no dial tone. Commercial phone lines are functional and are a viable method of communicating information about an emergency. MCR is not experiencing a major loss of communications. The NRC HOO stated that they would place a ticket with Verizon to resolve the issue. The LaSalle EP Manager contact information was given as a POC for Verizon.

DIER 20241107 EN 57221 - Automatic Reactor Scram Due to Manual Turbine Trip (Peach Bottom) "At 0728 EST on July 10, 2024, with Unit 2 in Mode 1 at 24 percent power, the reactor automatically scrammed due to a manual turbine trip. The [reactor] scram was not complex with all systems responding normally. Reactor vessel level reached the low-level set-point following the scram, resulting in valid Group 2 and Group 3 containment isolation signals. "Operations responded using emergency operating procedures and stabilized the plant in Mode 3. Decay heat is being removed by discharging steam to the main condenser using the turbine bypass valves. Unit 3 was not affected. "There was no impact on the health and safety of the public or plant personnel. The NRC Resident Inspector has been notified."

U-1 and U-2 ERDS not updating properly. The last reported date updated is 8/6/24 at 9:04 pm. ERDS status reads reconnecting. An attempt was made to perform a hard reboot and reset ERDS PPC with no changes.

Main control room received an unexpected annunciator 09-75-2-6 Rx Bldg Vent Isol. The reactor building isolated on a high building differential pressure (> 1" WG). SBGT was started and reactor building differential pressure was brought back negative. Investigation revealed all supply fans (66FN-5A, 5B, and 5C) and both below refuel floor exhaust fans (66FN-12A and 12B) were off/not running (Above refuel floor exhaust fans 66FN-13A and 13B were off as expected). No obvious abnormalities were noted in the field. Upon RB ventilation restoration, 66FN-12A would not start. Ventilation was restarted using 66FN-12B. All other fans restarted as normal.

There were coordination issues identified with the E22 bus outage and service water sluice gate inspection (WO 5319367). It was identified that these tasks cannot be performed in parallel. AO 56E.3-2 "E224-R-B, E224-T-B AND E224-P-A MOTOR CONTROL CENTERS OR E224 EMERGENCY LOAD CENTER DEENERGIZATION" directly conflicts with the guidance in WO 5319367.

MCR received a High alarm on the Gas channel for 0PR33J during restoration of VV HVAC from scheduled work. The particulate and iodine channel trends remained steady. The VV fan tripped and 0B train makeup filter placed itself online as expected. Work was completed for changing filter 0VV01FB (W/O#5425462-01) which required VV secured and subsequently restarted. Shortly after VV was restored, the 0PR33J saw a spike on the gas channel which led to the plant realigning. Previous IR# 4829100 & 4826978 documents 0PR33J spiking only on the gas channel as seen during todays event.

Power Reactor Event Number: 57514 Facility: River Bend Region: 4 State: LA Unit: [1] [] [] RX Type: [1] GE-6 NRC Notified By: Terry Blanchard HQ OPS Officer: Josue Ramirez Notification Date: 01/25/2025 Notification Time: 20:05 [ET] Event Date: 01/25/2025 Event Time: 17:07 [CST] Last Update Date: 01/25/2025 Emergency Class: Non Emergency Person (Organization): Deese, Rick (R4DO) Power Reactor Unit Info UnitSCRAM CodeRX CritInitial PWRInitial RX ModeCurrent PWRCurrent RX Mode 1NY100Power Operation100Power Operation Event Text OFFSITE NOTIFICATION DUE TO WASTE WATER DISCHARGE The following information was provided by the licensee via phone and email: "On January 25, 2025, at 1707 CST, River Bend Station performed a notification to the Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality per the Louisiana Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (LPDES) permit (LA0042731) due to a wastewater leak. The wastewater leak originated at a sewage lift pump station and resulted in an unauthorized discharge. There was no impact to the health and safety of the public or plant personnel. During performance of STP M-472-2 under W/O C93825294, U2 PAL Door test was unable to hold required 52-54 psig.

NRC received a busy signal when calling for plant status. The ENS phone in the Main Control Room did not ring. The NRC HOO contacted the LaSalle Unit 1 Supervisor at extension 2300 to verify a communication link and obtain plant status. The MCR was able to contact the NRC via the Main phone number listed on the ENS phone (301-816-5100). The MCR ENS phone appears mechanically sound and has the appropriate connections but has no dial tone. Commercial phone lines are functional and are a viable method of communicating information about an emergency. MCR is not experiencing a major loss of communications.

While performing DIS 0250-01 under WO# 05612925-01 it was found that dPIS 3-0261-2N was found OOT during testing. Unit 3 has an As Found setpoint tolerance of 223.4 to 242.6 psid where the As Found trip setpoint was found at 315.8 psid. This is higher than our tech spec allowable value of </= 252.6. Needle was sticking at ~170 PSID. The reset was 219.1 PSID. The needle was not touching the glass or faceplate.

During shift turnover, the MCR received a report that the temporary frac tank staged to support the new sewage plant mod was overflowing. FS responded to the storage tank and confirmed that the tank was overflowing. This tank is currently staged to support the new sewage plant effluent water. The tank that is overflowing contains water that was processed by the sewage treatment plant, and when placed in service would be released to the river. The mote the tank is staged on had a corner that was folded over, prior to leaving the mote was restored to the proper position. See attached photos. Environmental, chemistry, and the tank pump out company were contacted. The new sewage plant would not be considered plant equipment; no processes or procedures are in place for peach bottom employees to operate the new equipment. Operations is making hourly plant announcements to secure excessive domestic water usage to prevent unnecessary input to the sewage plant.

U-1 and U-2 ERDS not updating properly. The last reported date updated is 6/16/25 at 11:59 pm. ERDS status reads reconnecting. An attempt was made to perform a hard reboot and reset ERDS PPC with no changes.

Received the 2PM06J-B208 alarm for Serv Bldg TSC HVAC Panel Trouble alarm. Dispatched an EO who reported that the supply air flow low alarm was in 0PLC7J-B201. EO performed all LOR actions. EO discovered that the fan belts broken for the 0VS10C and was causing the alarm.
